title: Germline genomic and phenomic landscape of clonal hematopoiesis in 323,112 individuals

finding: The SNP rs2237892, located near KCNQ1, was associated with placental weight (PW). It exhibited a maternal parent-of-origin effect, where the association was conferred by the maternally transmitted allele, consistent with the known maternal-only expression of KCNQ1. It also played a role in influencing insulin levels, thereby linking fetal genetics to placental growth.
title: Genome-wide association study of placental weight in 179,025 children and parents reveals distinct and shared genetic influences between placental and fetal growth

finding: The SNP rs234864 was reported as a maternally-transmitted effect for birth weight (BW). It was associated with both BW and PW in the study, indicating a connection between maternal genetics and placental development.
title: Genome-wide association study of placental weight in 179,025 children and parents reveals distinct and shared genetic influences between placental and fetal growth

finding: The SNP rs174546 was associated with lowered risk of schizophrenia through its role in the FADS gene cluster, which is implicated in the desaturation of fatty acids. Specifically, higher levels of long-chain omega-3 fatty acids, such as DHA, were linked to a decreased odds ratio (ORIVW: 0.83, 95% CI: 0.75-0.92) for schizophrenia.
title: Causal associations between fatty acid measures and schizophrenia – a two-sample Mendelian randomization study

finding: In East Asian analysis, this SNP reached genome-wide significance (p=2.43e-14, MAF=0.002, OR=58.56) indicating a potential novel association for beta thalassemia.
title: Large-scale trans-ethnic replication and discovery of genetic associations for rare diseases with self-reported medical data

finding: The promoter variant rs35705950:G>T in MUC5B was found to decrease risk for IPF (OR = 0.50, P = 3.9 × 10^-80), showcasing a complex relationship with COVID-19 severity and respiratory conditions.
title: A second update on mapping the human genetic architecture of COVID-19

finding: The SNP rs780053569 was significantly associated with proxy Alzheimer's disease when analyzing pLOF and high-confidence missense variants. This variant caused an amino acid substitution from serine to leucine (p.S602L) in a critical region of SORL1, with a high CADD score of 26.2, indicating potential pathogenic implications.
title: Rare Variant Aggregation in 148,508 Exomes Identifies Genes Associated with Proxy Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs139351633 was significant in the study, causing an amino acid substitution (p.Q614H) in SORL1 with a CADD score of 24.2. This substitution was predicted to affect protein stability, contributing to the variant's association with Alzheimer's disease.
title: Rare Variant Aggregation in 148,508 Exomes Identifies Genes Associated with Proxy Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs140327834 was noted as a rare high-confidence missense variant associated with proxy Alzheimer's disease. It caused an amino acid substitution and had a significant p-value of 9.81×10^-5, although it was categorized as likely benign in previous assessments.
title: Rare Variant Aggregation in 148,508 Exomes Identifies Genes Associated with Proxy Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs371418037 was involved in the significant association with proxy Alzheimer's disease, leading to an amino acid change in SORL1, which was linked to alterations in protein stability. This variant had a CADD score indicating its potential impact.
title: Rare Variant Aggregation in 148,508 Exomes Identifies Genes Associated with Proxy Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs529302116 is an intergenic variant located on Chr11, associated with populations of South Asian ancestry. It was identified as a significant variant in a South Asian sample, demonstrating strong linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs33915217, an HBB intronic variant, despite not reaching genome-wide significance in non-South Asian GWAS.
title: Statistical haemoglobin thresholds to define anaemia across the lifecycle

finding: The rs7110845 variant was reported as a deleterious missense variant within the POU2F3 gene, which plays a critical role in keratinocyte differentiation. It was found to be highly significant with a p-value of 2.3×10^-13, suggesting its relevance in psoriasis pathophysiology.
title: GWAS meta-analysis of psoriasis identifies new susceptibility alleles impacting disease mechanisms and therapeutic targets

finding: The SNP rs610932, located in the gene MS4A6A, was identified as correlating with decreased risk for Alzheimer's disease (AD) in several meta-analyses. Additionally, a shared causal variant was found in MS4A6A that affected a locus near MS4A4A in contemporary AD genome-wide association studies (GWAS). Transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) indicated that increased expression of MS4A6A in monocytes was associated with AD risk, while DNA methylation studies suggested that MS4A6A expression might mediate this risk. Furthermore, MS4A6A was involved in the formation of atherosclerosis and demonstrated differential associations with various lipid classes between AD cases and controls.
title: Local genetic covariance analysis with lipid traits identifies novel loci for early-onset Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs1800497, located in the ANKK1 gene, was found to be significantly associated with the time to LiD, showing a beta of 0.24 with a significance level of p = 8.89 x 10^-3, indicating its role in LiD risk.
title: Genetic meta-analysis of levodopa induced dyskinesia in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs6265 was significantly associated with time to LiD, exhibiting a beta of 0.19 and a p-value of 4.95 x 10^-2. This SNP is situated in the BDNF gene and suggests its involvement in the development of LiD.
title: Genetic meta-analysis of levodopa induced dyskinesia in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs10750025 was identified as the top genetic variant linked to the common liability to addiction. It was located on the dopamine receptor D2 gene (DRD2), supporting the role of dopamine in addiction risk.
title: Novel insights into the common heritable liability to addiction: a multivariate genome-wide association study

finding: The SNP rs35023999 was also among the 42 identified variants dealing with the common liability to addiction, but detailed functional implications were not specified.
title: Novel insights into the common heritable liability to addiction: a multivariate genome-wide association study

finding: The SNP rs1801028 in the DRD2 gene was significantly associated with PANSS negative symptoms in African American patients.
title: Pharmacogenomic diversity in psychiatry: Challenges and Opportunities in Africa

finding: Variants such as rs1125394 in the DRD2 gene were associated with improved response to clozapine among African American patients.
title: Pharmacogenomic diversity in psychiatry: Challenges and Opportunities in Africa

finding: SNP rs2514218 was associated with decreased expression of the DRD2 gene, which was unexpected given its role in dopamine signaling related to schizophrenia. This negative association suggested a potential mechanism whereby genetic risk for schizophrenia could lead to reduced control of presynaptic dopamine release, implicating a crucial aspect of schizophrenia's genetic landscape.
title: Genetic and environmental regulation of caudate nucleus transcriptome: insight into schizophrenia risk and the dopamine system

finding: This SNP was associated with decreasing height, identified as an intronic signal within the SLC12A1 gene. SLC12A1 is known to be associated with height and Bartter syndrome, which is characterized by growth retardation, highlighting the potential impact of this rare variant despite its modest effect size.
title: A Genomics England haplotype reference panel and the imputation of the UK Biobank

finding: The variant rs11031006 at the 11p14.1 locus was associated with multiple gynecological traits and linked to the gene FSHB through a single-cell multimodal pituitary dataset, highlighting SCENT’s capability to pinpoint causal variants and their gene connections specifically within disease-relevant tissues.
title: Tissue-specific enhancer-gene maps from multimodal single-cell data identify causal disease alleles

finding: The SNP rs10736549 located in the CNTN5 gene was identified as a female-specific locus for neuroticism. It met genome-wide significance and was associated with higher neuroticism scores in females.
title: Sex-specific genetic and transcriptomic liability to neuroticism

finding: The SNP rs72995548 connected to the HSPB2 gene was identified as a female-specific risk locus for neuroticism. It reached genome-wide significance, indicating its importance in the expression of neuroticism in females.
title: Sex-specific genetic and transcriptomic liability to neuroticism

finding: rs11236533 was highlighted for disrupting a CTCF binding site and had implications for reduced expression of DGAT2, associated with gout risk.
title: A genome-wide association analysis of 2,622,830 individuals reveals new pathogenic pathways in gout

finding: This variant was identified among those connected to DGAT2 through GeneHancer, suggesting a role in gout pathogenesis.
title: A genome-wide association analysis of 2,622,830 individuals reveals new pathogenic pathways in gout

finding: SNP rs10899119 was also noted as part of the set influencing the DGAT2 gene, implying its contribution to gout.
title: A genome-wide association analysis of 2,622,830 individuals reveals new pathogenic pathways in gout

finding: Found to be connected via GeneHancer to DGAT2, this SNP plays a role in the gout genetic architecture.
title: A genome-wide association analysis of 2,622,830 individuals reveals new pathogenic pathways in gout

finding: This variant was recognized as part of the regulatory network involving DGAT2, important for understanding gout.
title: A genome-wide association analysis of 2,622,830 individuals reveals new pathogenic pathways in gout

finding: The presence of rs11236530 was noted in the linkage to DGAT2 through physical connections, impacting gout development.
title: A genome-wide association analysis of 2,622,830 individuals reveals new pathogenic pathways in gout

finding: SNP rs61897795 was associated with increased expression of the FADS2 gene, influencing metabolic pathways related to gout.
title: A genome-wide association analysis of 2,622,830 individuals reveals new pathogenic pathways in gout

finding: The SNP rs571342427 was identified as a candidate causal variant for type 2 diabetes, with pancreatic islet cells and pancreatic beta cells inferred as high confidence cell types. The insulin gene (INS) was noted as a target gene, linking this SNP directly to insulin regulation and type 2 diabetes pathophysiology.
title: Inferring causal cell types of human diseases and risk variants from candidate regulatory elements

finding: The rs28904921 variant, c.7271T>G in ATM, was associated with breast cancer and was identified in an Orkney pedigree, corroborating earlier findings of strong association with breast cancer risk.
title: Two founder variants account for over 90% of pathogenic BRCA alleles in Orkney and Shetland

finding: The SNP rs7934107-T in the CADM1 gene was associated with the behavior of 'working up a sweat'. This finding contributed to the understanding of physical activity-related traits, showing an interesting connection with behavior patterns.
title: Genome-wide association study of liking of physical activity in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs6589488-A in the CADM1 gene was previously found to be associated with anorexia nervosa. This allele was noted to be positively and moderately correlated (r²=0.39) with the rs7934107-T SNP, suggesting shared genetic pathways that might influence both PA behaviors and eating disorders.
title: Genome-wide association study of liking of physical activity in the UK Biobank

finding: This SNP was found to be associated with the mild progression subtype (Subtype I) of PD.
title: Comprehensively modeling heterogeneous symptom progression for Parkinson’s disease subtyping

finding: The variant rs571342427 was cited with an OR of 1.89 in relation to T2D risk, underscoring its possible contribution to the disease's etiology alongside rare GLP1R variants.
title: Rare variants of the glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor (GLP1R) gene are overrepresented in a severe obesity cohort and associated with type 2 diabetes in the UK Biobank

finding: The variant rs35705950:G>T located in the promoter of MUC5B was identified as protective against hospitalization with an odds ratio (OR = 0.83; 95% CI = 0.86, 0.93; P = 6.5 × 10^-9). This promoter variant increases MUC5B expression in the lung and is linked to both idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis risk and improved survival in IPF patients.
title: Mapping the human genetic architecture of COVID-19: an update

finding: The rs12252-C variant in the Interferon-Induced Transmembrane Protein 3 (IFITM3) gene was reported to be associated with disease severity in COVID-19. This genetic variant was implicated in an increased susceptibility to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 infection and mortality, as demonstrated in global epidemiological studies.
title: SARS-CoV-2 genomic surveillance identifies naturally occurring truncations of ORF7a that limit immune suppression

finding: The rs35705950 allele was associated with alveolar or parietoalveolar pneumonitis in the Hispanic American cohort. Earlier studies established the rs35705950-T allele's connection to idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and its protective role against COVID-19.
title: A comprehensive knowledgebase of known and predicted human genetic variants associated with COVID-19 susceptibility and severity

finding: The SNP rs964184 was identified to have a significant sex*gene interaction effect, specifically influencing VLDL cholesterol concentrations only in females. This SNP, previously noted as a risk factor for metabolic syndrome and coronary artery disease (CAD), illustrated how dietary factors and genetic variants could interplay in modulating metabolic outcomes, particularly regarding triglyceride levels.
title: Pleiotropic and sex-specific genetic architecture of circulating metabolic markers

finding: The MUC5B promoter variant rs35705950 was assessed for its association with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) interstitial lung abnormalities (ILA). It was identified as the strongest known genetic risk factor for both ILA and RA-associated interstitial lung disease (RA-ILD). The study found that, after controlling for confounders such as age, sex, and smoking status, the odds ratio (OR) for ILA in RA cases compared to non-RA was significantly elevated, at approximately 4.15. Furthermore, when factoring in the MUC5B genotype, RA cases displayed an even higher odds ratio for fibrotic ILA at 9.26. This finding underscored the importance of genetic factors, particularly the MUC5B variant, in predicting ILA development among RA patients.
title: Prevalence and mortality associations of interstitial lung abnormalities in rheumatoid arthritis within a multicenter prospective cohort of smokers

finding: This SNP was identified as a high-confidence protein truncation variant within a novel locus associated with HF.
title: Common- and rare-variant genetic architecture of heart failure across the allele frequency spectrum

finding: This missense variant was linked to the MYBPC3 gene, relevant to HF, and indicated its importance in the genetic study of HF.
title: Common- and rare-variant genetic architecture of heart failure across the allele frequency spectrum

finding: This SNP served as a tagging SNP for a missense variant in MYBPC3, highlighting its association with HF.
title: Common- and rare-variant genetic architecture of heart failure across the allele frequency spectrum

finding: This SNP was noted to have damaging predictions supported by high CADD scores, highlighting its potential relevance in reading and cognitive ability.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association analysis of quantitative reading skill and dyslexia improves gene discovery

finding: The SNP rs174564, an intronic variant of the FADS2 gene, was highlighted as a putative shared causal variant with a PP of 0.95 concerning the relationship between circulating levels of omega-3% and the risk of bipolar disorder (BIP). The A allele was associated with an increased level of DHA% (β = 0.28, P < 1 × 10^-300) and omega-3% (β = 0.39, P < 1 × 10^-300), while also showing a protective effect against BIP with an odds ratio (OR) of 0.93.
title: Shared genetic basis informs the roles of polyunsaturated fatty acids in brain disorders

finding: The SNP rs3817334 was associated with BMI and was found to be an mQTL genetic variant linked to the CpG site cg17580616, as well as an eQTL genetic variant associated with the gene ACP2. The probability of colocalization H4 for this association was also 100%.
title: Expression quantitative trait methylation analysis elucidates gene regulatory effects of DNA methylation: The Framingham Heart Study

finding: Similar to rs3817334, the SNP rs10838738 was associated with BMI and acted as an mQTL variant correlated with the CpG site cg17580616, and an eQTL variant related to the gene ACP2. This SNP also exhibited a probability of colocalization H4 of 100%.
title: Expression quantitative trait methylation analysis elucidates gene regulatory effects of DNA methylation: The Framingham Heart Study

finding: The SNP rs1064608 was associated with BMI, functioning as an mQTL associated with the CpG site cg17580616, and as an eQTL variant associated with the gene ACP2. The association presented a probability of colocalization H4 of 100%.
title: Expression quantitative trait methylation analysis elucidates gene regulatory effects of DNA methylation: The Framingham Heart Study

finding: rs174573 was identified as a novel SNP associated with both hypothyroidism and chronic sinusitis, with significant p-values for each condition (P_hypothyroidism=1.30e-07, P_chronic_sinusitis=1.04e-07). As a missense variant in FADS2, it is involved in fatty acid metabolism and has implications in the inflammatory response associated with these diseases.
title: Shared genetic etiology between hypothyroidism and complex diseases: a large-scale genome-wide cross-trait analysis

finding: rs12806363 was identified as a novel SNP related to both hypothyroidism and sarcoidosis, exhibiting significant p-values (P_hypothyroidism=6.4e-08, P_sarcoidosis=1.52e-06). It is an intron variant within the RPS6KA4 gene, which encodes for a kinase involved in cellular signaling pathways.
title: Shared genetic etiology between hypothyroidism and complex diseases: a large-scale genome-wide cross-trait analysis

finding: The SNP rs312777, located within the LRP5 gene region, was linked to preterm delivery with a significant p-value of 6.6 x 10^-9. It showed weak association with gestational duration (p-value = 3.9 x 10^-3), indicating its influence primarily on mechanisms related to early parturition.
title: Genetic effects on the timing of parturition and links to fetal birth weight

finding: In individuals of European ancestry, rs174576 was linked to higher odds of multiple cardiovascular diseases, particularly ischemic stroke, peripheral artery disease, and venous thromboembolism. The data indicated that increased PUFA biosynthesis, proxied by rs174576 near the FADS1/2 locus, contributed to these associations.
title: The impact of fatty acids biosynthesis on the risk of cardiovascular diseases in Europeans and East Asians: A Mendelian randomization study

finding: The rs174546 SNP from the FADS1/2 locus was associated with a lower concentration of shorter chain omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids while increasing the concentration of longer chain fatty acids. This variant was also linked to numerous traits including lipid and glycaemic traits, among others, indicating a significant impact on fatty acid metabolism.
title: The impact of fatty acids biosynthesis on the risk of cardiovascular diseases in Europeans and East Asians: A Mendelian randomization study

finding: The SNP rs1582763, an intergenic variant in the MS4A locus, was associated with reduced risk for Alzheimer's disease (AD) and higher levels of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) soluble TREM2. Carriers exhibited a trend for decreased proportions of activated microglia in the Mic.1 state and increased proportions in the Mic.3 state, which showed a proinflammatory profile. This suggested that the rs1582763-A allele contributed to altering the microglial response, pointing to its role in neuroinflammation and possibly conferring resilience against AD.
title: A landscape of the genetic and cellular heterogeneity in Alzheimer disease

finding: The intron variant rs2845878 in FAT3 was noted for its association with right putamen and lacked symmetry when compared with left putamen. This SNP was linked to brain volume metrics according to GWAS catalog results.
title: Beyond Volume: Unraveling the Genetics of Human Brain Geometry

finding: The rs11549407-A variant was significantly associated with beta Thalassemia (ICD10: D56), demonstrating a strong statistical signal (p-value < 5.6e-62), even though it had low overall frequency, particularly absent in many ancestries aside from the NFE group where it was still rare.
title: Whole-genome sequencing of half-a-million UK Biobank participants

finding: The rs33915217-G variant demonstrated significant association with lower corpuscular hemoglobin concentration specifically in the South Asian (SAS) cohort, highlighting its unique prevalence in this population and further underscoring the enriched data provided by whole-genome sequencing.
title: Whole-genome sequencing of half-a-million UK Biobank participants

finding: This SNP was linked to increased expression of the lymphocyte specific protein 1 (LSP1) while decreasing the expression of IFITM10. It showcased an example of a variant that affected multiple molecular phenotypes in opposite directions.
title: Genetic analysis of blood molecular phenotypes reveals regulatory networks affecting complex traits: a DIRECT study

finding: Linked to the regulation of FEN1, FADS1, and FADS2 gene expressions, this SNP was associated with metabolites and indicated a role in fatty acid metabolism, illustrating its involvement in multiple regulatory networks.
title: Genetic analysis of blood molecular phenotypes reveals regulatory networks affecting complex traits: a DIRECT study

finding: The SNP chr11:65814557:A:G was identified as a lead variant at the MUS81 locus, which is essential for telomere recombination, thereby influencing LTL.
title: Genomic, phenomic, and geographic associations of leukocyte telomere length in the United States

finding: The study indicated that SNP rs174564 was a significant factor driving the causal association between polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) and cerebral aneurysm. This conclusion was drawn from a series of sensitivity analyses which demonstrated that when SNP rs174564 and its nearby SNPs within 500 kb of the FADS2 locus were removed, the p-values of the results all exceeded 0.0033, suggesting that this SNP was crucial in supporting the causal link between PUFA levels and the risk of cerebral aneurysm.
title: Predicting the causal relationship between polyunsaturated fatty acids and cerebral aneurysm risk from a Mendelian randomization study

finding: Also previously reported as significantly associated with NAFLD, this SNP demonstrated a notable role in the genetic architecture of the disease.
title: A genome-wide association study for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease identifies novel genetic loci and trait-relevant candidate genes in the Million Veteran Program

finding: The deletion mismatch at this SNP, associated with OR4P1P, exhibited a hazard ratio indicating a significant association with late rejection in liver transplantation. It also correlated with increased binding of transcription factors such as Foxa and ZBTB33, which might affect gene expression.
title: The impact of genome-wide histocompatibility on liver transplantation outcomes

finding: The SNP rs11031005 was associated with early age at first birth and correlated with increased risk of genitourinary system diseases and early menopause.
title: Extensive antagonistic variants across human genome

finding: The SNP rs11218343 was associated with the hub gene SORL1, emphasizing its importance in Alzheimer's risk.
title: Single-cell RNA sequencing data reveals rewiring of transcriptional relationships in Alzheimer’s Disease associated with risk variants

finding: The missense SNP rs140201358 resided in PNPLA2, essential for triglyceride hydrolysis in the liver. Its deficiency led to triglyceride accumulation and hepatic steatosis, linking it to both NAFLD and liver fat regulation.
title: Genome-wide association study of liver fat, iron, and extracellular fluid fraction in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs234866 was linked to the gene CDKN1C, which is expressed in the pancreas and was previously implicated in type 2 diabetes. This linking was supported by a high posterior inclusion probability of 0.97.
title: Combining SNP-to-gene linking strategies to pinpoint disease genes and assess disease omnigenicity

finding: The SNP rs74046911 was also linked to the gene CDKN1C for type 2 diabetes, with a posterior inclusion probability of 0.92, indicating its strong potential as a causal variant.
title: Combining SNP-to-gene linking strategies to pinpoint disease genes and assess disease omnigenicity

finding: This SNP was associated with female reproductive system traits such as the length of the menstrual cycle and endometriosis in the context of HG risk, suggesting relevant phenotypic consequences beyond just HG.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS of severe pregnancy nausea and vomiting identifies risk loci associated with appetite, insulin signaling, and brain plasticity

finding: This SNP emerged as a significant pleiotropic locus upon increasing sample size, indicating a potential association with age-related ocular conditions.
title: Genome-wide analysis of genetic pleiotropy and causal genes across three age-related ocular disorders

finding: The SNP rs1619882 was identified as significant after further validation in various ocular-related datasets, supporting its association with common ocular disorders.
title: Genome-wide analysis of genetic pleiotropy and causal genes across three age-related ocular disorders

finding: This SNP was noted for its specific chromatin signatures in Müller cells and its potential interaction with the ME3 gene, linking it to macular thickness, which is relevant for age-related ocular conditions.
title: Genome-wide analysis of genetic pleiotropy and causal genes across three age-related ocular disorders

finding: The presence of SNP rs35705950 previously associated with IPF was assessed to determine whether it influenced the chronic sputum production signal. Findings showed that the chronic sputum production GWAS signal remained independent of rs35705950.
title: Genome-wide association study of chronic sputum production implicates loci involved in mucus production and infection

finding: The SNP rs11603634, known for its association with moderate-to-severe asthma, was tested to ascertain its relation to chronic sputum production. It maintained an association with chronic sputum production indicating interrelation with asthmatic traits.
title: Genome-wide association study of chronic sputum production implicates loci involved in mucus production and infection

finding: The rs35705950-G variant conferred protective effects against interstitial lung disease, despite ILDs being a risk factor for COVID-19, suggesting complex interactions.
title: Integration of GWAS and multi-omic QTLs identifies uncharacterized COVID-19 gene-biotype and phenotype associations

finding: In individuals homozygous for the rs580382 CC genotype of KIRREL3, a significant impact of elevated CD34+CD133+ endothelial progenitor cells on reducing Alzheimer's disease (AD) risk was observed with a hazard ratio (HR) of 0.31 (95% CI: 0.17-0.57, p<0.001). This relationship remained significant when adjusted for age, sex, years of education, and APOE ε4 status.
title: Circulating Endothelial Progenitor Cells Reduce the Risk of Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The rs4144611 TT genotype of KIRREL3 also demonstrated a significant protective effect against AD when accompanied by higher frequencies of CD34+CD133+ progenitor cells, with a HR of 0.29 (95% CI: 0.15-0.57, p<0.001). This finding highlighted a critical interaction with cerebrovascular pathology, particularly in individuals suffering from hypertension or cerebral microbleeds.
title: Circulating Endothelial Progenitor Cells Reduce the Risk of Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The common nonsynonymous variant rs6265 (Val66Met) showed a highly significant association with BMI (SLP = -21.86) in the sample analyzed. It had uncorrected mean BMIs of 27.47, 27.22, and 26.96 for the Val/Val, Val/Met, and Met/Met genotypes respectively, with an estimated per-allele effect size of -0.19.
title: Weighted burden analysis in 200 000 exome-sequenced UK Biobank subjects characterises effects of rare genetic variants on BMI

finding: The SNP rs367670643 was associated with AD, indicating its role in the MS4A6A locus's contribution to Alzheimer's susceptibility.
title: Complex genetic interactions affect susceptibility to Alzheimer’s disease risk in the BIN1 and MS4A6A loci

finding: The SNP rs11605427 was found to be significantly associated with AD, among the findings from the MS4A6A region, demonstrating its potential impact on disease risk.
title: Complex genetic interactions affect susceptibility to Alzheimer’s disease risk in the BIN1 and MS4A6A loci

finding: The SNP rs2081545 was linked to AD risk, highlighting its importance in the genetic landscape associated with MS4A6A.
title: Complex genetic interactions affect susceptibility to Alzheimer’s disease risk in the BIN1 and MS4A6A loci

finding: The SNP rs610932 was found to be associated with Alzheimer's disease, particularly influencing the nonadditive genetic interactions seen within the MS4A6A locus.
title: Complex genetic interactions affect susceptibility to Alzheimer’s disease risk in the BIN1 and MS4A6A loci

finding: The SNP rs7935829's association with AD further exemplified the potential genetic variances present in the MS4A6A locus.
title: Complex genetic interactions affect susceptibility to Alzheimer’s disease risk in the BIN1 and MS4A6A loci

finding: The SNP rs1286289 was noted to be significantly associated with AD, indicating a negative effect on risk, with a P-value of 4.21E-07.
title: Complex genetic interactions affect susceptibility to Alzheimer’s disease risk in the BIN1 and MS4A6A loci

finding: The SNP rs670139 was included in analyses showing interactions with other SNPs in the context of AD, implicating its role in genetic susceptibility.
title: Complex genetic interactions affect susceptibility to Alzheimer’s disease risk in the BIN1 and MS4A6A loci

finding: The SNP rs2884183 was associated with AD, displaying an independent effect that highlighted its contribution to the disease.
title: Complex genetic interactions affect susceptibility to Alzheimer’s disease risk in the BIN1 and MS4A6A loci

finding: The variant rs10830963 at the MTNR1B locus exhibited a high posterior probability as a likely causal variant in type 2 diabetes, providing insight into the genetic underpinnings of the disease.
title: Rare Non-coding Variation Identified by Large Scale Whole Genome Sequencing Reveals Unexplained Heritability of Type 2 Diabetes

finding: The SNP rs149580940 in FIBIN was associated with FVC, having a P-value of 7.89x10^-10 and a beta of 0.0449, presenting new insights into the genetic basis of lung function.
title: Multi-trait and multi-ancestry genetic analysis of comorbid lung diseases and traits improves genetic discovery and polygenic risk prediction

finding: The rs968567 SNP within the TMEM258-FADS2 locus on chr.11q12.2 had a strong positive association with IgA levels (Beta=0.12, P=2.42×10^-41), indicating multiple independent signals and implicating candidate genes that regulate fatty acid desaturation.
title: Genetic regulation of serum IgA levels and susceptibility to common immune, infectious, kidney, and cardio-metabolic traits

finding: The rs102275 SNP identified within the same locus (chr.11q12.2) as rs968567 also exhibited a significant association with IgA levels (Beta=0.07, P=3.60×10^-29) pointing to the complex interplay within this genetic region.
title: Genetic regulation of serum IgA levels and susceptibility to common immune, infectious, kidney, and cardio-metabolic traits

finding: The rs10896045 SNP on chr.11q13.1 associated with IgA levels (Beta=0.07, P=2.57×10^-22) was also linked to increased IgA nephropathy risk.
title: Genetic regulation of serum IgA levels and susceptibility to common immune, infectious, kidney, and cardio-metabolic traits

finding: The rs4938518 SNP at the POU2AF1 locus on chr.11q23.1 indicated a positive association with IgA levels (Beta=0.056, P=7.01×10^-16) and was previously linked to IgA production.
title: Genetic regulation of serum IgA levels and susceptibility to common immune, infectious, kidney, and cardio-metabolic traits

finding: Found within the MYBPC3 gene, rs3729989 was indicated in known cardiomyopathies.
title: Deep representation learning of electrocardiogram reveals novel insights in cardiac structure and functions and connections to cardiovascular diseases

finding: Found in the ST5 gene, rs3794153 was noted as a novel variant with a CADD score suggesting potential pathogenicity.
title: Deep representation learning of electrocardiogram reveals novel insights in cardiac structure and functions and connections to cardiovascular diseases

finding: The SNP rs683250 was associated with increases of shape asymmetry in controls compared to demented populations. It was also found to be in perfect linkage disequilibrium with all rare variants in the DLG2 region associated with Alzheimer's Disease (AD) in the current study.
title: Region-based analysis of rare genomic variants in whole-genome sequencing datasets reveal two novel Alzheimer’s disease-associated genes: DTNB and DLG2

finding: The SNP rs286043 exhibited suggestive evidence for association with AD risk in the International Genomics of Alzheimer's Project (IGAP) with a p-value of 5e-06. It was in linkage disequilibrium with 4 out of 10 variants from the DLG2 region associated with AD, indicating potential allelic heterogeneity.
title: Region-based analysis of rare genomic variants in whole-genome sequencing datasets reveal two novel Alzheimer’s disease-associated genes: DTNB and DLG2

finding: The significant association of SNP rs7131682 with DED was highlighted, suggesting its relevance in the genetic predisposition linked to hot spring residency.
title: Hot Spring Residency and Disease Association: a Crossover Gene-Environment Interaction (GxE) Study in Taiwan

finding: Similar to rs11066188, the SNP rs10840606 was also detected as an outlier in the MR-PRESSO analysis. Its exclusion did not significantly alter the findings regarding the association of genetically determined birth weight with LADA, affirming the robustness of the inverse association previously noted.
title: Birth weight, BMI in adulthood and latent autoimmune diabetes in adults: A Mendelian randomization study

finding: The lead SNP for the PANX1 locus, rs76201528, showed an extremely significant p-value of 3.93e-350, indicating a strong association with cfDNA features. This locus was highlighted in the study as the most significant finding.
title: cfGWAS reveal genetic basis of cell-free DNA features

finding: The lead SNP for the PANX1 locus, rs1946143444, was identified with a p-value of 6.31e-10 in the replication study, highlighting it as an insertion-deletion variant with significant implications for cfDNA molecular signatures.
title: cfGWAS reveal genetic basis of cell-free DNA features

finding: The intergenic variant rs3018700 at locus 11q22 was associated with genes involved in crucial pregnancy functions, including PGR, which mediates progesterone's effects, important for endometrial maturation and placentation.
title: GWAS of preeclampsia and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy uncovers genes related to cardiometabolic, endothelial and placental function

finding: The SNP rs1006195 at the HEM3 locus displayed a trivariate association with PAD, CAD, and smoking behavior (trivariate P=1.9×10−9). It had been reported in numerous previous GWAS for cardiometabolic traits and colocalized with HMBS and VPS11 mRNA expression, where HMBS had an opposite direction of effect compared to the other traits.
title: Multi-trait GWAS of atherosclerosis detects novel pleiotropic loci

finding: The SNP rs163184 was associated with a lesser response to glycaemic outcomes in Chinese patients. A large pooled RCT analysis indicated that patients carrying this variant showed differences in HbA1c response, potentially identifying it as a biomarker for glycemic response specifically to exenatide.
title: Precision medicine in type 2 diabetes: A systematic review of treatment effect heterogeneity for GLP1-receptor agonists and SGLT2-inhibitors

finding: The SNP rs1351522 was noted as a significant locus associated with both AN and its overlap with BMI. This indicated its potential relevance in understanding the genetic factors contributing to these phenotypes.
title: An Evolutionary Perspective on the Genetics of Anorexia Nervosa

finding: The SNP rs34445652 was highlighted in the research as a significant overlapping locus between AN and BMI, suggesting its potential role in the shared genetic architecture of these conditions.
title: An Evolutionary Perspective on the Genetics of Anorexia Nervosa

finding: The variant in CPT1A (rs80356779) was associated with lower plasma levels of 55 proteins including significant reductions in the levels of stem cell factor (SCF) and follistatin (FS). This finding indicated a pleiotropic effect of the CPT1A variant on systemic inflammation and cardiovascular markers.
title: Genetic regulation of the plasma proteome and its link to cardiometabolic disease in Greenlandic Inuit

finding: The lead SNP rs75472842 was associated with the CPS1-ERBB4 locus, where an additional copy of the T allele decreased 60.92 μmol/L glycine in maternal plasma, indicating its role in glycine metabolism.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study in 34,394 Chinese women reveals the genetic architecture of plasma metabolites during pregnancy

finding: The intergenic SNP rs16919711 was linked to homocysteine levels, where it functioned as an eQTL for PANX1 and GPR83.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study in 34,394 Chinese women reveals the genetic architecture of plasma metabolites during pregnancy

finding: rs11227478 was associated with sarcosine levels at the SLC29A2-NPAS4 locus, indicating a genetic link affecting metabolism of this amino acid.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study in 34,394 Chinese women reveals the genetic architecture of plasma metabolites during pregnancy

finding: Identified within the FOLR1-FOLR2 locus, rs35954619 was shown to decrease 5-methyltetrahydrofolate levels significantly, further supporting its impact on folate metabolism.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study in 34,394 Chinese women reveals the genetic architecture of plasma metabolites during pregnancy

finding: The PDE3B locus's known association with 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 confirmed the genetic influence on vitamin D levels.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study in 34,394 Chinese women reveals the genetic architecture of plasma metabolites during pregnancy

finding: At the DHCR7 locus, this known association showed a correlation with 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 levels, reinforcing the genetic basis for vitamin D metabolism.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study in 34,394 Chinese women reveals the genetic architecture of plasma metabolites during pregnancy

finding: The FDX1 locus was associated with 11-Deoxycortisol (11DOC) levels, confirming its role in steroid metabolism.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study in 34,394 Chinese women reveals the genetic architecture of plasma metabolites during pregnancy

finding: The APOA5 locus reinforced its association with lipid metabolism and trace elements.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study in 34,394 Chinese women reveals the genetic architecture of plasma metabolites during pregnancy

finding: The SNP rs55673936, located within the intronic region of the GALNT18 gene, replicated in two fully independent populations for the phenotype Hospitalized/Not_Hospitalized. This association is noteworthy as it aligns with previous findings linking GALNT18 to responses in COVID-19 treatments and suggests modulation of the IL-6 pathway.
title: Novel COVID-19 phenotype definitions reveal phenotypically distinct patterns of genetic association and protective effects

finding: The SNP rs12420134 mapped to the gene SOX6, which is crucial in central nervous system development, was significantly associated with hyper-arousal in individuals with PTSD. This suggests that genetic variations in SOX6 may influence PTSD symptomatology.
title: Mapping the epigenomic landscape of post-traumatic stress disorder in human cortical neurons

finding: The SNP rs1800497 located in the TAQI DRD2 gene was implicated in PTSD through previous studies. It has been associated with various psychiatric disorders, indicating it may play a role in the neural mechanisms underlying PTSD.
title: Mapping the epigenomic landscape of post-traumatic stress disorder in human cortical neurons

finding: The rs35705950 SNP within the MUC5B locus was associated with an increased risk of idiopathic fibrosing alveolitis with an odds ratio (OR) of 2.83 (p=4.12 x 10^-191). This finding reinforced previous studies linking this SNP to pulmonary conditions.
title: A Phenome-Wide Association Study of genes associated with COVID-19 severity reveals shared genetics with complex diseases in the Million Veteran Program

finding: rs5744249 was identified as a cis-eQTL for IL18 with notable discordance, as it showed opposing associations with mRNA and protein levels.
title: Mapping pQTLs of circulating inflammatory proteins identifies drivers of immune-related disease risk and novel therapeutic targets

finding: The SNP rs3750920 was associated with a polymorphism in the TOLLIP gene. In a post-hoc exploratory analysis of patients from the PANTHER study, it was proposed that individuals with this polymorphism may benefit from N-acetylcysteine (NAC) treatment for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). This finding suggested that NAC could decrease TLR-4 oxidant dependent signaling in these patients, providing a link between the SNP and potential therapeutic stratification in IPF.
title: A validated hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) signature across tissue compartments predicts clinical outcome in human lung fibrosis

finding: The rs11024102 variant was reported to be uniquely associated with PACG within East Asian populations, indicating the importance of ancestry-specific genetic variants in glaucoma susceptibility.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel ancestry-specific primary open-angle glaucoma loci and shared biology with vascular mechanisms and cell proliferation

finding: The rs2276035 variant was previously associated with both POAG and PACG, underpinning its relevance as a shared genetic risk factor.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel ancestry-specific primary open-angle glaucoma loci and shared biology with vascular mechanisms and cell proliferation

finding: The analysis revealed that rs499684 was significantly associated with prostate and testis expressed protein 4 (PATE4) which is involved in male fertility, particularly related to copulatory plug formation in mouse models.
title: Similar and different: systematic investigation of proteogenomic variation between sexes and its relevance for human diseases

finding: In African-American subjects, the G allele of rs702966 was significantly associated with mortality in COVID-19 patients, indicating a critical role for this SNP in vulnerable populations.
title: Interferon pathway lupus risk alleles modulate risk of death from acute COVID-19

finding: The TT genotype of rs4963128 was associated with protection from COVID-19 mortality among African American patients, suggesting a complex role of this SNP given its links to type I IFN levels.
title: Interferon pathway lupus risk alleles modulate risk of death from acute COVID-19

finding: Associated with multiple RBC traits, including lower hemoglobin count, the rs34598529 variant was identified at the HBB locus and replicated in independent datasets.
title: Whole genome sequencing association analysis of quantitative red blood cell phenotypes: the NHLBI TOPMed program

finding: The rs11549407 variant at the HBB locus was associated with multiple red blood cell traits, including reduced hemoglobin levels, and was confirmed as a significant finding in various analyses.
title: Whole genome sequencing association analysis of quantitative red blood cell phenotypes: the NHLBI TOPMed program

finding: Associated with various red blood cell parameters, rs33944208 was validated in studies identifying its effects on RBC metrics.
title: Whole genome sequencing association analysis of quantitative red blood cell phenotypes: the NHLBI TOPMed program

finding: Notable for its association with traits related to RBCs, the rs33915217 variant was confirmed to influence MCV and MCH characteristics.
title: Whole genome sequencing association analysis of quantitative red blood cell phenotypes: the NHLBI TOPMed program

finding: The SNP rs6598045, located in the IFITM3 gene, was associated with an increased risk of COVID-19 mortality in individuals carrying the G allele, particularly among those infected with the SARS-CoV-2 delta variant. This finding related to the host genetic factors influencing the severity of COVID-19 outcomes.
title: Integration of human organoids single-cell transcriptomic profiles and human genetics repurposes critical cell type-specific drug targets for severe COVID-19

finding: The SNP rs35705950, located in the MUC5B gene, was identified as having protective effects against COVID-19 hospitalization. This finding was significant as it highlighted the role of genetic factors in determining the risk of hospitalization due to COVID-19, although it did not confer protection against severe disease or mortality.
title: Cohort Profile of the Chilean COVID-19 Biorepository: a Multicentric initiative for multi-omics research on COVID-19 and LONG-COVID in a Latin American population

finding: The SNP rs10830963 was associated at genome-wide significance with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), showing a strong odds ratio (OR) of 1.41. This SNP is also known to associate with fasting glycaemic traits and is likewise implicated in type 2 diabetes (T2D), where its allelic effect was smaller (OR=1.09), indicating that GDM may reflect a more pronounced effect on glucose regulation during pregnancy.
title: Trans-ancestry genome-wide association study of gestational diabetes mellitus highlights genetic links with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP was identified as a cis-associated factor for B3GAT1, with genetically decreased levels correlating to increased prostate cancer risk, supported by a strong LD relationship with rs878987.
title: Efficient candidate drug target discovery through proteogenomics in a Scottish cohort

finding: This SNP was reported as a lead variant in prostate cancer GWAS, showing a significant association with prostate cancer and a strong LD with rs78760579.
title: Efficient candidate drug target discovery through proteogenomics in a Scottish cohort

finding: The SNP was associated with AAMDC and intrinsic epigenetic age acceleration related to DNA methylation, also lacking evidence for reverse causality.
title: Efficient candidate drug target discovery through proteogenomics in a Scottish cohort

finding: This SNP was part of the novel shared SNPs and contributed to defining the genetic landscape connecting obesity with MS.
title: Investigating shared genetic architecture between obesity and multiple sclerosis

finding: The variant rs3135506, representing a p.S19W change in APOA5, was significantly associated with elevated median TG levels in the AA population, corroborating previous associations noted in European and Hispanic populations. Carriers of this variant were notably overrepresented in the severe hypertriglyceridemia category, affirming its impact on TG metabolism, although the overall effect size was moderate.
title: Characterizing genetic profiles for high triglyceride levels in U.S. patients of African ancestry

finding: The rs11032789 SNP, associated with apoprotein A (apoA), was reported with a significance of 6.40E-10. This association was identified for the first time in the current study.
title: A Chinese host genetic study discovered type I interferons and causality of cholesterol levels and WBC counts on COVID-19 severity

finding: This SNP was found to be associated with the missingness of dopamine 4-sulphate, wherein its link to the TH gene pointed out a possible genetic influence on neurotransmitter metabolism affecting measurement reliability.
title: Genome-wide Association Studies of Missing Metabolite Measures: Results From Two Population-based Studies

finding: The rs11039202 variant in SPI1 indicated a P-value of 2.88×10^-9 in stage 3, reaffirming its contribution to genetic susceptibility to LOAD.
The SNP rs3781831, located near SORL1, reached a P-value of 2.85×10^-10 in stage 3, marking it as a critical susceptibility factor for Alzheimer's disease.

The study identified that the MUC5B promoter variant rs35705950 was significantly associated with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). Being heterozygous (GT) had an adjusted odds ratio (OR) of 4.8 (95% CI 3.5-6.8; p<0.01) for disease, while being homozygous (TT) showed an adjusted OR of 12.0 (95% CI 4.5-32.5; p<0.001). This variant was noted to increase airway expression of MUC5B, which is a key component in the pathogenesis of both IPF and asbestosis.
title: What role for asbestos in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis? Findings from the IPF job exposures study

finding: The study identified a locus with an African-enriched missense variant (rs75976740) in SLC22A11 that was linked to M2 Macrophages, demonstrating significance at p = 4.55e-8 and a beta of -0.48, highlighting its role in the immune system.
title: A Southern African Map of Blood Regulatory Variation Enables GWAS Interpretation

finding: The SNP rs73013527, related to the ETS1 gene, was associated with increased protection against rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with its minor allele, indicating a genetic aspect that could help outrun the disease.
title: Location of joint involvement differentiates Rheumatoid arthritis into different clinical subsets

finding: The variant rs601314 in the EFEMP2 gene showed a significant association with FSGS in the European-American cohort, with a p-value of 8.1×10^-9 and an odds ratio indicating a strong effect of the minor allele. However, it failed to replicate significance in both the African-American and Latin-American cohorts.
title: CR1 variants contribute to FSGS susceptibility across multiple populations

finding: The variant rs117071588 in the CCDC82 gene was significantly associated with FSGS in the European-American cohort, with a p-value of 4.0×10^-6. He was absent in the African-American cohort, indicating a lack of broader relevance in FSGS cases.
title: CR1 variants contribute to FSGS susceptibility across multiple populations

finding: At locus 11q22.3 associated with ATM, the variant rs11212666 was identified as a new significant association with overall CH susceptibility, supporting the understanding of genetic predispositions to this blood condition.
title: Genome-wide analyses of 200,453 individuals yields new insights into the causes and consequences of clonal hematopoiesis

finding: The SNP rs10501696 was identified in the study as one of the 11 loci that passed genome level significance (P < 5 x 10^-8) specifically in females. This SNP mapped to the GRM5 gene, which encodes the mGluR5 metabotropic glutamate receptor. The association was notable as the GRM5 gene was also involved in sex-specific biological processes, particularly in the context of depression, and contributed to the 'Regulation of Gene Expression Pathway.' Previous research indicated that the expression levels of glutamate receptor genes differed significantly between male and female patients with major depressive disorder, suggesting that the genetic mechanisms underlying depression may be sex-dependent.
title: A Sex-Specific Genome-Wide Association Study of Depression Phenotypes in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs76377757 was reported as an intergenic variant and reached genome-wide significance with a p-value of 4.3e-08 for its association with RPD, contributing novel insight into the genetic landscape of reticular pseudodrusen.
title: Genetic Distinctions Between Reticular Pseudodrusen and Drusen: Insights from a Genome-Wide Association Study

finding: The intronic variant rs542673349 of NECTIN1 reported associations with diverse cancers including lung cancer among various ethnic populations.
title: Trans-ethnic genome-wide meta-analysis of 35,732 cases and 34,424 controls identifies novel genomic cross-ancestry loci contributing to lung cancer susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs1940105 near LINC01395-TMEM45B was identified with strong associations for adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma, particularly in Asian populations.
title: Trans-ethnic genome-wide meta-analysis of 35,732 cases and 34,424 controls identifies novel genomic cross-ancestry loci contributing to lung cancer susceptibility

finding: This intronic variant in JAML on 11q23.3 emerged as associated with lung cancer risk, contributing to genetic insights.
title: Trans-ethnic genome-wide meta-analysis of 35,732 cases and 34,424 controls identifies novel genomic cross-ancestry loci contributing to lung cancer susceptibility

finding: This exonic variant of ATM was shown to be associated with adenocarcinoma risk, contributing new evidence in genetic evaluations.
title: Trans-ethnic genome-wide meta-analysis of 35,732 cases and 34,424 controls identifies novel genomic cross-ancestry loci contributing to lung cancer susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs34632468 was linked to the DRD2 gene, with a significant p-value of 1.04E-11, emphasizing its relevance in dopaminergic transmission and its established connection with nicotine dependence.
title: Multi-ancestry meta-analysis of tobacco use disorder prioritizes novel candidate risk genes and reveals associations with numerous health outcomes

finding: The SNP rs9919558 located in NCAM1 was significantly associated with TUD, achieving a p-value of 4.44E-12, which linked it to dopamine signaling and various smoking-related traits.
title: Multi-ancestry meta-analysis of tobacco use disorder prioritizes novel candidate risk genes and reveals associations with numerous health outcomes

finding: The rs61882275 variant was noted for its association with ELF5 and catalase (CAT) in relation to critical COVID-19, indicating its role in lung function.
title: Whole genome sequencing identifies multiple loci for critical illness caused by COVID-19

finding: SNP rs1847134 was only associated with 'Other non-epithelial cancer of skin' in the PheWAS analysis. This finding was captured consistently across the bias-corrected and robust Poisson models along with the Gold-standard logistic regression model.
title: Overcome the Limitation of Phenome-Wide Association Studies (PheWAS): Extension of PheWAS to Efficient and Robust Large-Scale ICD Codes Analysis

finding: The variant rs11229555-G in ZFP91-CNTF/GLYAT was also associated with a decreased risk of NMSC (OR 0.95, 95% CI 0.91, 0.99).
title: Inflammatory Bowel Disease Risk Variants Are Associated with an Increased Risk of Skin Cancer

finding: The lead SNP rs28624253 was located upstream of the MUC5AC gene, which encodes a mucin protein. This SNP was associated with pneumonia susceptibility and supported by a credible set proximal to the gene, implicating mucin proteins in the pathophysiology of pneumonia.
title: Genome-wide meta-analysis of pneumonia suggests a role for mucin biology and provides novel drug repurposing opportunities

finding: This intergenic variant was noted among genetic loci for fatty acid traits but did not have an associated gene.
title: Genome-wide association studies and multi-omics integrative analysis reveal novel loci and their molecular mechanisms for circulating polyunsaturated, monounsaturated, and saturated fatty acids

finding: The SNV rs7108992 was associated with an FVC-related structural variant deletion (Sniffles2.DEL.5C9EMA) that exclusively mapped to FLI1. This variant was characterized by a p-value of 2.0×10^-30 and a MAF of 0.322. The analyses indicated strong evidence connecting FLI1 expression in lung and smooth muscle-containing tissues to lung function measures, as well as correlations with pulmonary heart disease risk and protein levels of other known respiratory disease factors.
title: Imputation of structural variants using a multi-ancestry long-read sequencing panel enables identification of disease associations

finding: The study referenced the association of the APOC3 rs5128 polymorphism with plasma APOC3 and lipid levels. This association highlighted the role of the APOC3 gene in lipid metabolism, which was crucial for understanding metabolic diseases linked to aging. The identification of this SNP allowed for insights into how genetic factors, such as lipid levels influenced by APOC3, could contribute to age-related metabolic syndromes and conditions like type 2 diabetes.
title: Menopause Hormone Replacement Therapy and Lifestyle Factors affect Metabolism and Immune System in the Serum Proteome of Aging Individuals

finding: SORL1:rs11218343-C was classified as a protective allele, aiding in decreasing the risk for AD across analyzed ancestries.
title: Biobank-scale characterization of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias identifies potential disease-causing variants, risk factors, and genetic modifiers across diverse ancestries

finding: At locus 36 (signal 44), rs2120430 was identified as an eQTL for the gene CBL with strong association in melanocytes (P=0.007). It was linked to melanoma risk, further establishing its significance in gene regulation.
title: Mapping chromatin interactions at melanoma susceptibility loci and cell-type specific dataset integration uncovers distant gene targets of cis-regulation

finding: Similar to rs2120430, rs11217853 was implicated as a potential eQTL for CBL in consistent findings from the study (P=0.02), tying it to risk-associated variant regulation.
title: Mapping chromatin interactions at melanoma susceptibility loci and cell-type specific dataset integration uncovers distant gene targets of cis-regulation

finding: At locus 36 (signal 44), rs61900794 was found to influence CBL expression indirectly, showing regulatory interactions through CRISPRi experiments, although it lacked direct evidence of eQTL status.
title: Mapping chromatin interactions at melanoma susceptibility loci and cell-type specific dataset integration uncovers distant gene targets of cis-regulation

finding: This variant, associated with ROBO3, had a p-value of 6.12×10−17, implicating it in neural development and possibly visual pathways.
title: Genomewide association study of epiretinal membrane: discovery of significant risk loci in each of three American populations

finding: For SNP rs11030321, research suggested its involvement in the pro-angiogenic microenvironment specifically relevant to hematological malignancies. Increased levels of fractalkine influenced by this SNP contributed to systemic immune modulation and enhanced tumor infiltration by effector immune cells, thus improving therapeutic strategies in cancer treatment.
title: Potent clinical prognostic and systemic adjuvant therapeutic value of plasma fractalkine in PD-L1/PD-1 blockade immunotherapy for lung cancer

finding: This SNP at the 11p15.4 locus had a replication p-value of 1.87×10−6 and was located within an intron of TRIM22, marking it as a positive finding.
title: Genome-wide association studies of Down syndrome associated congenital heart defects

finding: The lead SNP rs950802 at the MS4A7 locus exhibited a strong association with increased spleen iron (beta=0.086, p=7.7e-26). This finding also coincided with a synonymous mutation affecting splicing in MS4A7, indicating a novel mechanism linking this SNP to spleen iron levels.
title: Analysis of MRI-derived spleen iron in the UK Biobank identifies genetic variation linked to iron homeostasis and erythrocyte morphology

finding: This SNP was linked to ascending aorta maximum area (AAo max area) and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) volume, indicating its role in both cardiac and central nervous system traits.
title: Heart-brain connections: phenotypic and genetic insights from 40,000 cardiac and brain magnetic resonance images

finding: This SNP was connected to neuroticism, depressive symptoms, and cognitive functions, indicating intricate interactions between mental health and cardiac health.
title: Heart-brain connections: phenotypic and genetic insights from 40,000 cardiac and brain magnetic resonance images

finding: This SNP had connections to DTI parameters and brain volumes, indicating its role in both neurological and cardiovascular traits.
title: Heart-brain connections: phenotypic and genetic insights from 40,000 cardiac and brain magnetic resonance images

finding: This SNP was found in association with multiple genes influencing both cardiovascular and neuropsychiatric traits.
title: Heart-brain connections: phenotypic and genetic insights from 40,000 cardiac and brain magnetic resonance images

finding: The SNP rs7106434 exhibited close relationships with PTSD-associated cardiovascular traits, showing its relevance in shared genetic pathways.
title: Genetics of posttraumatic stress disorder and cardiovascular conditions using Life’s Essential 8, Electronic Health Records, and Heart Imaging

finding: The SNP rs4275621 was reported in the analysis as having significant associations with both PTSD and cardiovascular disease traits.
title: Genetics of posttraumatic stress disorder and cardiovascular conditions using Life’s Essential 8, Electronic Health Records, and Heart Imaging

finding: The SNP rs117937125 at the 11q23.3 locus was identified as a novel risk locus for both major depressive disorder (MDD) and myocardial infarction (MI). It was colocalized with traits of blood lipids, with the mapped gene ZNF259 associated with dyslipidemia, suggesting an important role of lipids in the comorbidity between MDD and MI.
title: Role of Blood Lipids in the Shared Genetic Etiology Between Major Depressive Disorder and Myocardial Infarction: A Large-scale Multi-trait Association Analysis

finding: The SNP rs964184 was associated with dyslipidemia and coronary artery disease. This finding emphasizes its role in the genetic landscape that connects lipid traits with MI.
title: Role of Blood Lipids in the Shared Genetic Etiology Between Major Depressive Disorder and Myocardial Infarction: A Large-scale Multi-trait Association Analysis

finding: The SNP rs35705950 was estimated as causal and colocalized only in the lung tissue for individuals with severe COVID-19. The study did not find any eQTLs for this SNP in whole blood, emphasizing the tissue-specific expression effects related to COVID-19 outcomes.
title: Colocalization of expression transcripts with COVID-19 outcomes is rare across cell states, cell types and organs

finding: The SNP rs79878474 was identified in the genomic region chr11p15, specifically linked to the USH1C gene, which is highly expressed in the brain, particularly in the spinal cord. It was found to have the strongest association with anxiety and depression, evidenced by a p-value of 4.03e-07 from mega-analysis. This gene's disruption was connected to Usher syndrome type 1C and sensorineural deafness, highlighting its relevance in mental health.
title: Cross-continental environmental and genome-wide association study on children and adolescent anxiety and depression

finding: The SNP rs537626, located in the LINC01488 gene at 11q13.3, exhibited the strongest negative association with ROR-P. It was originally discovered in a GWAS related to early onset breast cancer and was also linked to increased risk of ER-positive cancer in studies involving African-American women. This indicates its potential impact on breast cancer aggressiveness and subtype susceptibility.
title: Development and testing of a polygenic risk score for breast cancer aggressiveness

finding: The SNP rs117912622 was found to be a novel locus related to CBC setpoints. This reinforced its role in understanding patient-specific hematological characteristics.
title: Hematologic setpoints are a stable and patient-specific deep phenotype

finding: The rs1286162 SNP, located outside the 19q13.32 region, was noted for its substantial relevance in contributing to the shared genetic risks for Alzheimer's disease and late-onset epilepsy, illustrating the extensive genetic complexity of these diseases.
title: Multi-class Modeling Identifies Shared Genetic Risk for Late-onset Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The rs3740688 SNP was a missense variant in the SPI1 gene, associated with increased expression of SPI1 and greater risk of prostate cancer, as well as reduced incidence of Hashimoto's thyroiditis, thereby illustrating its bidirectional impact on health outcomes.
title: Mapping inherited genetic variation with opposite effects on autoimmune disease and cancer identifies candidate drug targets associated with the anti-tumor immune response

finding: Fine-mapped for height in FinnGen and UKBB.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: SNP rs2581927 demonstrated a significant association with maternal gestational age (beta -2.03, p = 4.85x10^-6), indicating its relevance in pregnancy outcomes and potential connection to preeclampsia.
title: Clotting factor genes are associated with preeclampsia in high altitude pregnant women in the Peruvian Andes

finding: SNP rs12276362 was associated with proteinuria in the maternal genome as well (OR 0.41, p = 1.19E-05), underscoring its role in the clinical features of preeclampsia.
title: Clotting factor genes are associated with preeclampsia in high altitude pregnant women in the Peruvian Andes

finding: This SNP was associated with the severity of diagnosis in mothers (OR 2.4, p = 1.30E-05), suggesting its impact on the clinical outcomes of preeclampsia.
title: Clotting factor genes are associated with preeclampsia in high altitude pregnant women in the Peruvian Andes

finding: The rs35705950 variant at the MUC5B gene locus showed a protective effect against COVID-19 hospitalization in individuals over 60 years old (OR 0.86, P = 2.99x10^-2). This variant was associated with a five-fold increase in IPF risk and overexpression of mucin 5B but conferred protection against COVID-19 severity, suggesting a complex relationship between this SNP and both diseases.
title: Shared genetic etiology between idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and COVID-19 severity

finding: The SNP rs78587207 was identified in a GWAS meta-analysis involving 53,660 OCD cases and 2,044,417 controls, marking it as significant with a p-value of 5.28x10^-12. It was notably associated with various neuropsychiatric phenotypes, particularly schizophrenia (p=1.26x10^-8), depressive symptoms (p=2.74x10^-11), and neuroticism (p=2.96x10^-11) in prior studies. Gene-based analyses linked the allele to four putative causal genes, with catenin delta 1 (CTNND1) being the closest gene, which is implicated in OCD through colocalization with TWAS signals in dlPFC. The findings positioned CTNND1's role in cell adhesion and associated neural circuitry relevant to compulsivity in OCD, emphasizing its relevance in OCD's genetic landscape.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies 30 obsessive-compulsive disorder associated loci

finding: The intergenic variant rs146257041 was associated with reduced 28-day survival. This variant was linked to SLC5A12 and FIBIN genes, highlighting its potential role in sepsis outcomes.
title: A Genome-Wide Association Study of Survival in Patients with Sepsis

finding: This AD GWAS SNP overlapped a microglia specific enhancer connected to the PICALM gene. PICALM is involved in synaptic function and endocytosis, linking the SNP with Alzheimer's disease risk.
title: Cell-type specific cis-eQTLs in eight brain cell-types identifies novel risk genes for human brain disorders

finding: This AD GWAS SNP also overlapped a microglia specific enhancer connected to PICALM, reinforcing the association of this SNP with Alzheimer's disease through the same gene as rs10792832.
title: Cell-type specific cis-eQTLs in eight brain cell-types identifies novel risk genes for human brain disorders

finding: The ACTN3 R577X polymorphism was found to be associated with smaller masseter muscle volume (MMV) in men. This relationship highlighted the potential role of this genetic variant in influencing muscle mass and strength, especially in the context of sarcopenia among older adults.
title: Masseter Muscle Volume and Its Association with Sarcopenia and Muscle Determinants with Insights from ACTN3 Polymorphism in Older Japanese Adults: the Bunkyo Health Study

finding: The SNP rs7232 had a PP of 0.54 in the context of AD risk, associated with the MS4A gene cluster.
title: Multi-ancestry meta-analysis and fine-mapping in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs1582763 showed significance related to the MS4A gene region in the context of Alzheimer's disease research.
title: Multi-ancestry meta-analysis and fine-mapping in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs6591561 was discussed in relation to the relationship with the disease mechanism, indicating its potential impact in Alzheimer's pathways.
title: Multi-ancestry meta-analysis and fine-mapping in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs2049046 was associated with job burnout as observed in a study by He et al., 2020, which demonstrated that this polymorphism interacted with job stress and serum BDNF levels, both of which were negatively correlated with the incidence of burnout. The significant finding indicated that individuals carrying certain variations in this SNP may exhibit lower serum BDNF levels, which contributes to a higher risk of burnout, particularly in high-stress occupations.
title: Method of combining multiple researches to determine non-infectious disease causes. Analysis of Depression and Celiac disease causes

finding: was involved in signaling for tumorigenesis through inflammatory stimuli and was in high LD with a hair colour SNP.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: was an intronic variant in SOX6, linked to apoptosis in various cancers, yet its direct role in keratinocyte cancer is unclear. It was in LD with rs2953060 for sunburns.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: was recognized as an eQTL for SESN3, indicating a role in immune response regulation.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: was associated with lipid metabolism, influencing BCC risk, and was connected to cholesterol levels.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: was implicated in pigmentation traits and noted for its role in hair colour variability.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: was indicated near ATM, involved in DNA damage response efficacy.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: was associated with melanoma, highlighting its relevance to cutaneous cancer susceptibility.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: The study detected the c.33C>A mutation associated with beta thalassemia as a positive finding in the context of identifying mutations related to the phenotype.
title: The spectrum of rare and novel indel mutations responsible for β Thalassemia in eastern India

finding: The c.47G>A mutation was observed as a variant linked to beta thalassemia, indicating its relevance in the mutation spectrum affecting the disease phenotype.
title: The spectrum of rare and novel indel mutations responsible for β Thalassemia in eastern India

finding: The IVS 1-5 mutation (NM_000518.4:c.92+5G>C) was highlighted in the study as one of the most common mutations contributing to beta thalassemia in the studied population.
title: The spectrum of rare and novel indel mutations responsible for β Thalassemia in eastern India

finding: The presence of IVS 1-1 mutation (NM_000518.4:c.92+1 G>A) was confirmed in the study, showing its significance in the beta thalassemia mutation landscape.
title: The spectrum of rare and novel indel mutations responsible for β Thalassemia in eastern India

finding: The study found a significant association between rs7123010, a top SNP from a GWAS of Tourette syndrome (TS), and higher tic severity. This association remained significant after correcting for multiple testing, with an F value of 7.99 and a P value of 0.0004. The AA genotype of this SNP was positively associated with tic severity.
title: Investigation of gene-environment interactions in relation to tic severity

finding: This SNP was validated in relation to IgAN risk and was associated with decreased galactosylation and subsequent lower sialylation at O-glycans.
title: The genetics and epidemiology of N- and O- IgA glycomics

finding: The SNP rs45472704 was positively associated with an IBS clinical diagnosis, showing an adjusted odds ratio (aOR) of 2.41 (95% confidence interval [CI] = 1.26-4.60).
title: Genetic Variants in Carbohydrate Digestive Enzyme and Transport Genes Associated with Risk of Irritable Bowel Syndrome

finding: The SNP rs45529131 was positively associated with the IBS clinical phenotype, with an adjusted odds ratio (aOR) of 2.36 (95% CI = 1.23-4.52).
title: Genetic Variants in Carbohydrate Digestive Enzyme and Transport Genes Associated with Risk of Irritable Bowel Syndrome

finding: The SNP rs2277296 was negatively associated with the IBS phenotype, showing an aOR of 0.76 (95% CI = 0.62-0.93). It also impacted TREH expression levels in gastrointestinal tissues as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) associated with lower expression levels.
title: Genetic Variants in Carbohydrate Digestive Enzyme and Transport Genes Associated with Risk of Irritable Bowel Syndrome

finding: The SNP rs2277297 was also negatively associated with the IBS phenotype (aOR = 0.76, 95% CI = 0.62-0.93) and it showed similar eQTL effects as rs2277296, suggesting a regulatory role in TREH expression.
title: Genetic Variants in Carbohydrate Digestive Enzyme and Transport Genes Associated with Risk of Irritable Bowel Syndrome

finding: SNP rs10892251 was significantly associated with decreased sugar consumption behavior and also showed low risk for IBS-C phenotype, contributing to an overall observation of dietary selection pressures.
title: Genetic Variants in Carbohydrate Digestive Enzyme and Transport Genes Associated with Risk of Irritable Bowel Syndrome

finding: This SNP related to SORL1 was noted for enriching in centenarians, linked to amyloid precursor protein trafficking and associated with lower AD risk.
title: Cognitively Healthy Centenarians are genetically protected against Alzheimer’s disease specifically in immune and endo-lysosomal systems

finding: The synonymous SNV on MS4A6A (rs12453) was suggestive in logistic regression and AD-age score, while being just below significance in the Cox regression, indicating its relevance in AD risk.
title: A novel age-informed approach for genetic association analysis in Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs7482144 was associated with increased fetal hemoglobin production when co-occurring with the sickle-cell allele (HbS), contributing 7% to the variation in HbF levels, specifically in individuals with HbSS and HbAS genotypes. It was shown to be protective against malaria while being linked to increased gametocyte production.
title: Fetal hemoglobin enables malaria parasite growth in sickle cells but augments production of transmission stage parasites

finding: This SNP was located downstream of the gene METTL15 on chromosome 11 and was identified as the locus most strongly associated with ADHD-CUD. It had an odds ratio (OR) of 1.06 and a very significant p-value of 1.45×10^-18, establishing a strong link to both ADHD and CUD.
title: Disentangling the shared genetics of ADHD, cannabis use disorder and cannabis use and prediction of cannabis use disorder in ADHD

finding: This SNP, located near DRD2, was identified as an independent genome-wide significant variant associated with ADHD-CUD. It is a significant eQTL for DRD2 in the cerebellar hemisphere and is crucial for understanding the genetic contribution to ADHD-CUD.
title: Disentangling the shared genetics of ADHD, cannabis use disorder and cannabis use and prediction of cannabis use disorder in ADHD

finding: Located in a chromatin region interacting with DRD2, this SNP was also identified in ADHD-CUD. Its association underscores the relevance of DRD2 in ADHD pathology and offers insights into the genetic overlap between ADHD and CUD.
title: Disentangling the shared genetics of ADHD, cannabis use disorder and cannabis use and prediction of cannabis use disorder in ADHD

finding: The SNP rs2455569 served as the lead eQTL for ARHGAP42, demonstrating significant associations with blood pressure and CAD traits. It was linked to decreased expression in aorta tissues, providing insights into vascular regulation and disease relevance.
title: Integrative multi-ancestry genetic analysis of gene regulation in coronary arteries prioritizes disease risk loci

finding: The locus rs10737153 in MYEOV was noted for impacting PRC thickness and was additionally linked to breast cancer risk, suggesting cross-phenotype associations.
title: Sub-cellular level resolution of common genetic variation in the photoreceptor layer identifies continuum between rare disease and common variation
