finding: The SNP rs760568794, a missense variant (p.Gly77Asp), was associated with decreased triglycerides (TG) among South Asians, showing a significant association with a beta coefficient of -36.9% (P=2×10^-8). Although it was identified in both South Asian (Minor Allele Count=24) and Hispanic (Minor Allele Count=8) individuals, it did not show any association among Hispanics (P=0.86). This finding provided evidence supporting the variant's impact on TG levels specifically within the South Asian ancestry.
title: Rare coding variants in 35 genes associate with circulating lipid levels – a multi-ancestry analysis of 170,000 exomes

finding: The A allele of TPH1 (rs623580) was found to be a risk allele for creativity. Paternal indifference and neglect in early life negatively predicted creativity in youths who carried the A allele, specifically impacting fluency, flexibility, and originality. Additionally, male individuals carrying the A allele were associated with lower flexibility compared to TT homozygotes.
title: Paternal Indifference and neglect in early life and Creativity: Exploring the Moderating Role of TPH1 genotype and Offspring’s Gender

finding: The eQTL rs10791097 was observed to regulate the gene SNX19 across both fetal and adult cortical tissues, indicating its involvement in ASD-related gene expression.
title: Autism spectrum disorder: understanding the impact of SNPs on biological pathways in the fetal and adult cortex

finding: The eQTL rs174592 regulated FADS1, impacting gene expression relevant for ASD, as it was associated with both fetal and adult cortical tissues.
title: Autism spectrum disorder: understanding the impact of SNPs on biological pathways in the fetal and adult cortex

finding: The SNP rs11212527 was linked to climatic drivers influencing greening trends in the Alps, suggesting its association with vegetation responses to environmental changes. This SNP was relevant to the increase of dwarf shrubs over a 60-year period, demonstrating that fine-scale environmental factors, such as topography and micro-climate, significantly shaped plant distribution, despite unexpected influences from temperature increases and grazing declines.
title: Dwarf-shrubs dynamics in Mediterranean high mountain ecosystems

finding: The study demonstrated that the mutation R125M (rs1048220) markedly inhibited the cleavage of proBDNF to mBDNF. Mice expressing this mutation exhibited high levels of proBDNF and low levels of mBDNF, similar to the findings reported in autism spectrum disorder (ASD) patients, indicating a potential link between this SNP and autism-related behaviors.
title: Inhibiting proBDNF to mature BDNF conversion leads to autism-like phenotypes in vivo

finding: The mutation R127L (rs1048221) was found to significantly inhibit the cleavage of proBDNF to mBDNF in vitro. In the BDNF met/leu mouse model, this SNP led to an increase in the levels of proBDNF, which correlated with ASD-like phenotypes observed in the mice, further supporting a connection between this genetic variant and autism-spectrum behaviors.
title: Inhibiting proBDNF to mature BDNF conversion leads to autism-like phenotypes in vivo

finding: The SNP rs876659558 resulted in an E2039V mutation on the ATM gene, categorized as a highly conserved mutation associated with disease states.
title: Predicting functionally important breast cancer SNPs using pleiotropy, conservation, and protein structure

finding: The SNP rs864622251 resulted in an E2039K mutation on ATM, notable for being associated with various disease states due to its high conservation.
title: Predicting functionally important breast cancer SNPs using pleiotropy, conservation, and protein structure

finding: The SNP rs730881389 caused a mutation leading to L1283P on the ATM gene, associated with Ataxia-telangiectasia and breast cancer.
title: Predicting functionally important breast cancer SNPs using pleiotropy, conservation, and protein structure

finding: The SNP rs104894230 led to G12D mutation in HRAS, associated with numerous cancers and calculated to destabilize the protein.
title: Predicting functionally important breast cancer SNPs using pleiotropy, conservation, and protein structure

finding: Linked with primary biliary cirrhosis, SNP rs4938541 was present within B cell-specific chromatin suggesting its role in GC B cell maturation.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: Also associated with primary biliary cirrhosis, this SNP was noted for its impact within regulatory frameworks pertinent to B cell function.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: The rs74911261 variant, which caused a missense change from proline to leucine at position 144 of the Protein O-Xylosyltransferase (POGLUT3), was associated with lower protein levels in plasma as determined by cis pQTL analysis. It was predicted to destabilise the protein with a decrease in stability of more than 1.5 kcal/mol. This variant not only correlated with reduced protein levels but was also linked to an increased risk of breast, renal, and prostate cancer, indicating the significance of POGLUT3 protein stability as a risk factor for these cancers.
title: Predicted mechanistic impacts of human protein missense variants

finding: GSTP1 rs1695 was associated with altered GST activity, which reduces detoxification capacity, thus increasing efficacy of platinum compounds in colorectal cancer treatments.
title: Pharmacogenomics, biomarker network and allele frequencies in colorectal cancer

finding: CCND1 rs9344 was associated with outcomes in colon cancer patients treated with adjuvant 5-FU chemotherapy, showing its predictive value in treatment response.
title: Pharmacogenomics, biomarker network and allele frequencies in colorectal cancer

finding: The rs1800497 variant, associated with the DRD2/ANKK1 TaqIA A1 allele, exhibited a high frequency in Nahua and HUI populations (67% and 65%, respectively). This allele is linked to diminished DRD2 expression and susceptibility to alcohol dependence. However, in these Native Mexican groups, it was found not to correlate with excessive alcohol consumption or metabolic disturbances, contrasting with findings in admixed Mexican populations where the A1 allele was related to heavy alcohol drinking and increased risk of metabolic issues.
title: Dietary, Cultural and Pathogens-related Selective Pressures Shaped Differential Adaptive Evolution Among Native Mexican Populations

finding: The C allele of the DRD2 C957T SNP (rs6277) was found to be associated with increased sugar consumption and elevated serum triglycerides. This association adds to the evidence that genetic variants related to dopamine signaling pathways might influence dietary behaviors in these populations, although this specific SNP's impact on alcohol-related traits was not directly addressed in the context of Native Mexican groups.
title: Dietary, Cultural and Pathogens-related Selective Pressures Shaped Differential Adaptive Evolution Among Native Mexican Populations

finding: It was found that the Val66Met polymorphism (rs6265) in the BDNF gene was associated with long-term cancer-related cognitive impairment (CRCI) in breast cancer survivors. This association linked the genetic variation to reduced BDNF levels, which is crucial for neurogenesis and cognitive functioning, supporting the role of BDNF in the cognitive impairments observed after cancer treatments.
title: Cisplatin Induces BDNF Downregulation in Middle-Aged Female Rat Model while BDNF Enhancement Attenuates Cisplatin Neurotoxicity

finding: The intronic variant rs650585 in the RNF214 gene was associated with lower plasma Aβ1-40 levels (effect size = -0.073 SD, 95% CI = [-0.099; -0.047]; p-value = 2.56×10^-8). This variant was in linkage disequilibrium (R^2 = 0.75) with the synonymous BACE1 variant rs638405, which was also associated with lower Aβ1-40 levels (effect size = -0.071 SD, p-value = 1.21×10^-7). Furthermore, rs650585 showed an association with increased Aβ deposition in individuals positive for APOE ε4 within the FHS-Gen3 population (p = 0.02).
title: Plasma amyloid β levels are driven by genetic variants near APOE, BACE1, APP, PSEN2: A genome-wide association study in over 12,000 non-demented participants

finding: The synonymous variant rs638405, associated with the BACE1 gene, was linked to lower plasma Aβ1-40 levels (effect size = -0.071 SD; p-value = 1.21×10^-7). This variant was in linkage disequilibrium (R^2 = 0.75) with the intronic RNF214 variant rs650585, also associated with lower Aβ1-40 levels.
title: Plasma amyloid β levels are driven by genetic variants near APOE, BACE1, APP, PSEN2: A genome-wide association study in over 12,000 non-demented participants

finding: This intronic SNP in the LRRC4C gene indicated potential new insights into obesity and insulin resistance. Its association with Netrin G1, which promotes adipose tissue inflammation, suggested novel regulatory pathways important in metabolic conditions.
title: A large-scale multivariate pQTL study sheds light on the genetic architecture of obesity

finding: APOC3 rs4520 C/C homozygotes had lesser decreases in triglyceride levels after olanzapine treatment compared to T allele carriers. This SNP was linked to variations in triglyceride metabolism during antipsychotic therapy.
title: Metabolic effects of aripiprazole and olanzapine multiple-dose treatment in healthy volunteers. Association with pharmacogenetics

finding: BDNF rs6265 C/C subjects showed greater increases in insulin levels during aripiprazole treatment compared to other genotypes. This finding highlighted the role of BDNF genetic variant in metabolic responses to antipsychotic therapy.
title: Metabolic effects of aripiprazole and olanzapine multiple-dose treatment in healthy volunteers. Association with pharmacogenetics

finding: rs10891491 was related to gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) and located near the DRD2 gene. This gene is linked to psychiatric disorders and its blocking could help relieve nausea, highlighting its relevance to gastrointestinal motility.
title: Genome-wide association study of gastrointestinal disorders reinforces the link between the digestive tract and the nervous system

finding: rs10500661 was linked to PUD and situated upstream of CCKBR, which encodes a receptor involved in regulating gastrin and CCK, indicating its role in gastrointestinal functions and potential therapeutic implications.
title: Genome-wide association study of gastrointestinal disorders reinforces the link between the digestive tract and the nervous system

finding: The SNP rs2019090 was specifically identified as a functional variant associated with coronary artery disease (CAD) at the locus 11q22.3, and it appeared to promote the expression of the gene PDGFD through binding of transcription factors FOXC1 and FOXC2 to the A allele. In various experimental models, it was shown that the A allele correlated with enhanced PDGFD expression, leading to vascular smooth muscle cell (SMC) expansion and migration, which are recognized contributors to atherosclerosis. This allele also resulted in an inflammatory response that was linked to increased macrophage recruitment to arterial plaques. Additional analyses demonstrated that FOXC1 mutations had implications for PDGF signaling, reinforcing the significance of rs2019090 as a key genetic factor influencing CAD risk.
title: Molecular mechanisms of coronary artery disease risk at the PDGFD locus

finding: The ACTN3 gene polymorphism rs1815739 was associated with good performance in power activities, specifically in artistic gymnastics. The study reported a predominance of the RX genotype among both gymnasts and swimmers, indicating its potential advantage in strength-related sports due to the association of the R allele with protein production and enhanced athletic performance.
title: Genotypic and allelic distribution of the ACE, ACTN3, and IL6 genes in athletes of Artistic Gymnastics and Swimming in the department of Norte de Santander, Colombia

finding: The SNP rs11040513 was linked with divergent dynamics and functions of ERK MAP kinase signaling as outlined by Muta et al. in 2019. This finding underscored its importance in development, homeostasis, and cancer, indicating it played a role in the understanding of ERK signaling pathways.
title: Reusability and composability in process description maps: RAS-RAF-MEK-ERK signalling

finding: This SNP was associated with the ratio involving FADD and NFATC1, contributing to the understanding of the genetic architecture of immune response pathways and their implications in therapeutic strategies.
title: Genetic associations with ratios between protein levels detect new pQTLs and reveal protein-protein interactions

finding: The SNP rs33918474 corresponded to the variant p.Val20Glu in human beta-haemoglobin, which was associated with erythrocytosis. This finding highlighted how this missense variant caused a disease phenotype in humans while the wild type variant p.Glu20 was observed in horses. The study noted that a second difference at residue 69 likely compensated for the changes, illustrating coevolutionary dynamics within these proteins.
title: Individual human genomes frequently contain variants that have evolutionary couplings

finding: The rs12252-C polymorphism, which expresses an N-terminally truncated IFITM3, was associated with COVID-19 severity. This finding suggested that the variant could influence susceptibility and severity of the disease by affecting the function of IFITM3, a protein that inhibits viral entry.
title: The polybasic cleavage site in the SARS-CoV-2 spike modulates viral sensitivity to Type I IFN and IFITM2

finding: The missense variant Ser159Gly (rs3135932-G) in IL10RA associated with greater IL10 levels and higher IL10RA levels. It also correlated with increased risk of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) in a meta-analysis.
title: Large-scale comparison of immunoassay- and aptamer-based plasma proteomics through genetics and disease

finding: The sentinel cis pQTL (rs11236228) for CHRDL2 was shown to be in high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with a colorectal cancer risk variant, providing replication of prior findings through its association.
title: Large-scale comparison of immunoassay- and aptamer-based plasma proteomics through genetics and disease

finding: The variant rs4944940 was in high LD with rs11236228 and associated with a colorectal cancer risk, confirming the involvement of CHRDL2 in this disease context.
title: Large-scale comparison of immunoassay- and aptamer-based plasma proteomics through genetics and disease

finding: The SNP rs174549 was associated with the FADS1 gene, which was identified as a selected haplotype influencing fitness. The analysis showed that FADS1 is under selection and its effects are modeled correctly. The identification of this SNP corresponded to population-level differences in its predicted expression.
title: A gene-level test for directional selection on gene expression

finding: The SNP rs2155380 was identified as a lead variant in the region associated with platelet count and platelet crit traits. After conditioning on the STR, this variant was confirmed as responsible for the genetic signal observed, affirming its role in platelet-related phenotypes.
title: Polymorphic short tandem repeats make widespread contributions to blood and serum traits

finding: The SNP rs7108857, which alters the second CGG repeat to TGG in the STR, was shown to be significantly associated with platelet count and platelet crit. Its effects indicated that it was in strong linkage disequilibrium with the lead variant, yet it had independent associations with the traits in question.
title: Polymorphic short tandem repeats make widespread contributions to blood and serum traits

finding: The rs12252-C SNP in the IFITM3 gene was associated with an increased risk of severe influenza virus infection in humans. This SNP was noted to cause mislocalization of IFITM3, impairing its ability to inhibit influenza virus infections effectively. Studies demonstrated that this variant was homozygous in 20% of individuals within the Han Chinese population, contributing to their susceptibility to severe influenza.
title: IFITM3 protects the heart during influenza virus infection

finding: The rs34481144-A SNP located in the promoter region of the IFITM3 gene was linked to reduced production of IFITM3 protein. Individuals, particularly those with European ancestry, who were homozygous for this SNP (4% of the population) produced lower levels of IFITM3, rendering them more vulnerable to influenza infections.
title: IFITM3 protects the heart during influenza virus infection

finding: This variant had previously been shown to significantly lower triglyceride levels, and the current study provided evidence of a novel association with increased HDL-C levels in individuals carrying the A allele.
title: Role of Rare and Low Frequency Variants in Gene-Alcohol Interactions on Plasma Lipid Levels

finding: SLC22A6 rs3017670 was identified as a variant with a frequency seen more commonly in other genomic datasets than in the HAAD set, indicating potential underrepresentation in African populations.
title: The extent and impact of variation in ADME genes in sub-Saharan African populations

finding: In the study, an association between DNA methylation levels and the genotype at rs2071094 was established. Specifically, TT homozygotes displayed significantly lower CpG3 methylation levels compared to individuals with AT or AA genotypes. This variance was noted irrespective of fertility status, indicating that genetic variation was affecting methylation rather than fertility-related methylation differences.
title: The sperm epigenome does not display recurrent epimutations in patients with severely impaired spermatogenesis

finding: This SNP was recognized in the course of the analyses connecting MS with Crohn's Disease as well.
title: Investigating the shared genetic architecture between multiple sclerosis and inflammatory bowel diseases

finding: This SNP was also part of the findings relevant to the association between MS and CD.
title: Investigating the shared genetic architecture between multiple sclerosis and inflammatory bowel diseases

finding: This variant showed significant ASE and was linked to increased risk for T2D and diabetic nephropathy in diverse populations. It was also associated with heightened glucose levels and body mass index, confirming its relevance to T2D phenotypes.
title: iPSC-derived pancreatic progenitors are an optimal model system to study T2D regulatory variants active during fetal development of the pancreas

finding: The variant rs3087967, located in the 3' UTR of C11orf53, was significantly correlated with distal colorectal cancer risk and exhibited numerous associations with trans-eQTL targets throughout the colon. This SNP was identified as influencing the expression of trans-eQTL targets, particularly those linked to tuft cell markers IL17RB and TRPM5, which are known to define a rare epithelial cell type. Therefore, the study concluded that genetic variation at this locus is pertinent to colorectal cancer risk and its related eQTL dynamics.
title: Transcriptional dynamics of colorectal cancer risk associated variation at 11q23.1 are correlated with tuft cell abundance and marker expression in silico

finding: The finding related to SNP rs11040585 demonstrated that deletions at the 7q chromosome affected nuclear organization and subsequently influenced the expression of the HLXB9 gene, linked to various hematological disorders. This SNP was considered both a positive and original finding in the context of understanding nuclear gene positioning in relation to disease.
title: Assessment of the Utility of Gene Positioning Biomarkers in the Stratification of Prostate Cancers

finding: SNP rs174564 associated with the FADS1 or FADS2 enzyme was shown to have a regulatory role in lipid metabolism, also linking it to altered hemolytic propensity in RBCs during storage.
title: Ferroptosis regulates hemolysis in stored murine and human red blood cells

finding: The variant rs554277 was found to be associated with the Diuretic hormone 31 Receptor (Dh31-R1). This association provided insights into the genetic underpinnings of photoperiodic responses in the Drosophila model.
title: Characterizing Genetic Mechanisms Involved in Measuring Day-length in Drosophila melanogaster

finding: The SNP rs45515495 was located upstream of the APOA5 gene, a known regulator of TG/HDL levels. The G2PT model indicated high attention to this SNP, and subjects associated with this attention exhibited significantly higher predicted TG/HDL levels.
title: Mechanistic genotype-phenotype translation using hierarchical transformers

finding: The study by Cavalcante et al. demonstrated that the interleukin-18 promoter -137 G/C polymorphism (rs187238) was associated with biochemical markers of renal function and cardiovascular disease specifically in type 2 diabetes patients. This finding highlighted the SNP's relevance to chronic conditions affecting metabolic health, thus linking genetic variation to obesity-related complications.
title: Single-nuclei Transcriptome of Human AT Reveals Metabolically Distinct Depot-Specific Adipose Progenitor Subpopulations

finding: The SNP rs174556 was identified as an instrumental variable for the omega-3 fatty acid eicosapentaenoate (EPA) in a Mendelian randomization analysis. This analysis demonstrated that there was a causal relationship between EPA levels and body mass index (BMI), with a p-value of 0.0498, indicating a statistically significant association.
title: Bayesian network analysis complements Mendelian randomization approaches for exploratory analysis of causal relationships in complex data

finding: The SNP rs968567 served as an instrumental variable for the omega-3 fatty acid dihomo-linolenate (DGLA). The analysis presented a causal relationship with BMI, revealing a significant association with a p-value of 0.0327. Furthermore, it was mentioned that rs968567's relationship with rs174556 creates complications in interpreting the Mendelian randomization results due to linkage disequilibrium.
title: Bayesian network analysis complements Mendelian randomization approaches for exploratory analysis of causal relationships in complex data

finding: The SNP CREB3L1/rs7127254-C was also identified as increasing in frequency from sub-Saharan Africa to Latin America, suggesting its involvement in susceptibility to Zika virus effects during pregnancy.
title: Hypothetical Human Immune Genome Complex Gradient May Help to Explain the Congenital Zika Symdrome Catastrophe in Brazil: A New Theory

finding: The SNP PLAAT4/rs4963271-A exhibited increasing frequency from sub-Saharan Africa to Latin America, contributing to the differential risk of congenital Zika syndrome across populations.
title: Hypothetical Human Immune Genome Complex Gradient May Help to Explain the Congenital Zika Symdrome Catastrophe in Brazil: A New Theory

finding: Variant rs2154984 was shown to decrease enhancer activity for microtubule affinity regulating kinase 2 (MARK2), a gene implicated in ASD, while disrupting MTF1 and ZNF148 binding sites and introducing new binding sites for PPARD and NR2F6.
title: Massively parallel characterization of psychiatric disorder-associated and cell-type-specific regulatory elements in the developing human cortex

finding: The SNP rs71046746 was part of the DBSs in FADS2, showing different binding affinities among populations, with a DAF of 0.96 in CEU, 0.99 in CHB, and 0.88 in YRI, indicating significant population-specific expression variation and representing a positive original finding.
title: Human-specific lncRNAs contributed critically to human evolution by distinctly regulating gene expression

finding: The rs1076560 variant was specifically reviewed for its relationship with schizophrenia-related phenotypes, confirming its positive association with the disorder.
title: Screening of the Key Genes and Signaling Pathways for Schizophrenia Using Bioinformatics and Next Generation Sequencing Data Analysis

finding: The variant rs1061328, located in an intron of the PPFIA1 gene, showed signatures of positive selection. It was linked to the expression of genes critical for cell adhesion and migration, which are essential for placenta development and potentially involved in sPTB.
title: Accounting for diverse evolutionary forces reveals the mosaic nature of selection on genomic regions associated with human preterm birth

finding: The SNP rs78540526 was found to be a significant susceptibility locus in the CCND1 region on chromosome 11. It also reached genome-wide significance in the MTOP and FTOP analyses (P < 5.0 × 10^-8). The heterogeneity test for this SNP indicated significant variance by estrogen receptor (ER) status (P=0.011) and tumor grade (P=0.024).
title: A Mixed-Model Approach for Powerful Testing of Genetic Associations with Cancer Risk Incorporating Tumor Characteristics

finding: The SNP rs621313 was found to be associated with early AMD (P=6.8×10^-4) and was noted as being located near the TYR gene. This was classified as a completely novel locus for any AMD, and it was also significantly associated with various traits, including melanoma risk and skin pigmentation characteristics.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis for early age-related macular degeneration highlights novel loci and insights for advanced disease

finding: The SNP rs1042602 was a missense variant found in the credible set for the TYR locus. This variant had been previously associated with traits such as skin color and macular thickness. In this study, it was noted that it might also influence the risk of early AMD by potentially affecting retina health through melanin production.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis for early age-related macular degeneration highlights novel loci and insights for advanced disease

finding: Research published by Frisch et al. in 2019 indicated that the SNP rs11040457 was associated with alterations in STIM-Orai channels and reactive oxygen species within the tumor microenvironment, which could influence immune cell function and cancer cell resistance.
title: Combined CTL and NK cell cytotoxicity against cancer cells

finding: The SNP rs10770141 of the tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) gene was part of a double SNP combination linked to late-onset treatment-resistant schizophrenia (L-TRS). This combination indicated a risk related to dopaminergic signaling, suggesting that individuals carrying the T(+) allele may be more susceptible to the disease due to its association with higher TH gene expression.
title: Genetic combination risk for schizophrenia

finding: The SNP rs1800497, also known as TaqIA of the DRD2 gene, was included in a triple SNP combination indicating a risk for L-TRS. The presence of the A1(+) allele was associated with lower DRD2 gene expression, suggesting its potential role in increasing susceptibility to dopamine-related schizophrenia.
title: Genetic combination risk for schizophrenia

finding: The SNP rs10792832 was identified to overlap non-neuronal peaks, suggesting it has functional effects related to the expression of PICALM in microglia and/or oligodendrocytes. It exhibited significant GWAS p-values, indicating a strong connection to Alzheimer’s Disease, highlighting the need for future studies incorporating these cell types to clarify its functional role.
title: Cell type-specific histone acetylation profiling of Alzheimer’s Disease subjects and integration with genetics

finding: Similarly, rs3851179 was found to be in tight linkage with rs10792832 and also overlapped non-neuronal peaks, implying effects on PICALM expression, likely in microglia and/or oligodendrocytes. High GWAS p-values were recorded, indicating a substantial role in the context of Alzheimer’s Disease, thus underscoring the importance of future research into its functional impacts.
title: Cell type-specific histone acetylation profiling of Alzheimer’s Disease subjects and integration with genetics

finding: The SNP rs12365516 was examined for its influence in the CCDC82 region and confirmed as a single modifier effect, associated with Huntington's disease pathways.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The variant rs585809, mapped to the TRIM29 gene, was found to have a significant interaction with CAG expansion size (P = 0.01). This finding suggested that rs585809 might modulate the age at onset (AO) of Machado-Joseph disease (MJD) through this epistatic interaction.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies genetic factors that modify age at onset in Machado-Joseph disease

finding: The strongest signal identified was for the rs11529293 variant within the C11orf72 and RAG loci at 11p12, which had a significant association with AO (P = 3.30 × 10^-6). This association suggested involvement of DNA damage response genes RAG1 and RAG2 in MJD pathogenesis.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies genetic factors that modify age at onset in Machado-Joseph disease

finding: The lead SNP rs9420 was associated with schizophrenia and exhibited a co-localization probability of 90.1% with the expression of MED19, a gene involved in neuronal gene regulation.
title: Multi-tissue analysis reveals short tandem repeats as ubiquitous regulators of gene expression and complex traits

finding: The SNP rs12420140 was identified within the BCO2 locus, where both FiniMOM and SuSiE produced one credible set containing the same variants. This association was further supported by detection in the replication GWAS, confirming its relevance in the genetic landscape of the BCO2 locus.
title: Genetic fine-mapping from summary data using a non-local prior improves detection of multiple causal variants

finding: The SNP rs10830237, located near the TYR gene encoding tyrosinase, was classified as having the highest posterior probability for the induced genotype effect, demonstrating a gene-by-treatment interaction.
title: Probabilistic classification of gene-by-treatment interactions on molecular count phenotypes

finding: The study highlighted that the MALAT1 rs664589 polymorphism inhibited binding to miR-194-5p, which contributed to increased colorectal cancer (CRC) risk, growth, and metastasis. This finding was significant in the context of the inter-tumor heterogeneity observed in CRC, showing how a specific SNP can influence miRNA interactions and thereby affect tumor behavior.
title: Multi-omic study of genome-edited human colonoid models of colorectal cancer reveal genotype-specific patterns of microRNA regulation

finding: At the FADS1 locus, the associated SNP was under selection due to dietary changes, showing significant selection starting before the Neolithic and continuing during this period.
title: The Selection Landscape and Genetic Legacy of Ancient Eurasians

finding: The FADS2 locus exhibited strong selection signals in relation to dietary adaptations to fat intake, with evidence showing selection occurring before Neolithic arrivals in Europe.
title: The Selection Landscape and Genetic Legacy of Ancient Eurasians

finding: The SNP rs35705950, located in theMUC5B promoter, was previously associated with Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF). This study documented that the SNP overlaps a long non-coding RNA (lncRNA) named AC061979.1, suggesting its role in MUC5B expression regulation. Analysis of 3.9 TBases of RNA-SEQ data revealed expression of AC061979.1 in epithelial lung cells, and the SNP was found to be within a conserved region indicative of its functional significance. The G/T variant of rs35705950 exhibited strong associations with increased susceptibility and mortality in IPF across diverse populations and was linked to heightened MUC5B transcription and translation, contributing to dysregulation of MUC5B and resulting in mucus overproduction and cellular consequences in the alveolar environment.
title: The Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis-associated single nucleotide polymorphism rs35705950 is transcribed in a MUC5B Promoter Associated Long Non-Coding RNA (AC061979.1)

finding: The rs174570C SNP in the FADS2-3 gene showed an increase in frequency from about 20% in Eastern Baltic and Western Russian hunter-gatherers to roughly 50% in Corded Ware Culture individuals. This allele was connected to increased cholesterol and decreased triglyceride levels.
title: Genetic ancestry changes in Stone to Bronze Age transition in the East European plain

finding: The SNP rs648044 was associated with educational attainment in two genome-wide association studies (GWAS), showing strong links (FDR = 9×10^-9 and FDR = 2×10^-8) to this cognitive trait. Furthermore, rs648044 influenced glucocorticoid-induced expression of the transcription factor ZBTB16 in developing brain tissue, which correlated with increased generalized cortical thickness and surface area related to neurodevelopmental outcomes. Mendelian randomization analysis also revealed its associations with various neurobehavioral traits, supporting that the higher expression of ZBTB16, especially in A allele carriers, corresponds to better educational outcomes and positive neuroimaging phenotypes.
title: Temporal regulation of ZBTB16 expression by glucocorticoids alters human cortical neurogenesis

finding: The study by Šafranko et al. highlighted the application of N-Doped Carbon Quantum Dots (CNPs) in selective detection of Fe(III) ions. This finding was particularly significant in relation to metal ion sensing in the context of enhancing the properties of nanoparticles, which indicated that variations in this SNP may relate to the efficiency of CNPs in metal sequestration and agricultural applications.
title: Novel carbon nanoparticles (CNPs) from Catharanthus roseus petals for metal ion sensing and root growth modulation

finding: The SNP rs659366 in the UCP2 gene was linked to genes associated with energy metabolism and anxiety-like behaviors, showing potential implications for behaviors relating to psychiatric vulnerability in both animal models and human studies.
title: Bioenergetic-Related Gene Expression in the Hippocampus Predicts Internalizing vs. Externalizing Behavior in a F2 Cross of Selectively-Bred Rats

finding: The SNP rs11020146 was identified as being associated with cholesterol metabolism, which was emphasized in the context of its potential implications in neurodevelopmental disorders by modulating mTORC1 signaling and enabling transcriptional regulation of sterol/cholesterol biosynthesis genes. This link highlighted the significance of cholesterol levels in brain development and functioning, particularly concerning neurodevelopmental disorders.
title: mTOR driven gene transcription is required for cholesterol production in neurons of the developing cerebral cortex

finding: The variant rs10792831 was associated with PICALM in microglia from control subjects, indicating that it plays a role in the regulation of this AD risk gene. However, the association was not significant in microglia from AD subjects, suggesting that this regulatory effect is context-specific and may contribute to Alzheimer's disease susceptibility by dysregulating PICALM expression.
title: Cell-type-specific mapping of enhancers and target genes from single-cell multimodal data

finding: The single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) rs10830963 in the intron of the MTNR1B gene was robustly associated with increased risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D). Carriers of the G-risk allele exhibited diminished insulin secretion, increased fasting plasma glucose, and a higher risk of developing T2D compared to non-risk C-allele carriers. This SNP acted as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL), conferring enhanced expression of MTNR1B mRNA in pancreatic islets from risk allele carriers. Furthermore, cells differentiated from hiPSC and hESC lines carrying the G-allele displayed increased sensitivity to melatonin, which correlated with reduced insulin secretion, indicating the SNP's functional role in β-cell dysfunction.
title: Modelling genetic risk of β-cell dysfunction in human induced pluripotent stem cells from patients carrying the MTNR1B risk variant

finding: SNP rs11602449 exhibited a significant association with late-onset Alzheimer's disease, providing a nominal p-value of 0.003, indicating a genetic link between the DKK3 gene and AD. This SNP, located in an intronic region, had a minor allele frequency of 0.25 in the European population and 0.22 globally, which suggested potential functional implications due to linkage disequilibrium with other variants impacting DKK3 gene expression.
title: Restoring synapse integrity and memory in Alzheimer’s disease by downregulation of the Wnt antagonist Dickkopf-3

finding: The variant rs7935166 located in 11p11.2 was associated with alterations in white matter microstructure traits, particularly affecting non-FA parameters.
title: Common genetic variation influencing human white matter microstructure

finding: The SNP rs11020251 was associated with FOXM1 overexpression in cancer, highlighting its potential role in genomic features related to tumorigenesis. This finding was established through pan-cancer analyses which suggested that variations at this locus could influence the expression of FOXM1, a gene implicated in cancer progression.
title: PEX39 facilitates the peroxisomal import of PTS2 proteins

finding: The SNP rs7926602 was linked to lower ALKBH8 expression in both quiescent and proliferative SMCs, implicating its role in CAD risk and blood pressure regulation.
title: Genetic regulation of human aortic smooth muscle cell gene expression and splicing predict causal coronary artery disease genes

finding: The SNP rs11020216 was associated with the long non-coding RNA MALAT1, which has been implicated in cancer and metastasis. This finding related to the role of MALAT1 in hematopoietic differentiation, particularly in the context of myelodysplastic syndromes where gene expression variability was observed.
title: Hematopoietic differentiation is characterized by a transient peak of entropy at a single cell level

finding: The novel male-specific signal rs3824915, located in the gene ALX4 that encodes a homeobox gene involved in FGF signaling, was associated with male puberty timing and relates to disorders of cranium/CNS development.
title: Expanded genomic analyses for male voice-breaking highlights a shared phenotypic and genetic basis between puberty timing and hair colour

finding: The SNP rs12279250 was located within the NELL1 gene at the 11p15.1 locus and was implicated in metabolic traits, particularly in altering fasting plasma triglyceride levels. This association was highlighted in genetic studies focusing on African American populations.
title: Causal network perturbation analysis identifies known and novel type-2 diabetes driver genes

finding: Similar to rs12279250, the SNP rs4319515 was also identified within the NELL1 gene and demonstrated a correlation with changes in fasting plasma triglyceride levels, further supporting its association with metabolic traits in certain populations.
title: Causal network perturbation analysis identifies known and novel type-2 diabetes driver genes

finding: This SNP was identified as a trans-intrachromosomal eQTL associated with the gene NAV2, contributing to the understanding of gene regulation in COPD through change in transcription levels.
title: De novo discovery of traits co-occurring with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

finding: This SNP was also identified as a trans-interchromosomal eQTL, specifically linked to the KALRN gene, further indicating its involvement in the complex gene regulation mechanisms associated with COPD.
title: De novo discovery of traits co-occurring with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

finding: The study identified a novel association between rs12295710 (p.Gly15Ser) in MRGPRE and migraine, with statistical significance (p=3.8×10⁻⁸, OR=1.07, 95% CI: 1.05-1.10). This variant had not been previously reported in associations with migraine in the GWAS Catalog.
title: Medical relevance of common protein-altering variants in GPCR genes across 337,205 individuals in the UK Biobank

finding: This variant (p.Asn169Asp) in MRGPRX3 was found to be associated with standing height (p=7.69×10⁻⁶, β=0.0090, 95% CI: 0.0051-0.013), indicating a population association discussed for the first time.
title: Medical relevance of common protein-altering variants in GPCR genes across 337,205 individuals in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs12807809 was located immediately upstream of the NRGN gene on chromosome 11 and was associated with schizophrenia. A novel transcription start site was identified approximately 20 kb upstream of the annotated TSS for NRGN, with the novel transcripts incorporating annotated exons of NRGN.
title: Targeted, High-resolution RNA Sequencing of Non-coding Genomic Regions Associated with Neuropsychiatric Functions

finding: In the study, the common allele (T, major allele frequency = 0.67) of the FADS1 SNP rs174547 was associated with an increase in levels of several lipid species that typically contain polyunsaturated fatty acids, such as PC20:4 and TG56:6, among others. It was also associated with a decrease in levels of species with lower saturation status. This finding was notable for its implications in lipid metabolism.
title: Genome-wide association study of plasma triglycerides, phospholipids and relation to cardio-metabolic risk factors

finding: The SNP rs12366015 at the APOA1 locus was associated with hyperlipidemia and lipid lowering medication intake, highlighting its role in lipid disorders and metabolic health.
title: Genome-wide association study of plasma triglycerides, phospholipids and relation to cardio-metabolic risk factors

finding: The SNP rs174546 at the FADS1 locus was associated with increased total triglycerides but decreased levels of high polyunsaturated TGs, showcasing its specific regulatory role in lipid metabolism.
title: Genome-wide association study of plasma triglycerides, phospholipids and relation to cardio-metabolic risk factors

finding: The SNP rs11030346 was originally and positively associated with molecular characterization of colorectal primary tumors based on miRNA profiles, as reported in a study by Moreno et al. in 2019. This linkage offered insights into potential biomarkers for colorectal cancers, highlighting rs11030346's relevance in the context of cancer pathology.
title: Comprehensive multi-omics profiling of a healthy human cohort

finding: The SNP rs1801028 was linked to Schizophrenia, with the study indicating that mutations in the DRD2 gene associated with this SNP were deleterious. The findings suggested that the resultant protein exhibited abnormal interactions with key partners like neuronal calcium sensor 1, which may disrupt neurotransmitter regulation, thus contributing to the pathology of Schizophrenia.
title: In silico analysis of the altered protein structure and functions caused by existing synaptic gene mutations in Indian population having neurological disorders

finding: The SNP rs1125472 was found to overlap with a cxSV in the region associated with HAQER0245. This SNP was notably linked to the phenotypic trait of mathematical ability, suggesting that it may play a critical role in cognitive functions.
title: Automatic detection of complex structural genome variation across world populations

finding: The intronic peak carrying the fine-mapped red blood cell SNP rs2077078 demonstrated increased accessibility in Ts21 HSCs, with significance P = 1.4×10^-3. Its accessibility was also associated with the expression of C11orf21 and TSPAN32 (P < 0.03). However, differential expression analysis indicated that only TSPAN32 was dysregulated in Ts21 HSCs (P = 1.4×10^-3), suggesting a role in the lineage bias observed in Down's Syndrome, with TSPAN32 being the likely causal gene of the rs7775698-linked enhancer impacting red blood cell development.
title: Single-cell multi-omics map of human foetal blood in Down’s Syndrome

finding: The SNP rs11020216 was associated with the expression of the long non-coding RNA MALAT1, which has implications in cancer and metastasis. The findings suggested that variations at this locus could influence cancer progression through the modulation of MALAT1 expression levels.
title: Transcriptomic forecasting with neural ODEs

finding: The SNP rs4246215 was significantly associated with ulcerative colitis (UC) through the gene C11orf9, also known as MYRF. This association was identified in the context of the literature, where this gene was previously linked to inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) through a co-expression cluster of upregulated genes.
title: Finding associations in a heterogeneous setting: Statistical test for aberration enrichment

finding: SNP rs2079227 was found to correlate with increased thickness in the inferior temporal cortex for ASD, demonstrating its role.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs4930184 was linked with increased temporal pole SA for BD, showing its genetic effect on cortical structures.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs7127383 was shown to influence greater thickness in the auditory cortex across ADHD, PTSD, and SCZ, indicating its multifaceted genetic role.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: The variant rs7130881 was significantly implicated in both breast cancer and prostate cancer, with strong support in existing literature. It was part of a genomic region found at locus 11q13.3, which shared associations between the two cancer types, highlighting its relevance in cancer predisposition.
title: Recessive effects in cancer predisposition exposed by genome-wide and proteome-wide association studies

finding: SNP rs10749999 was associated with increased NCAM1 expression, positing that it may enhance YY1 and TEAD1 binding to the NCAM1 promoter within Schwann cells. This finding underscores joint regulatory mechanisms involving multiple transcription factors in controlling NCAM1 expression.
title: NetREm: Network Regression Embeddings reveal cell-type transcription factor coordination for gene regulation

finding: The stop-gained variant rs121907892 was replicated in association with uric acid levels, a well-reported finding that is notably unique to the East Asian population, including Koreans. This finding highlighted the genetic variance related to metabolic traits in the PheWAS results.
title: Phenome-wide association study of a comprehensive health check-up database in a Korea population: Clinical application & trans-ethnic comparison

finding: The analysis indicated that rs56030824 was significantly associated with both AUD (P = 8.91 × 10^-6) and DPW (P = 4.90 × 10^-12). It co-localized with the promoter marks for SPI1 specifically in microglia and was shown to alter a regulatory motif for the transcription factor RXRA, linking it to the biological processes in myeloid cells.
title: Multi-omics integration analysis identifies novel genes for alcoholism with potential link to neurodegenerative diseases

finding: The presence of the rs907611 risk allele was associated with decreased NFKB1 target gene expression in non-inflamed cases across all clusters, except Cluster 2, where it was linked to higher expression. This indicated a protective role in non-inflamed settings but an exacerbating role in inflamed conditions for UC.
title: A systems genomics approach to uncover patient-specific pathogenic pathways and proteins in a complex disease

finding: The risk allele at rs543104 was found to decrease NFKB1 target gene expression in all clusters during non-inflammation, suggesting protective effects. Conversely, during inflammation, it protected against increased expression only in specific clusters, thus revealing a context-dependent regulatory role in UC.
title: A systems genomics approach to uncover patient-specific pathogenic pathways and proteins in a complex disease

finding: The variant rs34588274 was associated with decreased sociability and belonged to the ARNTL gene, which is a circadian clock gene. This association was significant and showed relevance to mental health disorders like SCZ, MDD, and ASDs, supported by genetic correlation findings.
title: Genetic underpinnings of sociability in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs4245154 was linked to the DRD2 gene, a well-known candidate gene for multiple psychiatric disorders, including SCZ and MDD. This finding indicated that it potentially tapped into shared genetic mechanisms influencing sociability and psychiatric conditions.
title: Genetic underpinnings of sociability in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs4758351 on chromosome 11, located within an intergenic region of olfactory receptor genes, was associated with 2.39 times the odds of cryptosporidiosis in the first year of life. This finding contributes to the identification of genetic variants influencing susceptibility to symptomatic Cryptosporidium infection.
title: Genome-wide association study of cryptosporidiosis in infants implicates PRKCA

finding: The allele at rs1061810 showed a downregulation of L1 family gene sets and was found significant in the context of the HSD17B12 gene. This SNP's influence on TE expression was documented through both differential expression and GSEA.
title: An eQTL-based Approach Reveals Candidate Regulators of LINE-1 RNA Levels in Lymphoblastoid Cells

finding: The SNP rs2176598 was identified in connection with the regulatory gene HSD17B12 and demonstrated positive associations with L1 RNA levels through trans-eQTL analysis. It indicated the potential regulatory capacity of HSD17B12.
title: An eQTL-based Approach Reveals Candidate Regulators of LINE-1 RNA Levels in Lymphoblastoid Cells

finding: The variant rs4246215, located on chromosome 11, was found to be significantly associated with multiple blood cell traits, including red cell distribution width (p-value 1.45E-57), platelet counts (p-value 5.12E-47), and mean platelet volume (p-value 1.11E-50). This variant was linked to the gene FEN1 which was suggested to play a role in megakaryopoiesis and platelet formation. The findings indicated that the association of this variant with blood cell phenotypes supports a connection between allele-specific expression (ASE) and immune-related conditions.
title: Allele Specific Expression in Human – Genomic Makeup and Phenotypic Implications

finding: The study explored the common null polymorphism R577X (rs1815739) in the ACTN3 gene, which was associated with reduced muscle strength and slower walking speeds in young ambulant boys with Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) who lacked the gene. Conversely, aged dKO mice lacking both dystrophin and alpha-actinin-3 displayed protection against force deficits in fast-twitch muscles induced by eccentric contractions, indicating that the polymorphism had an age-related ameliorating effect on muscle pathology of dystrophinopathies. The findings suggested that the R577X polymorphism could switch fast-twitch fibers to a more glycolytic metabolism and increase the action of SERCA1 pumps, both contributing to better resilience against muscle injury associated with DMD.
title: Loss of α-actinin-3 confers protection from eccentric contraction damage in fast-twitch EDL muscles from aged mdx dystrophic mice by reducing pathological fibre branching

finding: The single nucleotide polymorphism rs755016, located in an intron of the Ano1 gene encoding TMEM16A, was implicated in the regulation of TMEM16A gene expression. It was associated with an increased risk of developing ischemic stroke as indicated by the MEGASTROKE genetic association study, and it also correlated with recovery after ischemic stroke based on the GISCOME study. Additionally, the SNP was found to be linked with raised diastolic blood pressure in a large study of 757,601 participants, which is relevant as TMEM16A is associated with increasing systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure. This SNP was notably connected to psychiatric, neurological, and circulatory traits in a phenome-wide association study.
title: The Ca2+-gated Cl- channel TMEM16A amplifies capillary pericyte contraction reducing cerebral blood flow after ischemia

finding: This SNP was highlighted as a caQTL in activated CD4+ T cells for loci associated with child-onset asthma, demonstrating allele-specific influences on accessibility (π=0.36, q-value=5.4×10^-4).
title: Mapping genetic effects on cell type-specific chromatin accessibility and annotating complex trait variants using single nucleus ATAC-seq

finding: This SNP in the MRPL21 gene demonstrated the strongest associations with HDL and triglycerides, highlighting its significance in lipid-related traits.
title: A method to map and interpret pleiotropic loci using summary statistics of multiple traits

finding: Found in the TNKS1BP1 gene, this SNP exhibited strong associations with HDL and total cholesterol, adding insights into its role in lipid traits.
title: A method to map and interpret pleiotropic loci using summary statistics of multiple traits

finding: At rs10791824, located near the OVOL1 gene, a strong preference for the A allele was observed. In a study involving six individuals, 85-100% of the reads were for the A allele, indicating a significant allele-specific chromatin accessibility response in stimulated CD4+ T cells of patients with atopic dermatitis (AD). This finding contributed to the overall discovery that 36 out of 60 AD-associated genetic variants exhibited allele-dependent behavior, reflecting the disease-specific regulatory mechanisms present in CD4+ T cells.
title: Epigenetic and Transcriptional Dysregulation in CD4+ T cells of Patients with Atopic Dermatitis

finding: The SNP rs636317-T was located in a CTCF binding site in the MS4A locus. It was shown to disrupt the CTCF binding consensus sequence, leading to altered chromatin architecture and increased expression of MS4A6A in microglial cells, thereby increasing AD risk.
title: Integration of Alzheimer’s disease genetics and myeloid cell genomics identifies novel causal variants, regulatory elements, genes and pathways

finding: The SNP rs11605348 was linked to the ARFGAP2 locus. Mutation of the zebrafish ortholog revealed developmental impairment, highlighting the importance of ARFGAP2 in early development and its implications for sleep-related behaviors.
title: Zebrafish screen of high-confidence effector genes at insomnia GWAS loci implicates conserved regulators of sleep-wake behaviors

finding: The SNP rs217727 was found to be significantly associated with dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). It induced a remarkable shift in the structural ensemble of the lncRNA H19, which is highly expressed in the heart and involved in various regulatory functions. The presence of this SNP was indicated to potentially impair the function of H19 and contribute to the pathogenesis of complex diseases, such as heart failure.
title: A genetic variant alters the secondary structure of the lncRNA H19 and is associated with Dilated Cardiomyopathy

finding: The intronic variant rs10765565 located on chromosome 11 was found to be genome-wide significant in relation to RRD.
title: Insight into the genetic aetiology of retinal detachment by combining small clinical and large population-based datasets

finding: The intronic variant rs7118363 was significant in association with idiopathic retinal detachment, contributing to the genetic understanding of the condition.
title: Insight into the genetic aetiology of retinal detachment by combining small clinical and large population-based datasets

finding: The SNP rs633918 in GRM5 was significantly associated with RRD, as confirmed by the sensitivity analyses.
title: Insight into the genetic aetiology of retinal detachment by combining small clinical and large population-based datasets

finding: The genotyped variant rs7118248 representing FAT3 emerged as a prominent signal for retinal detachment in the metanalysis.
title: Insight into the genetic aetiology of retinal detachment by combining small clinical and large population-based datasets

finding: The variant rs12792820 within TRIM29 also demonstrated significant associations contributing to the understanding of retinal detachment risk.
title: Insight into the genetic aetiology of retinal detachment by combining small clinical and large population-based datasets

finding: Missense variant rs1042602 in TYR showed a strong association with retinal detachment across multiple studies.
title: Insight into the genetic aetiology of retinal detachment by combining small clinical and large population-based datasets

finding: The rs2078267 variant located in the SLC22A11 gene was identified as another novel GWAS signal for BMI, with a significant P-value of 4.62 × 10−8 in the Indian population.
title: Multifaceted genome-wide study identifies novel regulatory loci for body mass index in Indians

finding: The SNP rs629367 was identified as a new polymorphism biomarker associated with an increased risk and poor survival of gastric cancer in a Chinese population, linked to the up-regulated expression of the miRNA let-7a.
title: FINDEL: A Deep Learning Approach to Efficient Artifact Removal From Cancer Genomes

finding: The SNP rs3741240, located in an intronic region of the SCGB1A1 gene on chromosome 11, was noted as being significantly associated with increased serum CC-16 levels and was previously identified in a GWAS for serum CC-16. Moreover, it was associated with a change in FEV1 in both Lung Health Study (LHS) and ECLIPSE cohorts, demonstrating a protective effect against COPD risk and progression.
title: The protective effect of club cell secretory protein (CC-16) on COPD risk and progression: a Mendelian randomisation study

finding: The SNP rs11231085 on chromosome 11, also an intronic variant in the SCGB1A1 gene, was among those significantly associated with serum CC-16 levels and showed a protective effect linked to changes in FEV1 in the LHS, thereby indicating its involvement in lung function decline.
title: The protective effect of club cell secretory protein (CC-16) on COPD risk and progression: a Mendelian randomisation study

finding: The SNP rs3135506 was associated with the APOA5 gene, which is involved in lipid metabolism. The variant was found to have the highest frequency in the HUI population and was linked to increased triglyceride levels and an elevated risk of coronary artery disease among various populations, including those identified as 'Hispanic'.
title: Population history and gene divergence in Native Mexicans inferred from 76 human exomes

finding: The SNP rs11040573 was associated with the dysregulation of Natural Killer (NK) cells in obesity-related conditions, specifically non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). This dysregulation was characterized by a notable decrease in NK cell cytotoxicity, which was linked to a transcriptional shift towards a profile typical of ILC1, suggesting potential implications for the immune response in obesity. The findings indicated that this SNP played a role in the metabolic changes observed in the livers of NAFLD patients.
title: TGFβ in the obese liver mediates conversion of NK cells to a less cytotoxic ILC1-like phenotype

finding: The SNP rs2649667 at the SLC43A1 locus was associated with phenylalanine levels, shedding light on the genetic regulation of this amino acid.
title: Cross-platform genetic discovery of small molecule products of metabolism and application to clinical outcomes

finding: The SNP rs7924772 demonstrated opposite odds ratios between HER2-negative and HER2-positive tumors, with associations suggesting a role in subtype-specific breast cancer risk; it was exclusively associated with HER2 status (P=1.4×10^-6), highlighting its significance in tumor marker heterogeneity.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies 32 novel breast cancer susceptibility loci from overall and subtype-specific analyses

finding: The SNP rs11030066 was identified through aLIT as having notable interactive effects in the context of obesity-related traits.
title: Identifying latent genetic interactions in genome-wide association studies using multiple traits

finding: The SNP rs78813996 in TMEM41B was identified to cause an Ile266Val/Leu substitution, with Val being the most prevalent variant. This SNP was nearly absent in European and African populations but had a frequency of approximately 3.5% in the Latin American population and around 20% in East and Southeast Asian populations. Additionally, it was found that this SNP negatively impacted flavivirus infection, suggesting a protective role against such viral infections in populations where this variant was more common.
title: TMEM41B is a pan-flavivirus host factor

finding: SNP rs35774874 was identified as colocalising with an i-eQTL targeting a probable novel 3'UTR of SNX19. The posterior colocalisation probability was 0.75, and this gene had already been implicated in schizophrenia, reinforcing the SNP's relevance to this neurological condition.
title: Regulatory sites for known and novel splicing in human basal ganglia are enriched for disease-relevant information

finding: SNP rs1050078, located in the SNX19 gene, was shown to operate in a gene-level manner, with both the exon containing the variant and the gene-level expression demonstrating a similar dosage relationship across individuals.
title: Regulatory sites for known and novel splicing in human basal ganglia are enriched for disease-relevant information

finding: Identified as part of a potential new allele for the Lu(a-b-) phenotype, contributing to discussions around loss-of-function mutations.
title: Characterization of Blood Group Variants in an Omani Population by Comparison of Whole Genome Sequencing and Serology

finding: This closely located SNP was examined in relation to roles in new allele predictions within the Lutheran blood group type, demonstrating diversity in blood group expression.
title: Characterization of Blood Group Variants in an Omani Population by Comparison of Whole Genome Sequencing and Serology

finding: Identified as a strong islet signal (TOA=1.0), this SNP was consistent with colocalized eQTL implicating MTNR1B as an effector gene in T2D.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs174601 was associated with decreased expression of the FADS1 and FADS2 genes in the liver, as well as decreased FADS1 and increased FADS2 and C11orf10 expression in peripheral leukocytes. This SNP contributed significantly to the protective association of elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels with preeclampsia (PE), with an overall odds ratio (OR) of 0.89, indicating a decreased risk of PE.
title: Risk of preeclampsia in patients with genetic predisposition to common medical conditions: a case-control study

finding: At the drd2 locus, rs2514218, a noncoding variant located 47 kb upstream from DRD2, was previously associated with anti-psychotic drug response in a cohort of schizophrenia patients. The study demonstrated that mono-allelic deletion of a candidate promoter-interacting region (PIR) upstream of DRD2 resulted in significant downregulation of DRD2 expression in excitatory neurons, providing further evidence of the regulatory impact of this SNP.
title: cis-Regulatory Chromatin Contacts in Neural Cells Reveal Contributions of Genetic Variants to Complex Neurological Disorders

finding: The SNP rs11218343 was associated with significant modified risk for the common late onset form of Alzheimer's disease (LOAD). This association suggested that carriers of this SNP had an altered risk profile for developing LOAD.
title: Relying on the relationship with known disease-causing variants in homologous proteins to predict pathogenicity of SORL1 variants in Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs74685827 was identified to independently associate with an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD). This suggests that this variant contributes to the genetic risk factors involved in the development of AD.
title: Relying on the relationship with known disease-causing variants in homologous proteins to predict pathogenicity of SORL1 variants in Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs11040538 was linked to genetic variations associated with the activation of the Hedgehog (HH)/GLI pathway. This was crucial as it underpinned the oncogenic signaling in cancers where CSNK1D was found to play a significant role in modulating GLI activity downstream of Smoothened (SMO). The study indicated that patients carrying the variant might respond differently to therapies targeting this pathway.
title: Casein kinase 1D encodes a novel drug target in Hedgehog-GLI driven cancers and tumor-initiating cells resistant to SMO inhibition

finding: The analysis indicated that rs10047483, located in intron 1 of PPP6R3, was the most significant eQTL SNP in thyroid tissue and its eQTL P-value was 6.99 x 10^-8. It colocalized with the eBMD GWAS lead SNP (rs11228240), and opposing allele effects suggested that reduced expression of PPP6R3 may lead to increased BMD.
title: Transcriptome-wide Association Study and eQTL colocalization identify potentially causal genes responsible for bone mineral density GWAS associations

finding: This SNP was located upstream of PPP6R3 and had a significant eBMD GWAS P-value of 6.6 x 10^-101. It showed high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs10047483 (r2=0.941) and supported the evidence that PPP6R3 expression was inversely related to BMD.
title: Transcriptome-wide Association Study and eQTL colocalization identify potentially causal genes responsible for bone mineral density GWAS associations

finding: This SNP was identified in a fracture GWAS as being significant in the PPP6R3 region. The TWAS analysis suggested its expression was significant for fracture (Bonferroni P-value of 6.0 x 10^-3) and it colocalized with eQTL associations in ovarian and thyroid tissues.
title: Transcriptome-wide Association Study and eQTL colocalization identify potentially causal genes responsible for bone mineral density GWAS associations

finding: In the context of this study, the SNP rs60808706 was linked to the LATE gene cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 1C (CDKN1C). The risk-increasing allele associated with this SNP was found to elevate the expression of CDKN1C, particularly in leukocytes exhibiting mosaic loss of chromosome Y (LOY). This finding suggested a bi-directional relationship wherein increased expression of CDKN1C contributed to the development of LOY, and the presence of LOY further altered the expression of CDKN1C, potentially leading to a cycle of enhanced clonal mosaicism due to disrupted cell cycle processes.
title: Immune cells lacking Y chromosome have widespread dysregulation of autosomal genes

finding: The SNP rs10830963 colocalized with both eQTL and T2D signals, showing strong association and regulatory implications in islet tissue.
title: TIGER: The gene expression regulatory variation landscape of human pancreatic islets

finding: The study demonstrated that the rs6265 SNP in the brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) gene significantly influenced the efficacy of therapeutic electrical stimulation (TES) in promoting muscle reinnervation following peripheral nerve injuries (PNI) in a preclinical rat model. Wild-type (WT) rats showed enhanced muscle reinnervation and greater muscle fiber cross-sectional area (CSA) following TES treatment. In contrast, rs6265 allele carriers did not exhibit significant improvements with TES, and their activity-dependent BDNF secretion was impaired compared to WT. These results highlighted the necessity of considering the rs6265 genotype in personalized treatment approaches for PNI.
title: The Impact of Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor rs6265 (Val66Met) Polymorphism on Therapeutic Electrical Stimulation for Peripheral Nerve Regeneration: A Preclinical Study of Therapy-Genotype Interactions

finding: The AD-protective allele of rs2293577 (G) was associated with higher expression of most causal genes in the 11p11.2 locus. This suggested a regulatory role in genes related to Alzheimer's disease.
title: A multiple-causal-gene-cluster model underlying GWAS signals of Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The risk allele of rs2280231 (A) was found to have an opposite effect on gene expression compared to the protective allele of rs2293577. This highlighted its negative impact in the regulation of multiple genes linked to Alzheimer's disease.
title: A multiple-causal-gene-cluster model underlying GWAS signals of Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The finding related to SNP rs2168101, which involves a G>T transition, indicated that this allele creates a GATA binding motif crucial for the DNA-binding activity of the GATA3 transcription factor. This activity was necessary for establishing a super-enhancer controlling the expression of the LMO1 gene locus in neuroblastoma. The high levels of GATA3 expression correlated with a dependency on LMO1 in a subset of neuroblastoma tumors and cell lines, which underlined its role as a transcriptional co-regulator of the adrenergic core regulatory circuit (CRC). ATRA treatment led to the loss of GATA3 expression, resulting in the collapse of the LMO1 super-enhancer, thus demonstrating a direct link between this SNP and the regulatory mechanisms governing neuroblastoma differentiation.
title: Retinoic acid rewires the adrenergic core regulatory circuitry of neuroblastoma but can be subverted by enhancer hijacking of MYC or MYCN

finding: In the UK Biobank cohort, rs11032483 was found to have a significant association with sex, showing an odds ratio of 1.25 and a p-value less than 1.3E-53. This variant is located in a known regulatory region on chromosome 11 and was suggested to increase risk in males while being protective in females for various sex-specific reproductive pathologies.
title: Sexually Antagonistic Selection on Genetic Variation is Rare in Humans

finding: The SNP rs11025530 was associated with the expression of <italic>NLRP6</italic> during comparisons between TB-T2D and T2D patients, adjusted for Khoe-San ancestry.
title: cis-eQTL mapping of TB-T2D comorbidity elucidates the involvement of African ancestry in TB susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs3808990 was linked to the expression of <italic>NLRP6</italic> in the context of TB-T2D versus T2D patients, while adjusting for Khoe-San ancestry.
title: cis-eQTL mapping of TB-T2D comorbidity elucidates the involvement of African ancestry in TB susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs10896664 was identified as affecting the expression of <italic>NLRP6</italic> when comparing TB-T2D and T2D patients, with adjustments for Khoe-San ancestry.
title: cis-eQTL mapping of TB-T2D comorbidity elucidates the involvement of African ancestry in TB susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs55970487 was associated with the expression of <italic>IFITM3</italic> when analyzing TB-T2D against T2D patients, considering Khoe-San ancestry.
title: cis-eQTL mapping of TB-T2D comorbidity elucidates the involvement of African ancestry in TB susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs77247842 was tied to the expression of <italic>IFITM3</italic> in the same analysis context as rs55970487, under Khoe-San ancestry adjustments.
title: cis-eQTL mapping of TB-T2D comorbidity elucidates the involvement of African ancestry in TB susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs12282149 was associated with <italic>IFITM3</italic> expression, consistent with the findings from the analysis involving TB-T2D and T2D patients.
title: cis-eQTL mapping of TB-T2D comorbidity elucidates the involvement of African ancestry in TB susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs140324259 was found to be a significant pQTL for MUC5B on chromosome 11, explaining approximately 14% of the variation in sputum MUC5B concentrations. Interestingly, the C allele of this SNP was associated with an increased risk of chronic bronchitis (CB) and acute exacerbations (AE) in multiple analyses, despite correlating with lower MUC5B levels.
title: Genetic Regulators of Sputum Mucin Concentration and Their Associations with COPD Phenotypes

finding: The variant rs117458494 was previously associated with amyloid metabolism and was detected in the SPON1 locus, providing evidence of a potential recessive variant related to Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Its presence in a candidate ROH segment contributed to the overall findings suggesting enriched homozygosity in AD cases.
title: Autosomal Recessive Alzheimer’s disease (arAD): homozygosity mapping of genomic regions containing arAD loci

finding: The SNP rs10838698 was reported to show a significant association with SPI1 expression in monocytes and macrophages. In this study, it expanded the association of changes in SPI1 expression to both naive and induced monocytes, highlighting its significance as related to Alzheimer's disease risk through the regulation of myeloid and B-lymphoid cell development.
title: Monocyte-specific changes in gene expression implicate LACTB2 and PLIN2 in Alzheimer’s disease

finding: This finding was positive and original, indicating that rs34324219 caused changes in TCN1 RNA and protein expression in whole blood. It colocalized with pernicious anemia, a disorder due to vitamin B12 deficiency, and TCN1 encodes haptocorrin, a protein essential for vitamin B12 uptake.
title: Open Targets Genetics: An open approach to systematically prioritize causal variants and genes at all published human GWAS trait-associated loci

finding: The genetic variant rs35705950 was associated with higher expression of the soluble mucin MUC5B. It was found to be underrepresented in COVID-19 patients compared to healthy individuals, suggesting a protective role for MUC5B during the SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: The glycosylated extracellular domain of MUC1 protects against SARS-CoV-2 infection at the respiratory surface

finding: The study concluded that the MMP7 A-181G promoter SNP (rs11568818) was significantly associated with an increased risk of hypertension in two distinct Indian populations. The heterozygous A/G genotype showed a strong association with hypertension, which was evidenced by an odds ratio (OR) of 1.641 and a p-value of 1×10-4 in the south Indian population, and an OR of 1.520 in the north Indian population (p=0.01). The -181G allele exhibited greater promoter activity compared to the -181A allele, and carriers of the -181A/G genotype had elevated plasma MMP7 levels, which correlated positively with blood pressure.
title: A common tag nucleotide variant in MMP7 promoter increases risk for hypertension via enhanced interactions with CREB transcription factor

finding: The SNP rs11040570 was identified in the prognostic analysis of genetic alterations in elderly patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) by Heiblig et al. (2019). The findings underscored the relevance of this SNP in the context of genetic profiling and prognosis within AML.
title: NSC348884 cytotoxicity is not mediated by inhibition of nucleophosmin oligomerization

finding: The rs769874876 variant in the PAX6 gene was noted as a singleton PTV in gnomAD. Similar to rs139297920, it did not affect the most expressed transcript and was located within an exon that had no reported ClinVar pathogenic variants, despite 165 such variants reported elsewhere in the gene.
title: Harnessing population-specific protein truncating variants to improve the annotation of loss-of-function alleles

finding: This SNP was identified with potential susceptibility in the context of copper exposure and its link to Alzheimer’s disease.
title: Genetic variability in pathways associates with pesticide-induced nervous system disease in the United States

finding: Similar to rs1695, this SNP was found to potentially increase susceptibility to Alzheimer’s disease with copper exposure.
title: Genetic variability in pathways associates with pesticide-induced nervous system disease in the United States

finding: The rs1126809 variant in the TYR gene had an odds ratio of 1.27 and was heterozygous in families UF16, UF19, and UF21, further supporting its association with melanoma susceptibility.
title: A Weights-based variant ranking pipeline for familial complex disorders

finding: The SNP FADS1 rs174599 began increasing in frequency around 25,000 years ago but exhibited a stagnation in change for approximately 5,000 years from 15,000 years ago. This SNP was part of a family involved in fatty acid metabolism, with its evolutionary trajectory suggesting a link to dietary changes and agricultural practices.
title: Exploring the genetic diversity of the Japanese Population: Insights from a Large-Scale Whole Genome Sequencing Analysis

finding: RS174600, along with other SNPs in the FADS gene family, was noted for showing signals of positive selection related to diet. It contributes to fatty acid biosynthesis and exhibited evolutionary changes reflecting the dietary adaptations in East Asian populations.
title: Exploring the genetic diversity of the Japanese Population: Insights from a Large-Scale Whole Genome Sequencing Analysis

finding: Similar to other SNPs in the FADS family, rs174601 showed evidence of positive selection, suggesting its relevance in the adaptation of dietary changes, particularly those relating to fatty acid synthesis.
title: Exploring the genetic diversity of the Japanese Population: Insights from a Large-Scale Whole Genome Sequencing Analysis

finding: The SNP rs97384 was identified as a part of the FADS gene family that experienced positive natural selection signals. These signals were associated with dietary changes and have been linked to metabolism of fatty acids.
title: Exploring the genetic diversity of the Japanese Population: Insights from a Large-Scale Whole Genome Sequencing Analysis

finding: The SNP rs57535397 was also linked to the FADS gene family, which demonstrated positive natural selection, indicating its involvement in metabolic adaptations related to dietary changes.
title: Exploring the genetic diversity of the Japanese Population: Insights from a Large-Scale Whole Genome Sequencing Analysis

finding: Similar to other members of the FADS gene family, rs76996928 indicated positive natural selection correlated with dietary influences and lipid metabolism.
title: Exploring the genetic diversity of the Japanese Population: Insights from a Large-Scale Whole Genome Sequencing Analysis

finding: The SNP rs174594 was mentioned as part of a group of FADS SNPs that underwent positive selection related to dietary practices, particularly those that involve increasing the synthesis of long-chain fatty acids.
title: Exploring the genetic diversity of the Japanese Population: Insights from a Large-Scale Whole Genome Sequencing Analysis
