finding: The SNP rs11030414 was associated with colorectal cancer through its relationship with the FOXO3 gene, revealing insights into its mitochondrial role in the pathology. This finding emphasized the importance of mitochondrial functions related to genetic variations in cancer development.
title: Good host - bad host: molecular and evolutionary basis for survival, its failure, and virulence factors of the zoonotic nematode Anisakis pegreffii

finding: The variant rs115070172 was identified as a lead eQTL for the gene GSTP1, with the T allele present at a high frequency of 0.63 in the Peruvian population. It was found to be significantly associated with lower expression levels of GSTP1, a gene implicated in breast cancer. This finding suggested that regulatory mechanisms associated with this variant may contribute to population-specific expression differences.
title: Sources of gene expression variation in a globally diverse cohort

finding: The SNP rs4930437 was noted to be completely linked with rs115070172 and was located within a putative promoter region near an H3K27ac-enriched site, suggesting strong enhancer activity. It was included in the same credible causal set for the expression of GSTP1, reinforcing the hypothesis that this eQTL signal might explain the lower GSTP1 expression observed in the Peruvian population compared to other populations.
title: Sources of gene expression variation in a globally diverse cohort

finding: At the MUC5B locus, the rs35705950 variant was implicated in colocalizations with trans pQTLs for surfactant protein D (SFTPD) and other proteins, indicating a genetic connection to lung-related expression patterns.
title: Genetic regulation of the human plasma proteome in 54,306 UK Biobank participants

finding: The SNP rs1393350 (G/A) in the TYR gene was highlighted as a TIM linked to pigmentation traits. It showed increases or decreases in frequency over time, thus serving as a biomarker for specific historical periods.
title: A genomic dating tool for ancient genomes resolves the origins of hundreds of Eurasian genomes

finding: The SNP rs1042602 (A) in the TYR gene was associated with the absence of freckles and showed strong evidence of positive selection in European populations, underlining its importance in pigmentation traits.
title: A genomic dating tool for ancient genomes resolves the origins of hundreds of Eurasian genomes

finding: The SNP rs11020232 was reported in the context of developing a PD-L1 antibody drug conjugate which offered selective chemo-guided immune modulation of cancer. This highlighted the potential for using specific SNP-related strategies to optimize PD-L1-targeting in cancer therapies.
title: Light-controlled elimination of PD-L1+ cells

finding: The deletion variant rs61002819 in the splice region was also associated with T2DM, as shown by a significantly higher incidence of the disease in carriers of the deletion variant (G/G homozygote: 36.07%, G/- heterozygote: 38.64%, -/- homozygote: 47.37%). The odds ratio for T2DM was found to be 1.13 (95% CI = 1.04-1.05, P = 9.84×10^-4). Furthermore, the GUTT-ISI index demonstrated insulin insensitivity in G>-deletion carriers, reinforcing the link between this SNP and metabolic disturbances.
title: Pancreatic Brsk2 amplifies parasympathetic signals to promote type 2 diabetes

finding: The variant rs536028004, located in the 3 prime untranslated region (3' UTR) of the BRSK2 gene, was associated with T2DM, with T allele carriers displaying a higher incidence of the disease (CC homozygote: 36.38%, T allele carriers: 49.07%). After adjusting for age and sex, this SNP resulted in an odds ratio of 1.03 (95% CI = 1.01-1.06, P = 9.90×10^-3), highlighting its potential role in glucose intolerance and insulin resistance. The findings suggest that all three SNPs contribute to the pathogenesis of T2DM through their associations with altered glucose metabolism.
title: Pancreatic Brsk2 amplifies parasympathetic signals to promote type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs7111400 was associated with a significant XPEHH score of 4.2829, indicating it was a signal for Neanderthal introgression related to immunity in HM populations, located in the CNTN5 gene on chromosome 11.
title: Genomic insights into the population history and biological adaptation of Southwestern Chinese Hmong-Mien people

finding: The SNP rs11552366, associated with IFITM1, was identified as the most pathogenic missense SNP based on the analyses from several bioinformatics tools. It had harmful effects on the protein product according to at least four out of six tools used in the study.
title: Elucidation of the interactions between SARS-CoV-2 Spike protein and wild and mutant types of IFITM proteins by in silico methods

finding: The SNP rs200528039, also related to IFITM1, demonstrated harmful effects on the protein, being one of the 18 SNPs with a significant impact as determined by multiple analysis tools.
title: Elucidation of the interactions between SARS-CoV-2 Spike protein and wild and mutant types of IFITM proteins by in silico methods

finding: The SNP rs371179996, connected to IFITM2, was among the 18 SNPs identified to have deleterious impacts on the protein variants, supported by assessments from the employed pathogenicity prediction tools.
title: Elucidation of the interactions between SARS-CoV-2 Spike protein and wild and mutant types of IFITM proteins by in silico methods

finding: The study demonstrated a complete correlation between homozygosity at exon 1 and homozygosity at SNP rs85074, with all 5 tested recombinants showing this relationship. Additionally, there was a complete correlation where heterozygosity at exon 1 coincided with heterozygosity at this SNP, as seen in all 67 tested clones. This finding indicated that SNP rs85074 was a reliable marker for identifying recombination outcomes in the context of interhomolog recombination.
title: Donor-Free Gene Correction by Targeted Interhomolog Recombination

finding: Similar to SNP rs85074, the study reported complete correlation between homozygosity at exon 1 and homozygosity at SNP rs7950932, with all 4 tested recombinants confirming this relationship. Furthermore, heterozygosity at exon 1 corresponded with heterozygosity at this SNP in all 24 tested clones, indicating that SNP rs7950932 also served as a reliable genetic marker in the analysis of interhomolog recombination events.
title: Donor-Free Gene Correction by Targeted Interhomolog Recombination

finding: The SNP rs11020251 was associated with the overexpression of the FOXM1 gene in cancer. This SNP provided a significant connection to dysregulation pathways that may relate to FSHD, indicating its potential role in muscle pathology, although the direct effects on muscle cells were not explicitly detailed in the findings.
title: The myopathic transcription factor DUX4 induces the production of truncated RNA-binding proteins in human muscle cells

finding: The SNP rs11040468 was associated with differential effects in ROS production and distribution, which were linked to the varying impacts observed in X-ray and carbon ion irradiation on cancer stem cell migration and invasion. This finding suggested a genetic predisposition that could influence the response of cancer stem cells to radiation therapies, potentially affecting treatment outcomes in chondrosarcoma.
title: Functionalized mesoporous silica nanoparticles for innovative boron-neutron capture therapy of resistant cancers

finding: The SNP rs11226207 was associated with a significant alteration in PDGFD expression in human adipose tissues, as revealed by eQTL analysis in the GTEx database. The research illustrated that this SNP was situated within a conserved region of the PDGFD gene and played a role in the regulatory mechanisms influencing adipogenesis and hemostasis of adipocytes.
title: Genomic analysis of worldwide sheep breeds reveals PDGFD a major target of fat-tail selection in sheep

finding: The SNP rs7924558 was associated with expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) analysis, revealing a significant interaction between genotype and smoking status for the gene TDRD3, which is a chromatin remodeler. This finding indicated that the effects of smoking on the gene's expression varied depending on the genotype at rs7924558, specifically within lung tissues.
title: The molecular impact of cigarette smoking resembles aging across tissues

finding: The SNP rs35865896 was associated with splicing of exon 4 in the IRF7 gene, impacting lupus erythematosus risk. The analysis indicated that skipping exon 4 correlated with a reduced likelihood of developing lupus. Significant structural changes were predicted between isoforms, with notable implications for the DNA binding ability of IRF7.
title: The impact of genetically controlled splicing on exon inclusion and protein structure

finding: The IFITM3 rs12252 T>C polymorphism was found to be associated with an increased risk of severe influenza. This polymorphism potentially influenced the severity of influenza infections, possibly affecting immune responses.
title: Screening key genes and signaling pathways in COVID-19 infection and its associated complications by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: The IFITM3 gene SNP rs6598045 had a strong correlation with the COVID-19 case fatality rate at the population level, indicating its significance in infectious disease resilience.
title: Screening key genes and signaling pathways in COVID-19 infection and its associated complications by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: Variants near rs66505542 were reported to affect several cell phenotypes and linked with multiple traits including HDL, underscoring multi-phenotypic effects on lipids.
title: MetaPhat: Detecting and decomposing multivariate associations from univariate genome-wide association statistics

finding: The APOA1 variant rs964184, located within 100KB of rs66505542, had established links to TG, TC, HDL, and LDL, reinforcing its critical role in lipid profiles.
title: MetaPhat: Detecting and decomposing multivariate associations from univariate genome-wide association statistics

finding: Variants at rs174567 near FADS1/2 were shown to have wide associations across lipidomics traits, with previous reports linking it to various lipid traits and galstones.
title: MetaPhat: Detecting and decomposing multivariate associations from univariate genome-wide association statistics

finding: The variant rs10792832 was associated with the regulation of the gene PICALM in microglia and aligned with prior findings in literature linking this variant to AD risk.
title: Deconvolution of polygenic risk score in single cells unravels cellular and molecular heterogeneity of complex human diseases

finding: The SNP rs10488763 was demonstrated to influence coronary artery disease (CAD) risk by modulating FDX1 expression in macrophages. Specifically, the risk T allele of this SNP reduced FDX1 expression due to alterations in chromatin structure and transcription factor binding, particularly involving AP-1 and CEBPB.
title: Partitioning heritability using single-cell multi-omics identifies a novel macrophage subpopulation conveying genetic risks of coronary artery disease

finding: Linked with rs10488763 and residing in a distal CRE for FDX1 and RDX, rs1443120 was associated with increased CAD risk and lower expression of FDX1, underscoring its potential impact on atherogenesis.
title: Partitioning heritability using single-cell multi-omics identifies a novel macrophage subpopulation conveying genetic risks of coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs11020251 was linked to the regulation of FOXM1 expression. In the context of cancer, overexpression of FOXM1 has been associated with genomic features that contribute to tumor progression. The research highlighted in the paper by Barger et al. (2019) illustrated that variations at this locus could impact the oncogenic potential of FOXM1, thereby underlying its role in cancer biology.
title: BRD4 Prevents R-Loop Formation and Transcription-Replication Conflicts by Ensuring Efficient Transcription Elongation

finding: This SNP was linked to type 2 diabetes in East Asians with a minor negative association (beta=-0.139, p=5.07×10^-24), marking its relevance in metabolic traits.
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: This SNP was linked to hair color diversity among populations.
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: The SNP rs2237895 within KCNQ1 was associated with GDM specifically in Pakistani women. This discovery indicated a potential ethnic variation in genetic risk factors for GDM.
title: Genome-Wide Polygenic Risk Scores and Prediction of Gestational Diabetes in South Asian Women

finding: Associated with Alzheimer’s disease, indicating a regulatory role relevant to neurodegenerative pathways.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: The SNP rs2334499, located in the chromosome region 11p15, was shown to be protective against type II diabetes when transmitted maternally, while it conferred risk when inherited from the father. This finding highlighted the influence of parent-of-origin effects (POEs) on phenotypic expression.
title: A statistical method for joint estimation of cis-eQTLs and parent-of-orign effects using an orthogonal framework with RNA-seq data

finding: The lead variant rs61876335 was associated with the gene RNH1, located approximately 6 kb downstream of the gene. It was observed that the variant is not in linkage disequilibrium (r2 = 0.019) with the lead SNP for its isoform, rs17584, suggesting differential regulatory influences on gene expression and isoform usage.
title: Fine mapping spatiotemporal mechanisms of genetic variants underlying cardiac traits and disease

finding: The SNP rs17584 was identified as the lead variant for the isoform ENST00000397604.7_2 of the gene RNH1, which is a synonymous coding variant not associated with rs61876335, indicating diverse regulatory mechanisms could be at play affecting isoform usage in cardiac contexts.
title: Fine mapping spatiotemporal mechanisms of genetic variants underlying cardiac traits and disease

finding: This SNP was identified as one of the eQTLs for TMEM135, with an extremely strong associated GWAS signal in the published Alzheimer’s disease GWAS study.
title: Leveraging functional annotation to identify genes associated with complex diseases

finding: rs541458 was identified as an eQTL for TMEM135, and it also exhibited the strongest GWAS signal among the eQTLs identified by T-GEN, linking it to Alzheimer's disease etiology.
title: Leveraging functional annotation to identify genes associated with complex diseases

finding: The APOC3_rs76353203_R19X variant was associated with lower triglycerides and higher HDL cholesterol, providing cardioprotection. Additionally, this study reported the novel association of this variant with lower levels of phosphatidylethanolamines and several triglyceride species.
title: Leveraging a founder population to identify novel rare-population genetic determinants of lipidome

finding: The SNP rs534191 displayed a significant association with a reQTL in myeloid cells linked to COVID-19 severity through its impact on the MMP1 locus. Its strong effects were observed specifically in the context of SARS-CoV-2, as indicated by an extremely low p-value (1.96 x 10^-16).
title: Environmental and genetic drivers of population differences in SARS-CoV-2 immune responses

finding: This SNP is located within MS4A2, a gene implicated in Alzheimer's disease.
title: A Semi-Supervised Ensemble Approach to Rank Potential Causal Variants and Their Target Genes in Microglia for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs10437653 was associated with birth weight in European populations and was located within a genomic region showing overrepresentation in Caribbean and Puerto Rican populations.
title: Continental-scale genomic analysis suggests shared post-admixture adaptation in Americas

finding: This SNP was predicted to reside within an oligodendrocyte-specific regulatory element, 35-kb upstream of the PICALM gene. It was reported to disrupt a potential FOS/AP1 factor binding site, leading to diminished accessibility of the variant allele, reflecting its functional impact on gene expression.
title: Single-cell epigenomic identification of inherited risk loci in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease

finding: This SNP was identified to disrupt a microglia-specific CTCF binding motif, contributing to our understanding of the MS4A6A locus and its relationship to Alzheimer's disease.
title: Single-cell epigenomic identification of inherited risk loci in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs3087967 was found to be associated with malignant tumor of colon. This variant generated an ectopic consensus of upstream sequence element (USE) in the 3' UTR of the POU2AF2/C11orf53 gene, causing an increase in the gene's mRNA expression. The study provided evidence indicating that the risk variant associated with this SNP led to higher expression levels in zebrafish gut cells when tested in a transgenesis reporter assay. This finding suggested a potential mechanism by which rs3087967 might contribute to the development of colon cancer.
title: Unravelling the regulatory function of a short 3’UTR sequence in zebrafish and in human cells

finding: The variant rs931127 was associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and was found within an ATAC-seq peak in the infected macrophage enhancer gene regulatory network (eGRN). This SNP was linked to specific genes in the eGRN, indicating its regulatory role.
title: GRaNIE and GRaNPA: Inference and evaluation of enhancer-mediated gene regulatory networks applied to study macrophages

finding: The SNP rs1234988 was identified as a dynamic eQTL for the gene ARHGAP42, which is associated with hypertension as indicated by a prior GWAS (p=2.5e-35). The effect of this SNP on ARHGAP42 expression varied significantly over the differentiation process specifically in the cardiac fibroblast lineage (Bonferroni-adj. p=2.4e-5), and was not detected in the cardiomyocyte lineage (adj. p=0.79). This highlights the importance of analyzing lineage-specific effects in gene regulation during cellular differentiation.
title: Single-Cell Sequencing Reveals Lineage-Specific Dynamic Genetic Regulation of Gene Expression During Human Cardiomyocyte Differentiation

finding: The SNP rs174537 was identified as playing a role in perceived facial aging through its association with methylation differences affecting FADS activity. In the context of skin aging, it was found to be anti-correlated with the age-protective causal CpG, cg27386326. Variations in the FADS genes, which contribute to lipid content in skin surface lipids, indicated that rs174537 may impact skin barrier function and alter susceptibility to skin conditions.
title: Epigenetics Insights from Perceived Facial Aging

finding: The variant rs150090666 was recognized as a stop-gain variant in PDE3B and was linked to higher BMI, particularly showing a 0.647 kg/m² increase compared to average participants, with a strong association (p = 2.09 x 10^-4). This variant was also implicated in obesity-related phenotypes, emphasizing its significant genetic contribution to obesity.
title: Components of genetic associations across 2,138 phenotypes in the UK Biobank highlight novel adipocyte biology

finding: The C224T polymorphism rs17571 was correlated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, showing significant associations with oxidative and inflammatory markers in patients.
title: Identification of key genes and biological pathways in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The SNP rs174548, mapped to the FADS1 gene, was associated with asthma and exhibited the strongest effect on methylation at cg21709803 specifically in CD8+ T-cells. This suggested a potential role of rs174548 in asthma pathology through mechanisms of immune dysregulation and fatty acid metabolism involving methylation changes in CD8+ T-cells.
title: A hierarchical Bayesian interaction model to estimate cell-type-specific methylation quantitative trait loci incorporating priors from cell-sorted bisulfite sequencing data

finding: The SNP rs174587 was identified as a nearby risk variant impacting both methylation at cg21709803 in CD8+ T-cells and asthma. This finding extended previous results in the association between meQTLs and asthma, providing high replication confidence and linking genetic variation directly to complex trait expression in immune-related cells.
title: A hierarchical Bayesian interaction model to estimate cell-type-specific methylation quantitative trait loci incorporating priors from cell-sorted bisulfite sequencing data

finding: This SNP encodes haemoglobin C (HbC) and was included in the joint model for severe malaria (SM) and other pheno-subtypes, showing relevance in the context of malaria susceptibility.
title: New insights into malaria susceptibility from the genomes of 17,000 individuals from Africa, Asia, and Oceania

finding: The SNP rs779445843 led to missense mutations G95W/R in human populations. This mutation in IFITM3 resulted in a complete loss of antiviral activity, particularly reducing the protein's ability to restrict Influenza A Virus (IAV) infection and HIV-1 pseudovirus entry. The findings were significant as they suggested that glycine-95 was essential for the inhibitory function of IFITM3, linking this specific polymorphism to impaired virus restriction.
title: Homology-guided identification of a conserved motif linking the antiviral functions of IFITM3 to its oligomeric state

finding: The rs11568626 SNP, which leads to the p.Arg50His mutation, was associated with decreased transport affinities of phosphate analogues such as adefovir, cidofovir, and tenofovir when analyzed in Xenopus oocytes-expressing the p.Arg50His variant compared to the wild-type hOAT1 (rs15914676). However, normal uptake of PAH, ochratoxin A, and methotrexate was observed in this variant, indicating a specific impairment in transport functions.
title: Substrate binding and lipid-mediated allostery in the human organic anion transporter 1 at the atomic-scale

finding: The rs11568634 SNP resulted in the substitution of Arg454 by Gln, which was associated with decreased uptake of PAH, ochratoxin A, and methotrexate, indicating a loss of function. This finding aligned with structural observations suggesting that Arg454 plays a crucial role in the intracellular charge-relay system essential for the MFS transport cycle.
title: Substrate binding and lipid-mediated allostery in the human organic anion transporter 1 at the atomic-scale

finding: The SNP rs2074238 was associated (P=2×10^-129) with the KCNQ1 gene, contributing to the understanding of genetic factors influencing ECG morphology.
title: The genetic makeup of the electrocardiogram

finding: The SNP rs2168101 (G>T) was identified as a significant neuroblastoma-associated locus with a p-value of 3.18 x 10^-16 and an odds ratio of 0.70 (95% CI 0.65-0.76). It mapped to a conserved GATA3 binding site within the LMO1 super-enhancer (SE). The risk allele (G) maintained GATA3 binding, which promoted LMO1 expression, while the protective allele (T) disrupted GATA3 binding and was associated with lower LMO1 expression. Following ATRA treatment, a 70% loss of the LMO1 SE was observed after 4 days, and there was a 1.46-fold decrease in LMO1 mRNA, indicating that this SNP was crucial in regulating transcriptional activity linked to neuroblastoma tumorigenesis.
title: Lineage specific transcription factor waves reprogram neuroblastoma from self-renewal to differentiation

finding: This SNP (rs7949874) was linked to the PHF-tau measurement phenotype with a notable p-value of 3E-8, indicating its association with tau pathology related to cognitive functions.
title: Systems genetics identifies the association between Enc1 and cognitive function in the hippocampus

finding: The variant rs4929965, situated near the INS gene on chromosome 11p15.5, showed that the minor A allele was associated with susceptibility to type 2 diabetes (OR=1.07, p=4.80×10^-25) while providing protection against type 1 diabetes (OR=0.87, p=1.89×10^-5), thereby demonstrating colocalisation with opposite directions of effect.
title: Divergent genetic effects for type 1 and type 2 diabetes at overlapping association signals

finding: The SNP rs6265, known as Val66Met, was highlighted as a widely studied single nucleotide polymorphism within the prodomain of the BDNF gene. The context of this finding pertained to its disease relevance, particularly as it is linked to numerous neuropsychiatric disorders. This variant showed that the prodomain, which is more prone to change than the mature domain, carries significant implications for the regulation and functionality of BDNF, influencing brain circuits and behavior.
title: The evolution of BDNF is defined by strict purifying selection and prodomain spatial coevolution, but what does it mean for human brain disease?

finding: The variant rs34704828 was identified as a known pathological variant associated with creating an upstream AUG (uAUG) in the 5' untranslated region of the gene HBB, which is linked to beta-thalassemia. The model demonstrated that the addition of this variant significantly influenced the predicted ribosome load by altering the context around the new AUG. This finding highlighted the variant's strong regulatory impact on translation, which indicates its relevance in pathological conditions.
title: Predicting Mean Ribosome Load for 5’UTR of any length using Deep Learning

finding: The SNP rs12790261 was found associated with the gene KDM2A and had a PrCa p-value of 1e-7, suggesting its potential involvement in prostate cancer biology.
title: The PENGUIN approach to reconstruct protein interactions at enhancer-promoter regions and its application to prostate cancer

finding: The SNP rs12628 in the HRAS gene was associated with an increased risk of melanoma in the North American population. This finding suggested a potential genetic predisposition to cancer related to HRAS.
title: Network Pharmacology Analysis of the active components and anticancer targets of Rhubarb

finding: This SNP served as a tag SNP in the PRS and was referenced for its relevance in colorectal cancer assessment, particularly concerning adenoma count.
title: Ability of known colorectal cancer susceptibility SNPs to predict colorectal cancer risk: A cohort study within the UK Biobank

finding: As an intronic variant of CYP2R1, this SNP was involved in vitamin D levels, but MR Corge estimates indicated no causal relationship with CAD.
title: MR Corge: Sensitivity analysis of Mendelian randomization based on the core gene hypothesis for polygenic exposures

finding: This intergenic variant near DHCR7 was linked to vitamin D levels; however, MR Corge suggested no causative relationship with CAD.
title: MR Corge: Sensitivity analysis of Mendelian randomization based on the core gene hypothesis for polygenic exposures

finding: The SNP rs948854 was implicated in depressive symptoms in adolescents, indicating a genetic association that suggests the galanin gene plays a role in modulating emotional responses, aligning with the findings of the importance of galanin signaling in neuropsychiatric diseases as indicated in the study with the <italic>Gal<sup>cKO-Dbh</sup></italic> mouse model.
title: Elimination of galanin synthesis in noradrenergic neurons reduces galanin in select brain areas and promotes active coping behaviors

finding: Situated in the promoter of BAD, this variant was shown to regulate BAD expression and significantly affected GPR137 and PYGM, suggesting its role in T cell apoptosis and development.
title: Linking candidate causal autoimmune variants to T cell networks using genetic and epigenetic screens in primary human T cells

finding: This variant was located in an intergenic region affecting SESN3 expression, which plays a role in regulating oxidative stress, though its specific function in T cells was not established.
title: Linking candidate causal autoimmune variants to T cell networks using genetic and epigenetic screens in primary human T cells

finding: This variant was found to significantly impact ETS1 expression, a transcription factor central to T cell survival and regulatory function, linking it to autoimmune disease outcomes.
title: Linking candidate causal autoimmune variants to T cell networks using genetic and epigenetic screens in primary human T cells

finding: The SNP rs12252, a genetic variant associated with the Interferon-Induced Transmembrane Protein 3 (IFITM3), was linked to increased disease severity in COVID-19 patients, indicating its role in modulating immune responses. This finding relates to immune system dynamics during infections, aligning with the identified role of Type I interferon (IFN-I) in phagocytic functions of microglia and brain development, as described in the context.
title: Type I interferon responsive microglia shape cortical development and behavior

finding: The rs11568818 polymorphism was associated with MMP-7 expression at an extra-articular site, showing a potential link to inflammatory processes in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.
title: C-terminal truncation of CXCL10 attenuates inflammatory activity but retains angiostatic properties

finding: The SNP rs2075291, which involved a genetic variant c.553G > T in the apolipoprotein A5 gene, was associated with altered triglyceride levels in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) who were receiving lipid-lowering drugs. This finding significantly contributed to understanding the genetic influences on lipid metabolism in CAD patients.
title: Genomic Insights of Bruneian Malays

finding: SNP rs964184 demonstrated significant ME for multiple traits including Apolipoprotein B, cholesterol, and triglycerides. It is located in the 3' UTR of the ZPR1 gene, which encodes a regulatory zinc finger protein. This variant had substantial ME effects and has been associated with lipid levels, showing involvement in insulin sensitivity and metabolic processes. Moreover, rs964184 was indicated as a cis-eQTL for several genes and had mediating effects on HDL-C and triglycerides through its associations.
title: A biobank-scale test of marginal epistasis reveals genome-wide signals of polygenic epistasis

finding: The SNP rs11235604, a missense variant (p.R220W) of the autophagy-related gene ATG16L2, was associated with coronary artery disease. This finding was significant due to its linkage with novel signals in a genome-wide association study involving a Japanese population.
title: Large scale genome-wide association study in a Japanese population identified 45 novel susceptibility loci for 22 diseases

finding: The variant rs11349741 in the FSHB/ARL14EP locus was significant in the analysis of regulatory elements and additionally showed colocalization with eQTLs in adrenal and ovarian tissues. This demonstrated its association with PCOS risk.
title: Gene regulatory activity associated with PCOS revealed DENND1A-dependent testosterone production

finding: The SNP rs2237895 in the KCNQ1 gene was reported to be associated with type 2 diabetes. Specifically, the minor allele of this SNP correlated with reduced insulin release following an oral glucose load, indicating a potential impact on glucose metabolism and insulin secretion mechanisms in diabetic patients.
title: An Activator Locks Kv7.1 Channels Open by Electro-Mechanical Uncoupling and Allosterically Modulates its Pore

finding: The BDNF Val66Met (rs6265) polymorphism also impacted local oscillation amplitudes and LRTCs, with significant effects noted on large-scale synchronization. This polymorphism was established to influence serotonin levels and to impact various behavioral and cognitive aspects, emphasizing its role in the maintenance and formation of neuronal networks.
title: Genetic polymorphisms in COMT and BDNF influence synchronization dynamics of human neuronal oscillations

finding: The SNP rs75393320 in the ACP2 gene was connected to increased levels of HDL cholesterol, often referred to as 'good cholesterol.' This SNP's analysis offered insights into genetic influences on cardiovascular health.
title: Fast and accurate estimation of selection coefficients and allele histories from ancient and modern DNA

finding: Another significant SNP, rs11039471, located intronic to the PTPRJ gene, showed a strong association with nightmares (p=3.7e-8). The locus related to rs11039471 had previously been implicated in regulating sleep traits, suggesting a broader role in disturbed sleep, including nightmares.
title: Nightmares share strong genetic risk with sleep and psychiatric disorders

finding: Linked to BAD, the eQTL was specific to treated CD8+ T cells and showed strong colocalization with a Crohn's disease GWAS locus, highlighting its role in T cell apoptosis and response to immunotherapy.
title: Systemic CD8+ T cell effector signature predicts prognosis of lung cancer immunotherapy

finding: This SNP showed significant colocalization with a Crohn's disease GWAS locus, suggesting its involvement in immune-related pathways and potentially affecting immune cell dynamics during therapeutic interventions.
title: Systemic CD8+ T cell effector signature predicts prognosis of lung cancer immunotherapy

finding: The SNP rs12252-C was associated with severe influenza in Chinese individuals, indicating that this genetic variant related to the interferon-induced transmembrane protein 3 (IFITM3) influences the severity of influenza virus infections. This finding is significant as it correlates with the observed cardiac dysfunction in the context of severe influenza virus infection, highlighting the importance of IFITM3 in pathogen susceptibility and disease severity.
title: Influenza virus replication in cardiomyocytes drives heart dysfunction and fibrosis

finding: The SNP rs217727 was analyzed for its influence on the secondary structure of the human lncRNA BIGHEART. The SHAPE-seq technique was successfully applied to both the wildtype and the minor allele of this SNP, yielding substantial data that contributed to the structure prediction of BIGHEART. This analysis highlighted the relevance of the SNP in understanding the molecular biology of heart failure, corroborating the findings that specific genetic variations can play significant roles in gene regulatory circuits relevant to myocardial remodeling.
title: LncRNA Bigheart trans-activates gene expression in a feed forward mechanism that facilitates calcineurin-NFAT signaling in myocardial hypertrophy

finding: The analysis highlighted that the genetic variant rs11604261 altered the expression of diacylglycerol lipase alpha (DAGLα) in the brain. This variation in expression levels suggested a potential correlation with susceptibility to alcohol use disorder (AUD) and could serve as a biomarker for predicting an individual's responsiveness to pharmacological inhibition of DAGL. The context emphasized that understanding this genetic variation could contribute to developing tailored treatment strategies for reducing alcohol consumption.
title: Targeting Diacylglycerol Lipase to Reduce Alcohol Consumption

finding: The SNP rs1806153 was identified as a functional variant related to major depressive disorder (MDD) and was previously defined as a 'conditional SNP' in association analyses. The findings support models that predict the existence of multiple functional SNPs within GWAS loci.
title: Transcriptional-Regulatory Convergence Across Functional MDD Risk Variants Identified by Massively Parallel Reporter Assays

finding: SNP rs489591 was recognized for its role in disrupting RXRA motifs, indicating its significance in the context of retinoid receptor TF binding sites under retinoid treatment conditions.
title: Transcriptional-Regulatory Convergence Across Functional MDD Risk Variants Identified by Massively Parallel Reporter Assays

finding: This SNP was identified as a lead MDD sSNP from a GWAS meta-analysis. It overlapped with ExN1 marker cCRE in the intronic region of the SPTBN2 gene and disrupted the TF binding site for RFX3. The motif accessibility for RFX3 was altered in both ExN1 candidate DARs and at the single-cell level in individuals with MDD. RFX3 motifs were also enriched in ExN1 cCREs that are located within heritable LD regions associated with MDD and linked to neuropsychiatric disorders.
title: Differential Chromatin Architecture and Risk Variants in Deep Layer Excitatory Neurons and Grey Matter Microglia Contribute to Major Depressive Disorder

finding: This SNP was associated with the SHANK2 gene, disrupting the binding site accessibility for the GLI2 transcription factor. It overlapped with an ExN1 marker cCRE and significantly correlated with the expression of anti-sense RNA of SHANK2, a protein known to be linked to postsynaptic density and neuropsychiatric disorders. The correlation coefficient was reported as 0.6.
title: Differential Chromatin Architecture and Risk Variants in Deep Layer Excitatory Neurons and Grey Matter Microglia Contribute to Major Depressive Disorder

finding: The SNP rs3842753 was associated with increased beta-cell INS messenger RNA levels in a meta-analysis of single-cell RNA-sequencing data. This finding was significant as it provided insights into potential mechanisms underlying type 1 diabetes risk, suggesting that alleles at this locus could modulate insulin expression and potentially contribute to the pathogenesis of diabetes.
title: Sex differences in islet stress responses support female beta cell resilience

finding: The SNP rs11040587 was associated with glioblastoma (GBM) and was characterized as having implications in regulating cell migration, proliferation, and survival of glioblastoma cells. The study highlighted its role in the context of integrin alpha-10 as a novel therapeutic target in GBM, underscoring the importance of genetic factors in the aggressive behavior of glioblastoma cells.
title: Glioblastoma cells use an integrin- and CD44-mediated motor-clutch mode of migration in brain tissue

finding: This variant scored highest among others in its risk locus, including GWAS SNP rs77502336, marking it as a significant finding.
title: WEVar: a novel statistical learning framework for predicting noncoding regulatory variants

finding: The SNP rs163184 in the KCNQ1 gene was associated with type 2 diabetes. This SNP suggested an influence on the binding activity of transcription factors Sp3 and Lsd1/Kdm1a, which could result in altered expression of CDKN1C. Thus, it was related to the regulatory mechanisms underlying ß-cell dysfunction in diabetes.
title: AFF3 and BACH2 are master regulators of metabolic inflexibility, β/α-cell transition, and dedifferentiation in type 2 diabetes

finding: The G-allele of rs2513280 was associated with increased alcohol consumption in women based on a large UK Biobank cohort of 345,140 individuals. This association showed statistical significance with a p-value of 0.0463. In contrast, the association was non-significant in men, highlighting a greater impact of the gene variant in the female population.
title: CRISPR disruption and UK Biobank analysis of a highly conserved polymorphic enhancer suggests a role in male anxiety and ethanol intake

finding: This SNP was successfully replicated in the context of CTSW and showed significant associations in the specified immune cell types within the larger study.
title: Genetic variants associated with cell-type-specific intra-individual gene expression variability reveal new mechanisms of genome regulation

finding: The SNP rs12807809 was associated with schizophrenia risk in a neuropsychological investigation. The study examined the impact of this variant on cognitive functions relevant to the disease's phenotypes, linking it to impaired cortical plasticity. Specific expression alterations related to this SNP were correlated with deficits in long-term potentiation (LTP) and depression (LTD), suggesting its involvement in the genetic mechanisms underlying plasticity impairments observed in schizophrenia.
title: Genetic mechanisms for impaired synaptic plasticity in schizophrenia revealed by computational modelling

finding: The SNP rs34481144 in the IFITM3 gene was associated with loss-of-function mutations leading to severe outcomes following Influenza A virus infection and severe COVID-19. Evidence indicated that individuals with this SNP exhibited less effective antiviral responses, implicating a role for IFITM3 in controlling virus spread and systemic pathology during infection.
title: Rapalogs downmodulate intrinsic immunity and promote cell entry of SARS-CoV-2

finding: The SNP rs12252, also within the IFITM3 gene, was similarly linked to severe COVID-19 outcomes, particularly through loss-of-function effects. This variant contributed to impaired interferon response and reduced antiviral activity, supporting the notion that effective cell-intrinsic immunity in airways was crucial for managing SARS-CoV-2 and Influenza infections.
title: Rapalogs downmodulate intrinsic immunity and promote cell entry of SARS-CoV-2

finding: The SNP rs174549 in the FADS1 gene was reported to have a potential predictive value for a favorable response to chemoradiotherapy, specifically in the context of oral cancer patients. This original finding suggested that this polymorphism may play a role in treatment outcomes, indicating its relevance in cancer management.
title: Identification of Key Genes Potentially Related to Triple Receptor Negative Breast Cancer by Microarray Analysis

finding: The SNP rs10830963 at the MTNR1B locus was found to have a robust temporal association with glucose levels, achieving a P-value of 1e-22. This SNP influenced insulin secretion and was shown to be associated with elevated fasting glucose levels, contributing to an increased risk of type 2 diabetes (T2DM). Analyses also demonstrated that the effect of the risk allele G on glucose levels was higher in the morning compared to the evening. These findings were replicated in the Estonian Biobank, further supporting the association of rs10830963 with diurnal glucose regulation.
title: Genetic variants affect diurnal glucose levels throughout the day

finding: The SNP rs12419690 at the CRY2 locus demonstrated a significant temporal association with glucose levels, with a P-value of 1e-16. Similar to MTNR1B, it was associated with altering glucose levels throughout the day, showing opposite associations in the morning and evening. The effect of the CRY2 risk allele A was associated with lower glucose levels in the morning but higher levels in the evening. This finding was also replicated in the Estonian Biobank, highlighting the role of rs12419690 in glucose metabolism and its diurnal variability.
title: Genetic variants affect diurnal glucose levels throughout the day

finding: The SNP rs4938344 was identified as an eQTL regulating the long non-coding RNA AP000892.6. The reference allele G led to decreased expression of AP000892.6 as measured in GTEx and in caffeine conditions during testing. High expression of AP000892.6 was associated with a decreased risk of hypertension and coronary artery disease (CAD). Furthermore, the SNP was predicted to influence the binding of transcription factors GABP and ETV1, which were upregulated in caffeine-exposed endothelial cells. This increased expression of these factors resulted in lower activity at the rs4938344 locus in response to caffeine, thereby leading to lower expression of AP000892.6 and an increased risk for CAD and hypertension.
title: Characterization of caffeine response regulatory variants in vascular endothelial cells

finding: Analysis of rs10833823, another basal SNP-eQTL in myeloid cells, indicated that while all tested cofactors were recruited to the reference allele, the SNP allele significantly enhanced recruitment for specific cofactors such as TBL1XR1 and GCN5. This SNP did not affect transcription factor PU.1 binding but was linked to altered cofactor recruitment.
title: Customizable high-throughput platform for profiling cofactor recruitment to DNA to characterize cis-regulatory elements and screen non-coding single-nucleotide polymorphisms

finding: The SNP rs11040529 was found to modulate MIF levels, and its association with melanoma patient data highlighted the potential for MIF-targeted therapies in improving responses to immune treatments.
title: Temporal genomic analysis of melanoma rejection identifies regulators of tumor immune evasion

finding: The DRD2/ANKK1 TaqIA A1 allele (rs1800497) was positively associated with diminished learning performance in tasks requiring response inhibition to obtain rewards, as previously observed in two independent cohorts and replicated in a third cohort of 99 participants. This finding indicated the influence of the A1 allele on striatal dopamine D2 receptor expression and its impact on motivated behavior.
title: Motivational learning biases are differentially modulated by genetic determinants of striatal and prefrontal dopamine function

finding: The SNP rs3842770 located in the INS-IGF2 region demonstrated exact replication with a p-value of 1.867 x 10^-3, confirming its association with T2D in the studied cohort.
title: A Novel Type 2 Diabetes Locus in sub-Saharan Africans, ZRANB3, is Implicated in Beta Cell Proliferation

finding: The SNP rs4072825 was found to have genome-wide significance in the African ancestry meta-analysis for T2D with a p-value of 2.35 x 10^-8.
title: A Novel Type 2 Diabetes Locus in sub-Saharan Africans, ZRANB3, is Implicated in Beta Cell Proliferation

finding: The rs11042811 SNP was associated with increased expression of AMPD3, suggesting a role for oligodendrocytes in white matter microstructure.
title: Brain expression quantitative trait locus and network analysis reveals downstream effects and putative drivers for brain-related diseases

finding: The rs2303865 SNP was associated with increased expression of CD82, indicating involvement in the oligodendrocyte pathway affecting white matter.
title: Brain expression quantitative trait locus and network analysis reveals downstream effects and putative drivers for brain-related diseases

finding: ZNF148 displayed differential binding to the major SNP of rs509813 when assays were performed using HeLa nuclear extracts. This binding confirmed ZNF148's role as a transcription factor that potentially regulates TERT expression, supporting earlier findings of its allele-specific binding.
title: E4F1 and ZNF148 are transcriptional activators of the A57C and wildtype TERT promoter

finding: The rs1131488 variant was found to be involved with the HMBS gene and was linked to thalamus anomalies. Mutations in HMBS are implicated in acute intermittent porphyria, which correlates with MRI anomalies.
title: Phenotypic and genetic associations of quantitative magnetic susceptibility in UK Biobank brain imaging

finding: The SNP rs5006884, associated with the gene OR51B6, was identified as having the strongest signals in African, American, and European populations. It is known to be linked to fetal hemoglobin (HbF) levels in sickle cell anemia, exemplifying the role of balancing selection in diseases.
title: Improved detection of evolutionary selection highlights potential bias from different sequencing strategies in complex genomic-regions

finding: The finding related to rs12275749 showed that the Alt protective allele disrupted the SMAD3 binding motif at the CCND1 locus, which was associated with reduced cell growth in the context of the TGFβ-SMAD3 axis affecting mammosphere-initiating cells in MCF7 breast cancer cells.
title: High throughput PRIME editing screens identify functional DNA variants in the human genome

finding: The investigation indicated that the Alt allele (protective allele) of rs12275479 at the CCND1 locus disrupted the SMAD3 binding motif, consistent with a role in decreasing cell growth in the context of breast cancer by impacting signaling pathways.
title: High throughput PRIME editing screens identify functional DNA variants in the human genome

finding: SIA detected a moderate signal of selection at the TYR locus with a selection probability of 0.62 and a selection coefficient approximately equal to 0.0011, indicating its connection to pigmentation.
title: SIA: Selection Inference Using the Ancestral Recombination Graph

finding: The rs5219 SNP in the KCNJ11 gene was associated with an increased risk of T2DM, indicating its potential involvement in insulin secretion and beta-cell function.
title: Bioinformatics analysis of potential key genes and mechanisms in type 2 diabetes mellitus

finding: The rs1042602(A) allele in the TYR locus was linked to pigmentation and showed evidence of recent selection in Western Eurasian history. The analysis indicated an origin for this allele with a robust selection coefficient, which decreased after 5,000 years ago. This entitlement aligns with existing literature, reinforcing its importance in understanding pigmentation-related adaptations within this geographic context.
title: Modelling the spatiotemporal spread of beneficial alleles using ancient genomes

finding: In the research by Franceschini et al., rs11030224 was implicated in enhancing the feasibility of unmanned aerial vehicle optical imagery for the early detection and severity assessment of late blight in potato crops.
title: Automatic late blight lesion recognition and severity quantification based on field imagery of diverse potato genotypes by deep learning

finding: The SNP rs1453541 (M263T) was associated with the intensity perception of Galaxolide in both discovery (p<2.07×10^-25) and validation studies (p<9.08×10^-6). This finding contributed to a novel association with the musk Galaxolide.
title: From musk to body odor: decoding olfaction through genetic variation

finding: The SNP rs1453542 (S151T) was confirmed to associate with the Galaxolide perception intensity in the same manner as rs1453541, with discovery p<2.59×10^-25 and validation p<1.02×10^-5.
title: From musk to body odor: decoding olfaction through genetic variation

finding: The SNP rs3898917 was found to correlate with the intensity of perception for trans-3-methyl-2-hexenoic acid (3M2H), showing a significant association in the discovery study (p<1.20×10^-11) and validated at a lesser significance (p<7.89×10^-5).
title: From musk to body odor: decoding olfaction through genetic variation

finding: The SNP rs6591536 (D183N) was replicated in both discovery (p<1.84×10^-41) and validation cohorts (high p<7.80×10^-39), demonstrating a robust association with the intensity perception of β-ionone.
title: From musk to body odor: decoding olfaction through genetic variation

finding: Similar to rs591536, rs7941591 was confirmed to be significantly associated with Galaxolide perception intensity in the validation study (p<5.8×10^-6).
title: From musk to body odor: decoding olfaction through genetic variation

finding: The SNP rs10837814 (L134F), associated with 3M2H intensity perception, reached significant findings in both discovery (p<6.57×10^-10) and validation (p<9.60×10^-8) studies.
title: From musk to body odor: decoding olfaction through genetic variation

finding: The SNP rs636317 was identified near the MS4A locus and was reported to show allelic imbalance on overlapping ATAC-seq peaks in myeloid cells. It displayed a strong predicted effect on regulatory activity from both the monocyte and microglia models, suggesting a role in AD predisposition by disrupting a CTCF transcription factor binding site.
title: Regression convolutional neural network models implicate peripheral immune regulatory variants in the predisposition to Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The research found that the common BDNF Val66Met single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP; rs6265) was implicated in persistent changes of synaptic function following exposure to isoflurane in mice. Specifically, carriers of the variant exhibited reduced exocytosis of glutamate synaptic vesicles, contributing to transient depression of excitatory synaptic transmission, which was irreversible in neurons with diminished BDNF release due to this polymorphism. Additionally, this SNP was linked to reduced hippocampal volume and impaired hippocampus-dependent learning and memory, indicating its importance in neurocognitive function.
title: A common human brain-derived neurotrophic factor polymorphism leads to sustained depression of excitatory synaptic transmission by isoflurane in hippocampus

finding: The SNP rs3740688 was associated with a significant genic association to Alzheimer's Disease (AD) as reported in the IGAP GWAS, with an odds ratio of 0.92 and a meta p-value of 5.4 x10^-13. This study included 35,274 AD cases and 59,163 controls, confirming the variant's role in modifying the risk of developing AD.
title: Modest changes in Spi1 dosage reveal the potential for altered microglial function as seen in Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP variant rs1057233 was implicated in resulting in a higher level of SPI1 expression, which correlated with an earlier age of onset for Alzheimer's Disease (AD). This finding suggested a direct link between SPI1 expression levels influenced by the SNP and AD onset timing.
title: Modest changes in Spi1 dosage reveal the potential for altered microglial function as seen in Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The association of SNP rs6589566 with triglycerides (TG) was noted, with a significant p-value of 3.98 × 10−18, indicating its important role in lipid metabolism among Samoans.
title: Genome-wide association studies in Samoans give insight into the genetic architecture of fasting serum lipid levels.

finding: SNP rs3741298 was associated with total cholesterol (TC) in the Samoan cohort, showing a significant p-value of 1.63 × 10−7, linking it to lipid levels in this unique population.
title: Genome-wide association studies in Samoans give insight into the genetic architecture of fasting serum lipid levels.

finding: The SNP rs964184 near APOA1 was found to have an association with total cholesterol (TC) and demonstrated a marked difference in effect allele frequency between Samoans and other populations, presenting a value of 0.440 compared to < 0.277 in 1000 Genomes populations.
title: Genome-wide association studies in Samoans give insight into the genetic architecture of fasting serum lipid levels.

finding: The study found that the Val66Met SNP (rs6265) significantly affected baseline levels of BDNF in individuals. Specifically, those carrying the Val allele had higher baseline BDNF levels compared to Met allele carriers. This SNP was linked to differences in neuroplasticity and cognitive performance, with implications for auditory processing enhancements observed in musically trained individuals. The findings support the hypothesis that genetic variations in the BDNF gene can influence auditory cortical adaptations resulting from long-term musical training.
title: BDNF Val66Met polymorphism as putative genetic substrate of music-induced plasticity in auditory prediction

finding: The SNP rs1061810 was found to have a negative expression effect on HSD17B12 in all twelve tissues investigated. This gene is involved in fatty acid synthesis, indicating a potential role in metabolic dysregulation associated with T2D.
title: Understanding functional consequences of type 2 diabetes risk loci using the universal data integration and visualization R package CONQUER

finding: The rs61742524 SNP was linked to a missense mutation (Cys3Trp) that may have clinical relevance as it was found in three out of 330 females with polyspermy but not in any of 300 matching controls in a study involving in-vitro fertilization. Its frequency in the AFR population was noted to be 26%, with a lower prevalence in females compared to the overall population, suggesting potential impaired fertility.
title: Genetic Diversity in the IZUMO1-JUNO Protein-Receptor Pair Involved in Human Reproduction

finding: The rs174583 polymorphism in the FADS2 gene was found to affect desaturase activities, fatty acid profile, insulin resistance, biochemical indices, and the incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), confirming its relevance to metabolic processes involved in the disorder.
title: Analysis of key genes and pathways associated with the pathogenesis of Type 2 diabetes mellitus

finding: The SNP rs10792832 was identified as a lead colocalised SNP linking microglial-specific cis-eQTLs with Alzheimer's disease (AD). It was shown to overlap a microglial-specific enhancer and was connected to the PICALM promoter via a PLAC-seq loop, indicating it played a significant role in regulating PICALM expression in the context of AD.
title: Single-cell Mendelian randomisation identifies cell-type specific genetic effects on human brain disease and behaviour

finding: The SNP rs2232950 was identified as a common missense variant within the SCGB1D2 gene that leads to a proline to leucine substitution at position 53 (Pro53Leu). This variant was shown to be deleterious based on SIFT and PolyPhen predictions. It had a significant association with Lyme disease with a P-value of 1.82×10^(-24) and an alternative allele frequency of 40%. The study indicated that this variant impaired the anti-Borrelia activity of the SCGB1D2 protein, providing insights into the host defense mechanisms against Lyme disease.
title: Secretoglobin family 1D member 2 (SCGB1D2) protein inhibits growth of Borrelia burgdorferi and affects susceptibility to Lyme disease

finding: The SNP rs4110197 was found to be the lead variant in a significant association with Lyme disease, with a P-value of 2.95×10^(-25). It is categorized as an intronic variant within the SCGB1D2 gene. Further finemapping indicated that the causal variant is likely one of a set of eight SNPs in high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs2232950, suggesting its potential importance in modulating the susceptibility to Lyme disease through effects on the SCGB1D2 protein.
title: Secretoglobin family 1D member 2 (SCGB1D2) protein inhibits growth of Borrelia burgdorferi and affects susceptibility to Lyme disease

finding: The SNP rs10742814 was linked to the DrinksPerWeek trait and also demonstrated predicted cell type-specific activity in MSNs, qualifying it as a potential causal SNP related to addiction.
title: Addiction-associated genetic variants implicate brain cell type- and region-specific cis-regulatory elements in addiction neurobiology

finding: The SNP rs2773516 was associated with heteroplasmic burden in European Americans (EAs), exhibiting a low p-value of 7.1E-10 and explaining 1.3% of the variability in heteroplasmy burden.
title: Presence and Transmission of Mitochondrial Heteroplasmic Mutations in Human Populations of European and African Ancestry

finding: The SNP rs36145545 showed a significant association with heteroplasmic burden in African Americans (AAs), with a p-value of 9.4E-11, explaining 1.2% of the variability in heteroplasmy burden.
title: Presence and Transmission of Mitochondrial Heteroplasmic Mutations in Human Populations of European and African Ancestry

finding: The SNP rs779031139 was identified through meta-analysis of European and African American cohorts, showing the strongest association with heteroplasmic burden at a p-value of 2.0e-18, contributing to 3.5% variability in EAs and 3.6% in AAs.
title: Presence and Transmission of Mitochondrial Heteroplasmic Mutations in Human Populations of European and African Ancestry

finding: The SNP rs174557 was identified as being bound by the PATZ1 protein, which down-regulated the expression of the fatty acid desaturase gene FADS1. This relationship highlighted the role of PATZ1 in regulating adipogenesis, as its activity was influenced by interactions with other transcription factors such as SP1 and SREBP1c. The finding was significant in the context of fat metabolism and obesity, reinforcing the role of PATZ1 as a key regulator in adipocyte differentiation.
title: Transcriptional control of adipogenesis by PATZ1

finding: SNP rs10835638 was identified in the indeterminate cases and had a meta-analysis P-value of 4.94×10^-12 associated with the FSHB locus, confirming the previous findings from the original GWAS.
title: Phenotypic clustering reveals distinct subtypes of polycystic ovary syndrome with novel genetic associations

finding: The SNP rs10835646 was also significantly associated with indeterminate cases (P=2.75×10^-11) in the FSHB locus and showed consistency with previously reported associations.
title: Phenotypic clustering reveals distinct subtypes of polycystic ovary syndrome with novel genetic associations

finding: The lead SNP rs11031006 showed an association in the indeterminate subgroup with a P-value of 2.96×10^-10, confirming prior findings in earlier GWAS studies.
title: Phenotypic clustering reveals distinct subtypes of polycystic ovary syndrome with novel genetic associations

finding: SNP rs11031005 was associated with the indeterminate subgroup of cases with a P-value of 2.91×10^-10, consistent with earlier observed associations.
title: Phenotypic clustering reveals distinct subtypes of polycystic ovary syndrome with novel genetic associations

finding: The SNP rs112369934 on chromosome 11 near the TRIM66 gene was identified as a novel locus associated with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) in an African American population where it reached genome-wide significance with a p-value of 2.01 x 10^-8 and an adjusted odds ratio of 1.67. This finding contributed to understanding the genetic basis of POAG and involved genes related to trabecular meshwork homeostasis and retinal ganglion cell maintenance.
title: Genome wide-association study identifies novel loci in the Primary Open-Angle African American Glaucoma Genetics (POAAGG) study

finding: At the KCNQ1 locus, the causal T2D variant rs231361 had predicted effects on an enhancer with beta cell-specific co-accessibility to the insulin promoter. The deletion of this enhancer in human embryonic stem cell-derived beta cells significantly reduced insulin gene and protein expression, providing strong evidence of its role in T2D risk.
title: Single cell chromatin accessibility reveals pancreatic islet cell type- and state-specific regulatory programs of diabetes risk

finding: SNP rs117863556 was identified as disrupting the binding of transcription factor REST to the gene GAB2 specifically in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. This finding contributes to understanding disease mechanisms unique to AD and the intricate gene regulatory networks.
title: Integrative analysis of multi-omics reveals gene regulatory networks across brain regions from risk variants to phenotypes of Alzheimer’s disease and Covid-19

finding: The indel variant rs11382548 was shown to affect alternative splicing in the TMEM216 gene by creating a canonical splice acceptor sequence and influencing two different intron excisions, highlighting its role in neurogenesis and developmental processes.
title: Genetic influences on cell type specific gene expression and splicing during neurogenesis elucidate regulatory mechanisms of brain traits

finding: This SNP was linked with alternative exon skipping for the ARL14EP gene and colocalized with the SCZ index SNP rs1765142. The risk allele G was associated with the skipping of this exon, suggesting a novel mechanism for schizophrenia risk through its effect on neurodevelopment.
title: Genetic influences on cell type specific gene expression and splicing during neurogenesis elucidate regulatory mechanisms of brain traits

finding: As an index SNP for schizophrenia, rs1765142 colocalized with the progenitor sSNP rs1222218, which regulated an exon skipping event for ARL14EP gene, pointing towards potential involvement in axonal development and schizophrenia pathology.
title: Genetic influences on cell type specific gene expression and splicing during neurogenesis elucidate regulatory mechanisms of brain traits

finding: The variant rs541102880 was identified as a rare African specific noncoding variant associated with the serum biomarker apolipoprotein A (APOA). This finding highlighted the importance of ancestry-specific genetic factors in serum biomarker associations.
title: Analyses of Biomarker Traits in Diverse UK Biobank Participants Identify Associations Missed by European-centric Analysis Strategies

finding: A noncoding variant aligned with the sickle cell trait was newly reported as associated with cystatin C levels, underscoring its relevance in kidney function assessments among African ancestry populations.
title: Analyses of Biomarker Traits in Diverse UK Biobank Participants Identify Associations Missed by European-centric Analysis Strategies

finding: Variant rs111709242 in PPFIBP2 was predicted as deleterious and associated with synapse formation, important for NMJ functionality. This highlighted its relevance in the severity of neuromuscular junction disorders.
title: Rare disease research workflow using multilayer networks elucidates the molecular determinants of severity in Congenital Myasthenic Syndromes

finding: rs77975665, another variant affecting PPFIBP2, was mentioned in the context of its potential role in NMJ processes and its relationship with several CMS genes, indicating its importance for severe CMS phenotypes.
title: Rare disease research workflow using multilayer networks elucidates the molecular determinants of severity in Congenital Myasthenic Syndromes

finding: The finding related to rs6265 indicated that brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) blood levels were decreased in patients with schizophrenia, suggesting an association between the genotypes of rs6265 and the altered levels of BDNF in individuals with neuropsychiatric disorders. This association underscores the potential role of genetic variations in influencing biochemical pathways relevant to schizophrenia.
title: A marker chromosome in psychosis identifies glycine decarboxylase (GLDC) as a novel regulator of neuronal and synaptic function in the hippocampus

finding: The SNP rs174593 was associated with increased FADS2 expression due to the creation of a match for the ELK1 transcription factor motif, which was predicted to elevate regulatory activity. This variant had a significant GWAS p-value and was implicated as an eQTL in liver tissues, relating it to reduced LDL cholesterol levels.
title: Deciphering regulatory DNA sequences and noncoding genetic variants using neural network models of massively parallel reporter assays

finding: The finding associated with the SNP rs664589 indicated that it was involved in inhibiting the binding to miR-194-5p, which contributed to an increased risk of colorectal cancer, along with promoting cancer growth and metastasis. This finding was originally reported in a study published in 2019, detailing the link between the MALAT1 polymorphism and colorectal cancer.
title: Loss of Lamin A leads to the nuclear translocation of AGO2 and compromised RNA interference

finding: The minor allele (G) of rs7937515 was associated with decreased clustering coefficient and local efficiency of the left middle temporal gyrus in both young and elderly participants. This SNP was also positively associated with body mass index (BMI) in young adults, indicating that the genetic influence from rs7937515 affected phenotypic outcomes related to brain connectivity across the lifespan.
title: Genetic Influence underlying Brain Connectivity Phenotype: A Study on Two Age-Specific Cohorts

finding: The derived allele for rs662799 in the ZPR1-APOA5 region was linked to increased triglycerides, demonstrating strong positive selection in the Jomon people. This allele was prevalent and associated with a higher ability to metabolize fats crucial for NST.
title: Cold adaptation in Upper Paleolithic hunter-gatherers of eastern Eurasia

finding: This SNP was noted as a joint lead risk SNP for both vitiligo and melanoma, establishing a direct link between these conditions.
title: Autoimmune Alleles at the Major Histocompatibility Locus Modify Melanoma Susceptibility

finding: The minor allele (A) of rs74911261 was associated with decreased risk of breast cancer and increased risk of renal cell carcinoma in individuals of European ancestry. Furthermore, the A allele was found to correlate with lower telomere length, specifically a reduction of 80.4 bp per allele, which supported previous observations that shorter telomere length is strongly associated with an increased risk for renal cancers.
title: Novel genetic determinants of telomere length from a multi-ethnic analysis of 75,000 whole genome sequences in TOPMed

finding: The SNP rs1453548 was identified as a lead signal for 'cups of tea per day', situated in an olfactory receptor-gene dense region on chromosome 11q12, and it explained significant variance related to β-ionone sensitivity.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis of dietary habits in UK Biobank identifies hundreds of genetic loci and establishes causal relationships between educational attainment and healthy eating

finding: The SNP rs7943953 was previously reported for its association with odor perception, specifically β-ionone sensitivity, and was part of the credible set for 'cups of tea per day' associated with olfactory receptor genes.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis of dietary habits in UK Biobank identifies hundreds of genetic loci and establishes causal relationships between educational attainment and healthy eating

finding: The SNP rs643017 was associated with 'cups of coffee per day' and found in a different region from tea intake on chromosome 11q12, illustrating the genetic distinction between beverage consumptions.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis of dietary habits in UK Biobank identifies hundreds of genetic loci and establishes causal relationships between educational attainment and healthy eating

finding: The SNP rs2445249 was associated with the dietary habit 'spread type: butter vs. any other', located in a region containing olfactory receptor genes, showcasing the genetic influence on butter consumption.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis of dietary habits in UK Biobank identifies hundreds of genetic loci and establishes causal relationships between educational attainment and healthy eating

finding: The SNP rs4937333 was associated with decreased expression of the ETS1 gene. This finding was particularly relevant in the context of its location in the miRNA-5003-binding site within the ETS1 3' untranslated region (UTR), potentially affecting the regulation of ETS1 expression and its roles in immune response and development of autoimmune conditions.
title: Sequences within and upstream of the mouse Ets1 gene drive high level expression in B cells, but are not sufficient for consistent expression in T cells

finding: The rs35705950 promoter variant for MUC5B was identified as a significant risk factor for developing Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF), accounting for at least 30% of total disease risk. This TT-minor allele variant was associated with enhanced MUC5B expression, contributing to a pathological state in both unaffected individuals and patients with IPF. The research established that this variant led to increased mucus expression in the respiratory bronchioles and the formation of honeycomb lesions characteristic of IPF, reinforcing its role in the progression of fibrosis. Additionally, ferrets used in the model were confirmed to possess this native variant, providing strong evidence for the relevance of MUC5B in human-like pulmonary fibrosis models.
title: Pulmonary Fibrosis Ferret Model Demonstrates Sustained Fibrosis, Restrictive Physiology, and Aberrant Repair

finding: This SNP was found to be specifically associated with TN disease in case-case comparisons.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: rs74911261 was associated exclusively with TN disease, contributing essential insights into subtype-specific genetic risk.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: This variant was closely associated with risk specifically in luminal A-like subtypes.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: Notably connected with luminal A-like risk with substantial evidence.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: Also related to high-grade tumor risk, bolstering findings for grade associations.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: The polymorphism rs3736228 at residue 1330 (Ala/Val) in LRP5 was associated with joint damage in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, specifically homozygous Val variants were implicated in increased joint damage. This finding provided insights into the potential implications of LRP5’s transport function for PUFAs, indicating that the presence of the Val residue was linked to reduced binding affinity to eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), which may relate to PUFA accretion and its effects on joint health.
title: LDL Receptor-Related Protein 5 is a Selective Transporter for Unesterified Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids

finding: The SNP rs2727271 exhibited allelic skew as determined by MPRA and was found to overlap an HCR-FlowFISH validated CRE for FADS1 and FADS2. This SNP displayed a significant effect, increasing activity by 1.2 log2 fold in a functional assay, confirming its role in gene regulation within the context of total cholesterol levels.
title: HCR-FlowFISH: A flexible CRISPR screening method to identify cis-regulatory elements and their target genes

finding: The variant rs174466 was associated with elevated PUFA levels and was validated as an eQTL affecting six genes, including FADS1, FADS2, and FADS3. HCR-FlowFISH demonstrated that rs174466 acted as a CRE specifically enhancing FADS3 expression, with the alternate allele creating a transcriptional activator motif. This SNP uniquely conveyed both allelic skew and functional CRE validation.
title: HCR-FlowFISH: A flexible CRISPR screening method to identify cis-regulatory elements and their target genes

finding: The variant rs61909476 was associated with fasting glucose (FG) in African American individuals, showing a significant effect (β=0.0812 mmol/l, P=3.9×10^-8), while having negligible effect in European ancestry individuals (β=0.0015 mmol/l, P=0.44). This finding highlighted its importance in the context of FG specifically within the African American population.
title: The Trans-Ancestral Genomic Architecture of Glycaemic Traits

finding: The variant rs10830963, located in an intron of the MTNR1B gene, demonstrated a strong association with both FG and HbA1c, confirming its impactful role in glycaemic traits due to identified allelic differences in enhancer activity and transcription factor binding.
title: The Trans-Ancestral Genomic Architecture of Glycaemic Traits

finding: The variant rs617948 showed a strong association with HbA1c levels, indicating its role in glycaemic regulation through effects on insulin secretion mediated by the C2CD2L gene.
title: The Trans-Ancestral Genomic Architecture of Glycaemic Traits

finding: Similar to rs35705059, the SNP rs35705950 displayed a robust association with IPF, validated through both discovery and meta-analysis with significant odds ratios, enhancing its characterization as a notable risk factor for IPF. The statistical data provided reliable evidence of its impact on susceptibility to the disease.
title: Toll-Like-Receptor 5 protects against pulmonary fibrosis by reducing lung dysbiosis

finding: The SNP rs1695 (gene GSTP1) was associated with increased risk of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) mortality, with a hazard ratio (HR) of 2.84 and a p-value of 0.01 in patients with HLA-B*08:01. This finding suggested a significant negative impact on outcomes following allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (alloHCT).
title: Associations of Minor Histocompatibility Antigens with Clinical Outcomes Following Allogeneic Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation

finding: Led findings in a new signal associated with height, indicating a probable pathogenic role.
title: Ancestral diversity improves discovery and fine-mapping of genetic loci for anthropometric traits - the Hispanic/Latino Anthropometry Consortium

finding: This SNP at RNH1 demonstrated high posterior probability and was linked to body mass, fulfilling a positive finding.
title: Ancestral diversity improves discovery and fine-mapping of genetic loci for anthropometric traits - the Hispanic/Latino Anthropometry Consortium

finding: The rs79423518-tagged cis-regulatory element (CRE) was identified as having a significant impact on the expression of target genes PRDX5 and TRMT112. This finding was supported by RT-qPCR results showing decreased expression levels upon intervention with sgRNAs, indicating a direct regulatory relationship.
title: Endogenous fine-mapping of functional regulatory elements in complex genetic loci

finding: The rs4930698-tagged CRE influenced the expression of PRDX5 and TRMT112, with RT-qPCR validations confirming that perturbations led to a decrease in gene expression. This suggests its role as a functional regulatory variant in a pLD context, working alongside rs79423518.
title: Endogenous fine-mapping of functional regulatory elements in complex genetic loci

finding: The SNP rs35705950 in the MUC5B gene was reported to have a strong association with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) incidence, yielding an odds ratio of 5.64. Moreover, despite previous studies indicating that the risk allele was associated with increased survival, the analysis suggested that this association might be due to index event bias, revealing instead a significant association with decreased survival (hazard ratio of 0.766). The adjusted analysis demonstrated that rs35705950 has a positive log hazard ratio with an extremely strong effect on survival.
title: Adjustment for index event bias in genome-wide association studies of subsequent events

finding: rs1126809 was identified in the TYR gene as an independent significant SNP related to eye colour variation.
title: Investigating the genetic architecture of eye colour in a Canadian cohort

finding: The SNP rs36051450, located approximately 25kb upstream from GGRAMD1B at 11q24.1, was identified with a p-value of 2e-9 in a multi-ethnic NIA-LOADFS sample including 3456 Caucasians and 287 African Americans. The minor allele of this SNP significantly reduced the hazards of Alzheimer's Disease (AD) in both genders, indicating its potential protective effect, particularly notable in female individuals due to a smaller male sample size.
title: Genome-wide association analysis of age-at-onset traits using Cox mixed-effects models
