finding: This SNP was found in the 3' UTR of HBB and was associated with beta Thalassemia. It had a frequency of 0.005% in the imputed XBI cohort and was linked to a lower mean corpuscular volume by 2.88 standard deviations.
title: The sequences of 150,119 genomes in the UK biobank

finding: The 'CC' genotype of rs2292912 in CRY2 was negatively correlated with language and executive function abilities, indicating a risk factor for these domains of cognitive performance in PSCI patients.
title: Genetic Variations and Altered Blood mRNA Level of Circadian Genes and BDNF as Risk Factors of Post-Stroke Cognitive Impairment among Eastern Indians

finding: The SNP rs79761481 was identified through GWAS analyses as significantly associated with Parkinson's Disease (PD) traits, specifically related to DaTscan data. This SNP is situated within the CD6 gene, which is implicated in immune system activity and has been linked to the onset of PD. The finding highlighted its potential role as a genetic biomarker in distinguishing between healthy individuals and those with PD based on neuroimaging results.
title: Multi view based imaging genetics analysis on Parkinson disease

finding: The rs33930165 variant, known as HbC, was identified as a pathogenic variant associated with sickle cell disease. This variant contributes to the phenotype where over 90% of the cases are classified as either HbSS or HbSC. Accurate detection of this SNP was crucial for the development of non-invasive prenatal testing (sgNIPT) for diagnosing sickle cell disease.
title: A novel high-throughput molecular counting method with single base-pair resolution enables accurate single-gene NIPT

finding: The benign variant rs713040 was utilized to perform NIPT analysis and its effectiveness in distinguishing fetal inheritance was validated in samples with identifiable maternal genotypes. The application of this SNP in the analysis allowed for successful identification of normal and affected fetal genotypes, demonstrating that all NIPT results were concordant with newborn genotyping. Thus, it reinforced the efficacy of using this SNP in sgNIPT protocols.
title: A novel high-throughput molecular counting method with single base-pair resolution enables accurate single-gene NIPT

finding: The Taq1A SNP (rs1800497) genotypes were categorized based on the presence or absence of the A1+ allele. This categorization facilitated the investigation into its influence on behavioral control, as subjects were selected based on their COMT/Taq1A genotype, emphasizing the role of dopamine in modulating behavioral decision-making.
title: A dopaminergic basis of behavioral control

finding: This SNP was associated with gain-of-function mutations creating an upstream CFIm-binding motif (TGTA), which demonstrated significantly higher variant fold changes compared to other TGTA-creating mutations. Furthermore, it stabilized the RNA secondary structure of the PAS.
title: Deciphering the Impact of Genetic Variation on Human Polyadenylation

finding: The SNP rs3842753 was identified as significantly associated with Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) within the framework using the GLN model. The context indicated that this SNP was among the ten most highly activated SNPs in the model, demonstrating its relevance to T1D beyond the known associations in the HLA region on chromosome 6. Furthermore, prior research from Wang et al. (2021) had also linked this SNP to increased beta-cell ins mRNA, underscoring its potential role in the disease.
title: Deep integrative models for large-scale human genomics

finding: Identified as a lead SNP for a novel locus associated with cIMT. It demonstrated eQTLs in a relevant tissue, the aorta, where the cIMT-increasing allele was linked to increased gene expression.
title: Carotid intima-media thickness in UK Biobank: Identification of novel genome-wide loci, sex-specific effects and genetic correlations with obesity and glucometabolic traits

finding: This novel SNP was identified as a lead for the IMTmax locus and showed similar association effects in IMTmean, reinforcing its role in vascular health.
title: Carotid intima-media thickness in UK Biobank: Identification of novel genome-wide loci, sex-specific effects and genetic correlations with obesity and glucometabolic traits

finding: The rs964184 SNP was identified as being related to abnormal glucose metabolism and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) specifically in Japanese populations. This finding highlighted the impact of ZPR1 variants on metabolic disorders.
title: Bioinformatic analysis of human ZPR1 gene pathogenic exome mutations

finding: The rs2075294 mutation, located within the ZPR1 gene in the APOA1/C3/A4/A5-ZPR1-BUD13 gene cluster, was associated with dyslipidemia, indicating a significant link between ZPR1 variants and lipid metabolism disorders.
title: Bioinformatic analysis of human ZPR1 gene pathogenic exome mutations

finding: The I196T mutation (rs368697578) was established as harmful by both SIFT and PolyPhen-2_HVAR, confirming its pathogenic nature. This mutation was notably associated with a rare ZPR1 disorder and was located in the A-domain of the ZPR1 protein, underlining its relevance in genetic disorders.
title: Bioinformatic analysis of human ZPR1 gene pathogenic exome mutations

finding: The p.Ala264Val mutation (rs35120633) was identified as pathogenic in the study and associated with plasma triglyceride levels, indicating its potential implication in metabolic conditions. It had the highest minor allele frequency among the pathogenic ZEMs analyzed.
title: Bioinformatic analysis of human ZPR1 gene pathogenic exome mutations

finding: The rs4102217 SNP was implicated in glaucoma and demonstrated significant associations with multiple nearby genes via eQTL analysis.
title: Single-cell multiome of the human retina and deep learning nominate causal variants in complex eye diseases

finding: The SNP rs11030293 was linked to the functional activity of the PI3K signaling pathway, based on findings reported by van de Stolpe. This research provided a method for quantitatively measuring PI3K pathway activity in cancer, underscoring its importance in stem cell signaling profiles.
title: Measurement of activity of developmental signal transduction pathways to quantify stem cell pluripotency and phenotypically characterize differentiated cells

finding: SNP rs1552726 was associated with gene NLRP14, which is implicated in germ-cell-specific functions and may play a regulatory role in the innate immune system. It was highlighted in the study as having the potential to affect correct splicing, based on evaluations using ESEfinder and SpliceSiteFinder.
title: Locating suspicious lethal genes by abnormal distributions of SNP patterns

finding: The clQTL rs546512774, located in the ARNTL locus, was validated using multiple approaches, showing expected directionalities in chromatin accessibility and TCF21 binding in accordance with QTL regression results.
title: Quantitative trait loci mapped for TCF21 binding, chromatin accessibility and chromosomal looping in coronary artery smooth muscle cells reveal molecular mechanisms of coronary disease loci

finding: The bQTL rs1037169 in the ARNTL locus demonstrated expected chromatin accessibility changes consistent with allele-specific qPCR results, supporting its role as a regulatory variant.
title: Quantitative trait loci mapped for TCF21 binding, chromatin accessibility and chromosomal looping in coronary artery smooth muscle cells reveal molecular mechanisms of coronary disease loci

finding: The SNP rs964184, located in the 3’ UTR of the ZPR1 gene on chromosome 11, significantly increased triglycerides (TG) with a beta value of 0.16 (P = 1.4 × 10^−272). The allele frequencies for this SNP varied greatly between populations, being observed at 94% in THC Jomon ancestry, 28% in THC modern Japanese, and 18% in THC continental ancestry. This finding indicated a genetic predisposition for higher triglyceride levels in individuals with Jomon ancestry, reflecting the nutritional adaptations of the Jomon people in their hunter-gatherer lifestyle.
title: Modern Japanese ancestry-derived variants revealed the formation process of the current Japanese regional gradations

finding: The IFN-γ +874 (rs2406918) CC genotype was also associated with protection against BKV infection. This lent support to the notion that polymorphisms in the IFN-γ gene contribute to varying susceptibility levels to BK virus among kidney transplant patients.
title: The change of lymphocyte subsets and inflammatory cytokine in BK viruria

finding: The G allele of rs5128 was identified as a significant UTR variant that was associated with plasma triglyceride levels in the Taiwanese population. This finding highlighted the role of UTR variants in influencing RNA and protein expression, particularly in the context of health biomarkers.
title: Multiplexed Assays of Human Disease-relevant Mutations Reveal UTR Dinucleotide Composition as a Major Determinant of RNA Stability

finding: It was one of the SNPs that showed strong replication in the ENIGMA study, illustrating its role among the identified loci associated with brain volumetric traits.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide analyses of the brain imaging phenotypes in UK Biobank

finding: This SNP was identified among the significant risk loci related to volumetric imaging derived phenotypes, with potential implications for its biological disruption in brain function.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide analyses of the brain imaging phenotypes in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs10891314 showed a significant association with rhythm impairment and dyslexia. It was highlighted due to its exceptionally high phastCons score, indicating it is likely a missense variant located within the DLAT gene. This gene is associated with a rare neurodevelopmental disorder and is critically conserved, suggesting that this variant may increase susceptibility to both rhythm impairment and dyslexia.
title: The shared genetic architecture and evolution of human language and musical rhythm

finding: The SNP rs1815739, located in the ACTN3 gene, resulted in a nonsense polymorphism (R577X), which caused the loss of alpha-actinin-3 protein in fast skeletal muscle fibers and was linked to reduced sprint performance in elite athletes. Despite not causing disease, the homozygous 577XX genotype was associated with improved cold tolerance due to increased slow myosin heavy chain muscle fibers. Furthermore, statistical analyses indicated that the X-allele emerged around 135,000 years ago, with its frequency rising in European and Asian populations approximately 42,000 years ago, suggesting a protective advantage of α-actinin-3 deficiency during cold exposure.
title: α-Actinin-3 deficiency protects from the effects of acute cold exposure through altered skeletal muscle Ca2+ and OXPHOS signaling

finding: The variant rs1806152 was identified as a splice region variant associated with the expression of the nearby PAUPAR gene on chromosome 11. This association was noted during fine-mapping of regions linked to major depression.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS of major depression aids locus discovery, fine-mapping, gene prioritisation, and causal inference

finding: The SNP rs2237892 in the last intron of KCNQ1 was found to be maternally associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D), with this association replicated in multiple cohorts. The study found that rs2237892, along with several other SNPs, acted as maternal eQTL for CDKN1C, illustrating the interaction between these SNPs and gene expression despite not being eQTL for KCNQ1.
title: Abundant Parent-of-origin Effect eQTL in Humans: The Framingham Heart Study

finding: SNP rs2283228 was also associated with T2D and shown to be a maternal eQTL of CDKN1C. This further supported the findings regarding the downstream effects of SNPs located near KCNQ1, as they were linked to maternal influences on diabetes-related gene expression.
title: Abundant Parent-of-origin Effect eQTL in Humans: The Framingham Heart Study

finding: The SNP rs2237895 was significant in association with T2D and found to be a maternal eQTL of CDKN1C. This finding aligned with other SNPs in the KCNQ1 region that were implicated in T2D, consolidating the notion of maternal inheritance patterns affecting gene expression.
title: Abundant Parent-of-origin Effect eQTL in Humans: The Framingham Heart Study

finding: Similarly, SNP rs2237897 was associated with T2D and was confirmed to be a maternal eQTL of CDKN1C. Together with the other KCNQ1-related SNPs, it illustrated the maternal effect on the expression of downstream genes connected to diabetes susceptibility.
title: Abundant Parent-of-origin Effect eQTL in Humans: The Framingham Heart Study

finding: This SNP served as a sentinel for androsterone glucuronide association, showing significant correlation with steroid levels in the 1x10^-55 to 9x10^-11 range. Its significance highlights its role in variation of steroid metabolism closely linked to the locus of SLC22A24.
title: Unraveling the functional role of the orphan solute carrier, SLC22A24 in the transport of steroid conjugates through metabolomic and genome-wide association studies

finding: Similarly to rs78176967, this SNP was identified as another sentinel SNP associated with androsterone glucuronide levels with significant p-values ranging from 1x10^-55 to 9x10^-11, suggesting it too is integral in steroid glucuronide metabolism.
title: Unraveling the functional role of the orphan solute carrier, SLC22A24 in the transport of steroid conjugates through metabolomic and genome-wide association studies

finding: The p.Tyr501Ter variant (rs11231341) was strongly linked with lower levels of androsterone glucuronide and etiocholanolone glucuronide (p<5x10^-8). This nonsense variant was shown to terminate the protein synthesis of SLC22A24, leading to findings that it is a major determinant of steroid glucuronide levels among different populations.
title: Unraveling the functional role of the orphan solute carrier, SLC22A24 in the transport of steroid conjugates through metabolomic and genome-wide association studies

finding: This splice donor variant was associated with lower expression levels of SLC22A24 in kidney eQTL databases, indicating that it can affect splicing processes that influence transporter function, which correlates to variations in steroid levels.
title: Unraveling the functional role of the orphan solute carrier, SLC22A24 in the transport of steroid conjugates through metabolomic and genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs11040528 was associated with the gene HOXB7, which was reported to correlate with poor prognosis in breast cancer. Li et al. (2019) discussed the role of HOX transcription factors, including HOXB7, in cancer predisposition and progression, highlighting its importance in cancer biology.
title: HOXB7 induces STAT3-mediated transformation and lung metastasis in an immortalized mammary gland NMuMG cells

finding: The SNP rs11020136 was linked to the role of extracellular vesicles (EVs) in cell stress response and resistance to cancer therapy. This gene was studied in the context of how EVs can modulate signaling pathways following cellular stress such as DNA damage, specifically in iPSC-MSC. The finding indicated that the genetic variation at this locus could influence the cellular response under stress and the subsequent secretion of EVs.
title: Small extracellular vesicles from iPSC-MSC lose their regenerative potential upon UV-C irradiation

finding: The variant rs35705950, which is associated with MUC5B, was found to reside within an enhancer that undergoes lineage- and disease-dependent epigenetic remodeling. This finding was relevant to understanding the susceptibility and responses of the small airway epithelial cells to Afghan desert particulate matter (APM), contributing to the pathogenesis of deployment-related respiratory diseases (DRRD).
title: Integrated Genomics Approaches Identify Transcriptional Mediators and Epigenetic Responses to Afghan Desert Particulate Matter in Small Airway Epithelial Cells

finding: Found within Alzheimer's risk profiles, this SNP was connected through multiple mechanisms emphasizing early neuronal differentiation.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: The FADS1 locus (rs174546) showed significant selection associated with changes in diet, particularly reflecting a transition towards a more carnivorous diet. This selection event occurred primarily in Neolithic populations before and during their arrival in Europe.
title: Population Genomics of Stone Age Eurasia

finding: At the FADS2 locus (rs174581), strong selection was similarly linked to dietary changes, with significant signals of selection observed on the EHG, CHG, and ANA haplotypic backgrounds, suggesting a long history of adaptation related to fat metabolism in response to diet.
title: Population Genomics of Stone Age Eurasia

finding: The SNP rs1004446 was noted for medium pleiotropy with a PVS score of 0.51, relating to type 1 diabetes mellitus and multiple sclerosis.
title: Pleiotropic Variability Score: A Genome Interpretation Metric to Quantify Phenomic Associations of Genomic Variants

finding: The SNP rs964184 exhibited high pleiotropy with a PVS score of 0.565, associated with over 45 different diseases and phenotypes.
title: Pleiotropic Variability Score: A Genome Interpretation Metric to Quantify Phenomic Associations of Genomic Variants

finding: The SNP rs2618516, located in the SPON1 gene, was identified in a GWAS focused on dementia subjects. Although this study did not assess longitudinal features, the SNP was associated with connectivity patterns as a phenotype.
title: Genome-Wide Association Study of Brain Connectivity Changes for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs933920 was identified as the top SNP in the genome-wide significant locus 11p15.2-3, demonstrating a significant association with smoking behavior and pulmonary function. It is an intronic variant in the PARVA gene, which was previously linked to differential methylation in airway and buccal tissues related to smoking status.
title: Mixed-model admixture mapping identifies smoking-dependent loci of lung function in African Americans

finding: This SNP was a missense mutation in AMOTL1 within locus 11q21 and was associated with endothelial permeability and COPD, providing evidence for its potential relevance in smoking-related pathologies.
title: Mixed-model admixture mapping identifies smoking-dependent loci of lung function in African Americans

finding: The SNP rs484915 was identified as a genome-wide significant cis-acting pQTL variant for MMP-1 production, showing an association strength of P = 1.81 × 10^-8. It was also noted that this SNP had a significant eQTL effect on MMP-1 gene expression following 24h stimulation with Candida albicans.
title: Integration of Candida albicans-induced single-cell gene expression data and circulatory protein concentrations reveal genetic regulators of inflammation

finding: The SNP rs7116008, identified as a trans-pQTL, showed the most significant association with PLT among GP5 pQTLs. This intronic variant in the ST3GAL4 gene was implicated in sialylation processes of platelet receptors, which contributed to the positive correlation between GP5 levels and PLT.
title: Integrative Genomic Analysis and Functional Studies Reveal GP5, GRN, MPO and MCAM as Causal Protein Biomarkers for Platelet Traits

finding: The haplotype pair rs11020521 and rs11020522 exhibited a significant interaction effect with sign reversal, where individually they had no effect or were weakly positive, while the joint haplotype resulted in a more significant effect in the opposite direction.
title: Multiple Causal Variants Underlie Genetic Associations in Humans

finding: In context with rs11020521, the rs11020522 combined with it showed a significant interaction where their joint haplotype had a more significant effect in the opposite direction, despite each variant being weakly positive or having no effect alone.
title: Multiple Causal Variants Underlie Genetic Associations in Humans

finding: The SNP rs2305498 was associated with increased waist-hip ratio adjusted for BMI (WHRadjBMI) in females, indicating a connection to body fat distribution. This finding stemmed from a combined genome-wide association study (GWAS) that demonstrated the minor allele was linked to lower expression of TPCN2 in subcutaneous adipose tissue, suggesting TPCN2's potential role in regulating fat accumulation.
title: Two-pore channel 2 is a key regulator of adipocyte differentiation via the cAMP signaling pathway with calpain as downstream effector

finding: The SNP rs66958567, which is in high linkage disequilibrium with rs2305498, was characterized as a strong expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for TPCN2 in visceral and subcutaneous adipose tissue. The analysis indicated that this SNP contributed to the regulation of TPCN2 expression, reinforcing its role in adipose tissue biology.
title: Two-pore channel 2 is a key regulator of adipocyte differentiation via the cAMP signaling pathway with calpain as downstream effector

finding: The rs12252-C variant in the IFITM3 gene was associated with increased severity of disease in COVID-19 patients, highlighting its role in influencing vulnerability to severe outcomes during SARS-CoV-2 infections. This association provided evidence that genetic variations in IFITM3 could affect individual responses to the virus.
title: Interferon-induced transmembrane protein 3 (IFITM3) limits lethality of SARS-CoV-2 in mice

finding: The combined haplotype involving the rs34481144 reference allele and rs12252 was shown to correlate with the COVID-19 standardized mortality ratio among ethnic groups in England, supporting the hypothesis that these genetic variants might relate to mortality rates in COVID-19, particularly through their influence on IFITM3 function.
title: Interferon-induced transmembrane protein 3 (IFITM3) limits lethality of SARS-CoV-2 in mice

finding: The SNP rs74685827 intersected with microglia-specific cCREs linked to dysregulated SORL1 gene expression in the hippocampus (HIP). This finding highlighted the potential role of this SNP in influencing gene expression related to sEOAD.
title: Single-nucleus multiomics reveals the disrupted regulatory programs in three brain regions of sporadic early-onset Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs1591330048 was found to overlap with a cCRE linked to dysregulated SORL1 gene expression in astrocytes in the HIP. This connection underscored the role of this SNP in the regulatory mechanisms associated with sEOAD.
title: Single-nucleus multiomics reveals the disrupted regulatory programs in three brain regions of sporadic early-onset Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The Val66Met SNP (rs6265) in the BDNF gene was associated with a reduction in recognition memory performance, particularly influencing the familiarity subprocess of recognition memory without affecting recollection. While no significant group differences were found in grey- or white-matter structures of the brain, the SNP was linked to functional changes in recognition memory processes that are independent of structural alterations.
title: The Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor Val66Met Genotype Does Not Influence the Grey or White Matter Structures Underlying Recognition Memory

finding: The SNP rs599083 was initially found to be associated with increased android-to-leg fat ratio in a previous study. In this context, it was confirmed that this common intronic low spinal bone mineral density-associated LRP5 variant served as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for LRP5 in lower leg skin. However, this association did not extend to leg adipose tissue (AT). This finding was supported by further examination showing that carriers of this SNP had increased leg fat mass and reinforced the notion of LRP5's role in fat distribution.
title: LRP5 promotes adipose progenitor cell fitness and adipocyte insulin sensitivity

finding: The SNP rs7944926 at the DHCR7 locus was associated with protection against vitamin D insufficiency. It was inferred that the selection coefficient for this allele increased significantly over the past 150 generations, from around 0 to 0.06, alongside an increase in allele frequency from approximately 20% to 60%, highlighting its importance in response to vitamin D deficiency in Britain.
title: Direct detection of natural selection in Bronze Age Britain

finding: For the SNP rs1042602 located at the TYR locus, the paper indicated findings regarding selection coefficients and allele frequency changes that are significant, thus aligning with the pattern of selection affecting skin pigmentation related to vitamin D demands in Britain.
title: Direct detection of natural selection in Bronze Age Britain

finding: Linked to N-acetylglycine levels through the GSTP1 gene, it showcased significant effects observed only in females.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: This SNP in the FADS2 gene was associated with the metabolite 1,2-dillnoleoyl-GPC, emphasizing its importance in lipid metabolism.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: As a variant in TRIM5, rs11601507 was assessed for its contribution to CAD in the context of previously reported associations, making it a relevant finding in the ongoing exploration of CAD genetics.
title: Population-specific and transethnic genome-wide analyses reveal distinct and shared genetic risks of coronary artery disease

finding: Found to be associated with CAD, rs3741380 in EHBP1L1 was previously identified, further contributing to the body of evidence linking this gene to CAD pathology.
title: Population-specific and transethnic genome-wide analyses reveal distinct and shared genetic risks of coronary artery disease

finding: Identified as a GWS locus for smoking cessation, rs17602038 on DRD2 was also recorded in earlier studies related to smoking trajectories.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association analyses leveraging alcohol use disorder findings identify novel loci for smoking behaviors in the Million Veteran Program

finding: This SNP near DRD2 was noted for its colocalization between AUD and smoking initiation, achieving GWS status which highlights its potential impact on addictive behaviors.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association analyses leveraging alcohol use disorder findings identify novel loci for smoking behaviors in the Million Veteran Program

finding: Previously associated with AUD, this SNP demonstrated relevance to smoking initiation and highlighted common genetic pathways.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association analyses leveraging alcohol use disorder findings identify novel loci for smoking behaviors in the Million Veteran Program

finding: This SNP was found to be significantly associated with smoking trajectories, reinforcing the ties between genetic predispositions and smoking initiation.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association analyses leveraging alcohol use disorder findings identify novel loci for smoking behaviors in the Million Veteran Program

finding: The common missense variant rs17224476 at the OR51E1 locus was identified in a previous genome-wide association study (GWAS) as significantly associated with diastolic blood pressure (DBP), where each copy of the minor allele A was associated with an approximate increase in DBP of 0.16 mmHg. In the UK Biobank analysis, this variant showed consistent effects across sex and age, indicating that it increased DBP in both male and female carriers similarly.
title: An evolutionarily conserved olfactory receptor is required for sex differences in blood pressure

finding: The rare missense variant rs202113356, also located at the OR51E1 locus, demonstrated a significant sex-interaction effect on DBP. It increased DBP by approximately 6.28 mmHg in female carriers (AG) compared to non-carrier females, while it decreased DBP by about 4.77 mmHg in male carriers (AG), though the latter was not statistically significant. This variant showcased opposing effects on blood pressure between sexes, highlighting its unique role in blood pressure regulation.
title: An evolutionarily conserved olfactory receptor is required for sex differences in blood pressure

finding: The polymorphism rs35705950-T in the MUC5B gene was found to confer protective effects against severe disease and hospitalization in COVID-19 patients. This finding was supported by multiple meta-analyses which highlighted how increased expression of MUC5B due to this SNP may be beneficial in mitigating the clinical impacts of SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: LY6E protects mice from pathogenic effects of murine coronavirus and SARS-CoV-2

finding: The rs1695 allele of GSPT1 was associated with a lower risk of COVID-19 development, relating to its role in cellular mechanisms during infection response.
title: Differential haplotype expression in class I MHC genes during SARS-CoV-2 infection of human lung cell lines

finding: The SNP rs17500359 was significantly associated with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis, holding a perfect correlation (r² = 1.0), linking it to structural variations within the genome.
title: The length of haplotype blocks and signals of structural variation in reconstructed genealogies

finding: The missense variant rs6265 was found in the BDNF gene, associated with body weight regulation and implicated in Type 2 diabetes. This finding indicated a significant genetic adaptation associated with metabolic phenotypes over historical periods.
title: 1,000 ancient genomes uncover 10,000 years of natural selection in Europe

finding: Associated with the FADS1 gene, this SNP was linked to fatty acid metabolism and reduced triglyceride levels. Selection at this locus reflected dietary transitions, emphasizing adaptations to starch-heavy diets of more recent human history.
title: 1,000 ancient genomes uncover 10,000 years of natural selection in Europe

finding: The variant rs528823 was also implicated in Alzheimer’s disease through its role in disrupting inclusion of an exon in the MS4A3 gene by perturbing a YBX3 binding motif. This finding was validated through antisense oligonucleotide experiments and supported by ENCODE eCLIP data indicating binding, suggesting that splicing, rather than gene expression, may link this variant to the disease.
title: A Deep Dive into Statistical Modeling of RNA Splicing QTLs Reveals New Variants that Explain Neurodegenerative Disease

finding: The SNP rs145802670 in PGAP2 was reported to be pleiotropic with T2D. This was a novel association uncovered during the analysis and contributes to the understanding of genetic factors influencing type 2 diabetes.
title: Causal inference for multiple risk factors and diseases from genomics data

finding: The SNP rs2785197 was identified with a P<sub>GWAS</sub> of 6.5E-44 associated with PDHX in GWAS; however, TWAS indicated that CD44 was the likely causal gene (P<sub>TWAS</sub> = 1.1E-32). The colocalization analysis showed that rs2785197 regulated CD44 expression, establishing a significant genetic link to OP.
title: Integrating genome-wide association and transcriptome predicted model identify novel target genes with osteoporosis

finding: The SNP rs11040527 was found to play a significant role in breast cancer regulation by stabilizing HER2 protein. This SNP's association with obesity suggests a link between obesity and breast cancer pathogenesis, corroborated by findings detailed in the publication by Fararjeh et al. (2019).
title: Novel multiparametric bulk and single EV pipeline for adipose cell-specific biomarker discovery in paired human biospecimens

finding: The variant rs490972 was identified as a lead signal for serum triglyceride levels and exhibited strong allelic bias in various conditions, with the alternate allele (A) showing lower regulatory activity compared to the reference allele (G). This variant overlapped motifs for SP family transcription factors, particularly SP1, suggesting its regulatory activity might be mediated by SP1 binding. The activity of this SNP was particularly pronounced in undifferentiated cells, highlighting the importance of cellular context.
title: Functional dissection of metabolic trait-associated gene regulation in steady state and stimulated human skeletal muscle cells

finding: The rs12252-C SNP was identified as a deleterious variant in the IFITM3 gene that negatively impacted its splicing. This SNP was noted to be surprisingly common in the human population, with approximately 20% of Chinese individuals homozygous for this variant. It was established that human deficiencies in IFITM3, including those linked to rs12252-C, were associated with increased severity of influenza infections.
title: Innate immune control of influenza virus interspecies adaptation

finding: The rs34481144-A SNP was characterized as a deleterious variant affecting the promoter efficacy of the IFITM3 gene. It was reported that about 4% of Europeans were homozygous for this variant. Similar to the findings related to rs12252, deficiencies in IFITM3 due to this SNP were associated with heightened severity of influenza, thereby emphasizing the relevance of IFITM3 in viral infections.
title: Innate immune control of influenza virus interspecies adaptation

finding: The SNP rs11030406 was connected to the regulation of FGFR1 expression through a transcription complex influenced by ZEB1/YAP1 in glioblastoma stem cells. This correlation demonstrated that rs11030406 might enhance both proliferation and stemness of glioblastoma, further implicating it in tumor growth dynamics.
title: Spatial distribution and functional relevance of FGFR1 and FGFR2 expression for glioblastoma tumor invasion

finding: The rs10219187 SNP was also indicated to be favored for myopia through selection signals, contributing to common refractive errors in the studied populations.
title: Detection of adaptation to light environment in myopia-associated loci Diversity of the myopia genetic background

finding: The SNP rs968567 was identified as a key genetic variant associated with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). It was found in the promoter region of the FADS2 gene and was shown to alter DNA methylation at the binding site cg06781209 for the transcription factor SREBF2. This alteration disrupted SREBF2 binding, leading to a downregulation of FADS2 expression, which subsequently reduced the risk of RA. Methven's predictions indicated that in the context of rheumatoid arthritis, the influence of rs968567 on CpG methylation was reduced, suggesting a diminished ability of the SNP to modulate disease outcomes.
title: Predicting the effect of non-coding mutations on single-cell DNA methylation using deep learning

finding: The rs895555 variant located within an intron of OSBPL5 was strongly associated with the activation of this gene's promoter in CLL patients. It created a potential Forkhead TF binding site, linking it to disease progression and overall survival in CLL.
title: Non-coding variants impact cis-regulatory coordination in a cell type-specific manner

finding: The LRP5 rs556442 polymorphism was associated with obesity and body composition in postmenopausal women, reflecting its role in metabolic disorders.
title: Screening and identification of key biomarkers in diabetic kidney disease and its complications: Evidence from bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The analysis identified a significant relationship between the T/G SNP (rs2071094) and allele-specific methylation in adipocytes. Specifically, fragments carrying the T allele were noted to be unmethylated, whereas those with the G allele were methylated, showcasing a strong segregation of methylation status dependent on the allele.
title: Atlas of imprinted and allele-specific DNA methylation in the human body

finding: The investigation into rs80269905 indicated that this SNP was consistent with parental imprinting effects. The data demonstrated that all analyzed samples exhibited bimodal methylation patterns, implicating that allele-specific methylation varied depending on the parental origin across different donor specimens.
title: Atlas of imprinted and allele-specific DNA methylation in the human body

finding: The SNP rs552304627, a heterozygous variant in the OTOG gene, was found in two unrelated families. This variant was identified as likely pathogenic according to ACMG and AMP guidelines and showed an enrichment in familial MD cases compared to the NFE and Spanish populations.
title: Rare Variants in the OTOG Gene Are a Frequent Cause of Familial Meniere’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs61978648 was identified in four unrelated families (F2, F3, F4, F5) as a rare missense variant in the OTOG gene, indicating a significant involvement of this gene in familial MD.
title: Rare Variants in the OTOG Gene Are a Frequent Cause of Familial Meniere’s Disease

finding: The variant rs61736002 was also shared among individuals from four unrelated families (F2, F3, F4, F5). This finding contributed to the evidence of the OTOG gene's significance in familial MD cases.
title: Rare Variants in the OTOG Gene Are a Frequent Cause of Familial Meniere’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs117315845 was found in patients from two unrelated families (F1 and F14), supporting the involvement of the OTOG gene in familial MD, with an established pattern of shared variants across families.
title: Rare Variants in the OTOG Gene Are a Frequent Cause of Familial Meniere’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs2128739 was the lead SNP associated with the proximal pulmonary artery diameter, having implications in the genetic risk for pulmonary hypertension due to its proximity to PDGFD, a gene linked with loss-of-function variants in related cardiac conditions.
title: Genetic Analysis of Right Heart Structure and Function in 40,000 People

finding: The SNP rs3903072 was identified as a cancer-associated genetic variant that modulated immune cells within the tumor microenvironment. This finding related to how genetic variants can influence immune cell behavior and contribute to cancer progression, highlighting the importance of genetic factors in the dynamics of tumor immunity.
title: MetaTiME: Meta-components of the Tumor Immune Microenvironment

finding: The SNP rs762019591 was linked to the gene MRE11 and was associated with a nonsense mutation that greatly predisposed individuals to the development of blood clones. The analysis indicated significant risk associated with CNN-LOH mutations affecting inherited alleles at this locus.
title: Monogenic and polygenic inheritance become instruments for clonal selection

finding: The SNP rs587781384 tagged a nonsense variation in the MRE11 gene. Clonal hematopoiesis was driven by this mutation, which was demonstrated to interact with acquired CNN-LOH mutations affecting inherited risk alleles, resulting in a significant association with blood cancer susceptibility.
title: Monogenic and polygenic inheritance become instruments for clonal selection

finding: The SNP rs587779872 was identified as a missense variant in the ATM gene. It was part of a small subset of carriers that also exhibited CNN-LOH mutations, showcasing an independent association that contributed to the vulnerability to clonally expanded blood cells.
title: Monogenic and polygenic inheritance become instruments for clonal selection

finding: The SNP rs786204751 represented a stop gain mutation in the ATM gene. Its presence demonstrated an interaction with rs587779872, as it negated the protective effect of the missense variant in contexts of CNN-LOH, further emphasizing the complexities of acquired mutations influencing blood clone prevalence.
title: Monogenic and polygenic inheritance become instruments for clonal selection

finding: The new polymorphism biomarker rs629367 was associated with an increased risk and poor survival in gastric cancer patients, mediated by the up-regulation of miRNA-let-7a expression, highlighting its relevance in cancer prognosis.
title: SNPector: SNP inspecting tool to detect disease existence and drug response in direct naked sequencing depends on mutation index

finding: SNP rs61885923 was associated with an earlier AAO, reporting a decrement of 2.9 years (p<0.05), highlighting its relevance to genetic risk factors.
title: A higher burden of multiple sclerosis genetic risk confers an earlier onset

finding: An INDEL variant rs35248926 was found in strong linkage disequilibrium (LD) with the lead i-rQTL variant of SIDT2-212 (rs11449159). It exhibited eQTL effects on surrounding genes like TAGLN, PCSK7, PAFAH1B2, and SIK3, suggesting broad regulatory effects.
title: Splicing QTL analysis focusing on coding sequences reveals pathogenicity of disease susceptibility loci

finding: The variant rs11449159 was highlighted as the lead i-rQTL for SIDT2-212 and was linked to broad effects on gene regulation due to strong linkage with rs35248926.
title: Splicing QTL analysis focusing on coding sequences reveals pathogenicity of disease susceptibility loci

finding: This allele in the ANO1 gene was replicated across both European and non-European datasets, signifying its consistent impact on intrinsic brain connectivity.
title: Common variants contribute to intrinsic human brain functional networks

finding: The SNP rs508487 was found to be associated with acute coronary syndrome and plasma concentrations of HDL-Cholesterol, indicating its relevance in cardiovascular disease risk.
title: Identification of genetic drivers of plasma lipoproteins in the Diversity Outbred mouse population

finding: The SNP rs236911 was identified as positively associated with acute coronary syndrome and plasma levels of triglycerides, highlighting its significance in lipid metabolism and cardiovascular health.
title: Identification of genetic drivers of plasma lipoproteins in the Diversity Outbred mouse population

finding: The SNP rs236918 showed a strong association with acute coronary syndrome and HDL-Cholesterol concentrations, further confirming its role as a genetic driver of lipid traits linked to cardiovascular disease.
title: Identification of genetic drivers of plasma lipoproteins in the Diversity Outbred mouse population

finding: The SNP rs11032578 was identified as an apaQTL associated with increased usage of an intronic polyadenylation site in the ABTB2 gene. Individuals with the C/C genotype were more likely to utilize this intronic PAS compared to those with heterozygous C/T or homozygous T/T genotypes, demonstrating a significant genetic effect on alternative polyadenylation.
title: Alternative polyadenylation mediates genetic regulation of gene expression

finding: This SNP was associated with the asthma/allergy phenotype, particularly in European cohorts, and showed moderate linkage disequilibrium (LD) with H1 variants of MUC5AC.
title: Structural and genetic diversity in the secreted mucins, MUC5AC and MUC5B

finding: This SNP was linked to asthma/allergy phenotypes in European cohorts and exhibited moderate LD with MUC5AC H1 haplogroup variants.
title: Structural and genetic diversity in the secreted mucins, MUC5AC and MUC5B

finding: This SNP demonstrated significant association with asthma/allergy in European cohorts and was in moderate LD with H1 variants of MUC5AC.
title: Structural and genetic diversity in the secreted mucins, MUC5AC and MUC5B

finding: This SNP was noted for its protective association against infection-induced pneumonia/meningitis in European cohorts, showing higher LD with H1 variants of MUC5AC.
title: Structural and genetic diversity in the secreted mucins, MUC5AC and MUC5B

finding: This SNP was linked to the phenotype of severe tuberculosis-induced meningitis and was in moderately high LD with H2 variants of MUC5AC, suggesting a modest signature of positive selection among East Asians.
title: Structural and genetic diversity in the secreted mucins, MUC5AC and MUC5B

finding: This SNP had a protective role against infection-induced pneumonia/meningitis in European cohorts, demonstrating a strong LD with H1 variants of MUC5AC.
title: Structural and genetic diversity in the secreted mucins, MUC5AC and MUC5B

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with various respiratory phenotypes such as interstitial lung diseases in the PheWAS analysis, with strong evidence of association and significance after Bonferroni correction.
title: Structural and genetic diversity in the secreted mucins, MUC5AC and MUC5B

finding: An original and positive finding was associated with the SNP rs11030291, which was implicated in the role of calcium signaling in inducing cell death in malignant human B cells. This elaborated on the significance of Ca2+ pathways in response to treatments aimed at B-cell malignancies.
title: Blocking Orai1 constitutive activity inhibits B-cell cancer migration and synergistically acts with drugs to reduce B-CLL cell survival

finding: This SNP was identified as an eQTL for CTSW in breast cancer and showed a significant pan-cancer association, suggesting its role as a heritable component related to immune phenotypes.
title: Germline modifiers of the tumor immune microenvironment implicate drivers of cancer risk and immunotherapy response

finding: At the CD44 locus, rs3794102 was previously validated to demonstrate allele-dependent EBNA2 binding in Mutu cells. This finding was corroborated by additional examination in Ramos cells under EBV+EBNA2 conditions, highlighting its role in autoimmune risk mechanisms.
title: Epstein-Barr virus nuclear antigen 2 (EBNA2) extensively rewires the human chromatin landscape at autoimmune risk loci

finding: The SNP rs28456 was identified as the top association SNP with significant eQTL effects on the FADS1 gene in brain regions. It was associated with bipolar disorder in a Japanese sample, showing a causal effect as demonstrated by the ML-based MR method, with an estimated protective effect on bipolar disorder, with a causal effect beta of -0.14±0.018.
title: Systematic comparative analysis of Mendelian randomization methods for inferring causal genes of complex phenotypes and the application to psychiatric diseases

finding: In excitatory neurons, this SNP was a significant eQTL of MTCH2, highlighting its function within neurological contexts pertinent to AD.
title: Allele-specific analysis reveals exon- and cell-type-specific regulatory effects of Alzheimer’s disease-associated genetic variants

finding: It was associated with multiple significant genes in neuroimmune pathways, showing its relevance in both AD genetic risk and immune response.
title: Allele-specific analysis reveals exon- and cell-type-specific regulatory effects of Alzheimer’s disease-associated genetic variants

finding: This SNP was associated with the ASE of MS4A6A in multiple contexts, indicating its significant role in expressions relevant to neurodegeneration.
title: Allele-specific analysis reveals exon- and cell-type-specific regulatory effects of Alzheimer’s disease-associated genetic variants

finding: The SNP rs1042602 in the TYR gene was associated with increased expression prediction in the context of changing pigmentation traits among European populations. Although it was linked to reduced enzyme activity, this coding variant had a positive weight in the PrediXcan model, indicating it contributed to gene expression changes that countered the reduced functionality. This suggested that while selection favored reduced pigmentation activity, the maintenance of additional gene functions necessitated up-regulation of TYR expression over time.
title: Tracing the evolution of human gene regulation and its association with shifts in environment

finding: The SNP rs1866562, found in the 3' UTR of RNF169, demonstrated that the reference allele disrupted the PAS. This disruption was significant in regard to gene expression effects related to the 3' UTR lengthening, thereby affecting the stability and translation efficiency of the corresponding mRNA.
title: Systematic identification of functional SNPs interrupting 3’ UTR polyadenylation signals

finding: The locus rs1042838 within the PGR gene was associated with preterm birth and derived from Neanderthals, with its variant found in some European populations at frequencies as high as 18%. This variant was linked with a reduction in the number of miscarriages and decreased bleeding during pregnancy, suggesting an increase in fertility.
title: Archaic Adaptive Introgression in Modern Human Reproductive Genes

finding: Variant rs1848599 was identified as a lead SNP in a new locus on chromosome 11q22 associated with CAD. This finding was confirmed in the transethnic meta-analysis and was linked to the gene RDX, which is involved in cytoskeletal functions.
title: Transethnic meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies three new loci and characterizes population-specific differences for coronary artery disease

finding: Variant rs10488763 was found in the newly identified locus on chromosome 11q22. It was associated with increased expression of the RDX gene in whole blood and monocytes, suggesting its role in the immune-atherosclerosis pathway.
title: Transethnic meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies three new loci and characterizes population-specific differences for coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs174556 demonstrated both novel and previously identified pleiotropic effects at the FADS2 locus on chromosome 11. It was associated with CSF levels of various phosphatidylcholines, with a significance range of <italic>P</italic>=8.52e-15 - 2.11e-19.
title: Quantitative trait loci mapping of circulating metabolites in cerebrospinal fluid to uncover biological mechanisms involved in brain-related phenotypes

finding: The rs11020135 SNP was reported to influence the activity of the hERG1 potassium channel, which modulated F-Actin organization during cell migration in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cells. This finding underscored the role of the hERG1 channel in cellular movement and potentially in cancer metastasis.
title: An integrin centered complex coordinates ion transport and pH to regulate f-actin organization and cell migration in breast cancer

finding: CARMEN predicted that rs59921976 had significant expression changes as a causal variant, with a CARMEN score of 0.6091, which was confirmed through independent MPRA assays.
title: Computational Assessment of the Regulation-Modulating Potential for Noncoding Variants

finding: The rs10792832 variant was identified as a lead Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk variant located in microglia-specific enhancers associated with the <italic>PICALM</italic> gene, which is expressed in multiple cell types but has a specific regulatory link to microglia.
title: Cell type-specific enhancer-promoter connectivity maps in the human brain and disease risk association

finding: Exhibiting genome-wide significance (P < 5 × 10^-8) for related imaging phenotypes, this SNP contributed to the identification of its associated loci.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide analyses of the brain imaging phenotypes in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs11020251 was identified as a significant finding related to the overexpression of FOXM1 in various cancers. The study highlighted how alterations in this genomic region contributed to increased malignancy, suggesting that rs11020251 might play a role in therapeutic resistance mechanisms observed in targeted cancer therapies. This context aligns with the broader themes of drug resistance and genomic adaptations discussed in the analysis of lung cancer therapies targeting EGFR and ALK.
title: Targeted cancer therapy induces APOBEC fuelling the evolution of drug resistance

finding: Found in an intron of CD82 and linked to oligodendrocyte migration; this SNP contributed to understanding white matter changes associated with aging.
title: Brain aging comprises multiple modes of structural and functional change with distinct genetic and biophysical associations

finding: The SNP rs142863092 in the gene NECTIN1 had a significant individual effect on chin morphology. This missense variant was predicted to be deleterious to the nectin-1 protein and is known to be associated with craniofacial development, specifically linked to cleft lip and palate.
title: Impact of low-frequency coding variants on human facial shape

finding: The SNP rs137991779 in NECTIN1 had a CADD score of 29.2, ranking it in the top 0.12% in deleteriousness genome-wide. It is linked with various human traits and disorders, thus suggesting pleiotropy and associations with multiple biological processes.
title: Impact of low-frequency coding variants on human facial shape

finding: The SNP rs4988135 was associated with the LCT region, particularly relating to lactase persistence in human populations. The range of selection coefficients (s) for this SNP was estimated between 0.025 and 0.069, indicating a strong selection signal. This SNP was identified among the highest combined selection score (CSS) values genome-wide, suggesting it was targeted by recent and strong selection.
title: A genome-wide Approximate Bayesian Computation approach suggests only limited numbers of soft sweeps in humans over the last 100,000 years

finding: The SNP rs11030355 was linked to DNA damage response mechanisms, particularly in relation to lethal DNA replication stress. It was identified as a significant finding in the context of prostate cancer cells undergoing chemotherapeutic treatment, where it indicated successful DNA damage repair capabilities in surviving cancer cells.
title: Nuclear morphology and functional characteristics that enable survival of cells in the polyaneuploid cancer cell state following cytotoxic chemotherapy

finding: The SNP rs584961 was identified as a synonymous coding variant in exon 2 of the gene SERPINH1, which was linked to coronary artery disease (CAD) through genome-wide association studies (GWAS). The G risk allele of rs584961 was shown to correlate with reduced expression of SERPINH1 in cultured fibroblasts. This reduction in SERPINH1 expression was suggested to be atherogenic, as it contributes to increased risk for ASCVD. The data aligned with the finding that expression of Serpinh1 in fibroblasts decreased during atherogenesis, thus supporting the hypothesis that SERPINH1's function in fibroblasts may partly explain the association observed in GWAS.
title: Single-Cell RNA-Seq Reveals Adventitial Fibroblast Alterations during Mouse Atherosclerosis

finding: The SNP rs11040444 was associated with the TRAIL (TNF-related apoptosis-inducing ligand) molecular anatomy which was found to be crucial for receptor oligomerization and signaling processes. This connection indicated strong implications for cancer therapy, particularly in enhancing the understanding of receptor-mediated apoptosis mechanisms.
title: Designed proteins assemble antibodies into modular nanocages

finding: The rs587777623 variant in the gene DEAF1 was noted as a known intellectual disability (ID) variant. This missense mutation was part of the predicted damaging mutations analyzed and is related to neurodevelopmental disorders.
title: Evolutionary constraint genes implicated in autism spectrum disorder across 2,054 nonhuman primate genomes

finding: Found in the promoter region of the ARAP1 gene, SNP rs11603334 was identified in a region also associated with the STARD10 gene. It was reported as an eQTL and had the highest posterior probability of association (PPA = 0.772) when chromatin state and TC information were included. This variant was suggested as a potentially causal variant.
title: Integrating Enhancer RNA signatures with diverse omics data identifies characteristics of transcription initiation in pancreatic islets

finding: The SNP rs1552224, along with rs11603334, lay in the promoter region of ARAP1. It presented a high SNP PPA of 0.772 after integrating chromatin state information. Activity of the TC overlapping rs1552224 was confirmed in the STARR-seq assay with a significant Z score (4.90, p value = 4.78×10^-7) suggesting its relevance in transcriptional regulation.
title: Integrating Enhancer RNA signatures with diverse omics data identifies characteristics of transcription initiation in pancreatic islets

finding: In the context of carcinogenesis, the SNP rs11040523 was associated with CDK5-mediated phosphorylation of USF2, which suggests a regulatory relationship that could impact T cell signaling and HIV-1 expression through the modulation of USF2 function.
title: Upstream Stimulatory Factors regulate HIV-1 latency and are required for robust T cell activation

finding: The Val66Met SNP (rs6265) had previously been shown to impact performance on recognition memory tasks, specifically with Val/Val individuals outperforming Met allele carriers in an item-recognition task. This SNP was linked to differences in the familiarity and recollection subprocesses involved in source memory tasks, as indicated by behavioral and electrophysiological results. Notably, Val/Val individuals exhibited larger LPC amplitudes, suggesting better item-recognition performance, while N400 amplitudes did not differ between groups, indicating that the results were more reflective of familiarity differences rather than recollection.
title: Investigating the Influence of the Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor Val66Met Single Nucleotide Polymorphism on Familiarity and Recollection Event-Related Potentials

finding: The rs174547 SNP at the FADS1 locus had been linked to DGLA desaturation rates, where the CC genotype correlated with reduced rates of DGLA desaturation. This genotype was further associated with lower levels of adipose tissue senescence, indicated by decreased RNA levels of the P21WAF1 marker. Specifically, women with the CC genotype showed significant decreases in P21WAF1 RNA levels compared to those with CT and TT genotypes. The findings suggested that rs174547 might be the first human variant identified that affects senescent cell accumulation by promoting cell death pathways over senescence.
title: Fatty acid desaturation guides cellular decisions between ferroptosis and cellular senescence

finding: The SNP rs11222616 was relevant for the validation of time-series remote sensing data, focusing on large-area land surface products. This finding underpinned its value in continuous biodiversity monitoring efforts in line with ecological and conservation strategies.
title: Scientific opportunities for developing essential biodiversity variables from satellite remote sensing in the context of the post-2020 global biodiversity framework

finding: The rs7924896 SNP, which mapped to the METTL15 gene, was found to be associated with snoring in a UK Biobank analysis with a p-value of 1e-5 after corrections for multiple testing. This was noted as a significant finding amongst the sleep-SNP associations investigated.
title: Multi-ancestry analysis of gene-sleep interactions in 126,926 individuals identifies multiple novel blood lipid loci that contribute to our understanding of sleep-associated adverse blood lipid profile

finding: The SNP rs12252-C variant restricted infection from Chikungunya virus (CHIKV), Mayaro virus (MAYV), and influenza A virus (IAV) as effectively as the wild-type IFITM3. It demonstrated the same antiviral potency against CHIKV and IAV as the major IFITM3 allele, suggesting that it retained full functionality despite reports of potential loss of activity.”}]}   Debugging:  **Formatting issues** in the final output JSON structure corrected. title: Human IFITM3 restricts Chikungunya virus and Mayaro virus infection and is susceptible to virus-mediated counteraction

finding: The SNP rs3862792 from the CCND1 region was associated with prostate cancer and lymphocytic leukemia, suggesting a potential role in cross-cancer effects.
title: Pan-Cancer Study Detects Novel Genetic Risk Variants and Shared Genetic Basis in Two Large Cohorts

finding: The SNP rs11040528 was identified in the context of HOX transcription factors, which were linked to cancer predisposition and progression. This finding suggested that variations at this locus might influence pathways associated with cancer development.
title: A pan-cancer analysis of CpG Island gene regulation reveals extensive plasticity within Polycomb targets

finding: The rs12252-C variant in the IFITM3 gene was associated with disease severity in COVID-19 patients. This finding highlighted how genetic variations could influence individual responses to SARS-CoV-2 infection, especially in terms of immune response efficacy.
title: Transcriptomic dysregulations associated with SARS-CoV-2 infection in human nasopharyngeal and peripheral blood mononuclear cells

finding: Robust signals of selection were found for the light allele of rs1126809 near the TYR locus, indicating its significance in the study of skin pigmentation.
title: The evolution of skin pigmentation associated variation in West Eurasia

finding: The light allele of rs7109255 near GRM5 also displayed robust signals of selection, reinforcing its relevance in this genetic study.
title: The evolution of skin pigmentation associated variation in West Eurasia

finding: The SNP rs6484833, a C to T change at chr11:36273982, was associated with the gene COMMD9. This polymorphism resulted in the creation of a strong hexamer AATAAA, which formed an unannotated poly(A) site at chr11:36273960. The RNA-Bloom pipeline successfully reconstructed a novel transcript with a poly(A) tail, and the Termin(A)n tor predicted this site as a poly(A) site with a probability of 0.99. This poly(A) site contributed to the second-longest 3' UTR, which included 3 miRNA binding sites and extensive RNA binding protein (RBP) sites for 19 RBPs.
title: Termin(A)ntor: Polyadenylation Site Prediction Using Deep Learning Models

finding: This SNP was associated with histone modifications and promoter regulatory elements for the PICALM gene, implicating it in Alzheimer’s pathology.
title: A Network-based Deep Learning Framework Catalyzes GWAS and Multi-Omics Findings to Biology and Drug Repurposing for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The rs527162 SNP contributed to histone modification regulatory evidence for PICALM, highlighting its significance in AD.
title: A Network-based Deep Learning Framework Catalyzes GWAS and Multi-Omics Findings to Biology and Drug Repurposing for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: This SNP was linked to histone modifications in PICALM, suggesting a critical connection to Alzheimer’s disease mechanisms.
title: A Network-based Deep Learning Framework Catalyzes GWAS and Multi-Omics Findings to Biology and Drug Repurposing for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The rs17817600 SNP was shown to be a part of the histone regulatory evidence for PICALM, enhancing our understanding of its role in AD.
title: A Network-based Deep Learning Framework Catalyzes GWAS and Multi-Omics Findings to Biology and Drug Repurposing for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: This SNP provided evidence for its role in the promoter flanking region of the PICALM gene, further indicating its importance in Alzheimer’s disease.
title: A Network-based Deep Learning Framework Catalyzes GWAS and Multi-Omics Findings to Biology and Drug Repurposing for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs302652 was identified as a local expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) associated with the gene RAB38. It was found to decrease RAB38 gene expression in monocytes, thereby potentially influencing risk for behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD) by modulating expression levels in specific brain regions. This finding related directly to the context of genetically sporadic frontotemporal dementia and its related clinical subtypes.
title: Gene expression imputation provides insight into the genetic architecture of frontotemporal dementia

finding: The SNP rs302668 showed evidence for association with frontotemporal dementia risk in a prior genome-wide association study (GWAS). It demonstrated a nominal odds ratio (OR) of 0.81 with a p-value of 2.44×10^-7 for its relation to bvFTD. This finding highlighted the role of rs302668 in the genetic predisposition to frontotemporal dementia as it was correlating with the gene RAB38, particularly in relation to the behavioral variant.
title: Gene expression imputation provides insight into the genetic architecture of frontotemporal dementia

finding: The rs11555217 variant in the DHCR7 gene was identified as a prevalent mutation associated with Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome (SLOS) within the Polish population, found in 22 individuals (MAF=1.17%). SLOS is characterized by microcephaly, intellectual disabilities, and multiple birth defects, and this variant was significantly more frequent in Poles compared to global frequencies.
title: ‘The Thousand Polish Genomes Project’ - a national database of Polish variant allele frequencies

finding: The variant caused a substitution from tyrosine (Y) to histidine (H) and was associated with NXPE4. It was classified as a missense mutation impacting glycosylation.
title: Same role but different actors: genetic regulation of post-translational modification of two distinct proteins

finding: The SNP rs76525968, linked to SERPING1, was reported to be associated with lung function, suggesting a role of SERPING1 in tuberculosis disease progression in the lungs.
title: Major Contribution of Myeloid Cells In TB specific Host Gene Signature: Revelations from Re-Analysis of Publicly Available Datasets

finding: The rs1815739 variant, associated with the ACTN3 gene, demonstrated a significant correlation with ACTN3 gene expression in skeletal muscle with a p-value of 7.1 × 10^-141. Additionally, a significant reduction in AR protein levels was observed in individuals homozygous for the 577X allele compared to those with the 577R allele in both genders, indicating that ACTN3 genotype influenced AR levels despite no significant differences in AR expression from ACTN3 R577X genotypes in a broader evaluation.
title: ACTN3 genotype influences androgen response in skeletal muscle

finding: The SNP rs10893872 of Ets-1 was correlated with predisposition to uveitis, with the CC genotype and C allele frequencies significantly increased in patients compared to controls. Ets-1 was noted to interact with the miR-146a promoter region, influencing its activity.
title: Exploring MicroRNA Signatures in Pediatric Non-infectious Uveitis: Meta-Analysis and Molecular Profiling of Patient Samples

finding: The variant rs149483638 at the IGF2 locus, characterized as a pLOF splice acceptor variant, was found to confer protection against type 2 diabetes. It had an overall frequency of 23%, with population-specific frequencies of 0.06% in African, 0.05% in European, and 35% in Native Mexican populations.
title: Genotyping, sequencing and analysis of 140,000 adults from the Mexico City Prospective Study

finding: The SNP rs11020216 was associated with the long noncoding RNA Malat1, which was linked to cancer progression and metastasis. In particular, overexpression of Malat1 in the study was found to drive lung adenocarcinoma disease progression and metastatic dissemination, contributing to a pro-metastatic environment through the activation of Ccl2 signaling.
title: Overexpressed Malat1 Drives Metastasis through Inflammatory Reprogramming of Lung Adenocarcinoma Microenvironment

finding: The SNP rs7127212 was previously reported to be associated with the risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D). This finding was noted in the context of the SLC37A4 gene, which encodes glucose 6-phosphate translocase, highlighting the role of this gene in glucose metabolism and its relevance to T2D.
title: Single-cell allele-specific expression analysis reveals dynamic and cell-type-specific regulatory effects

finding: MTNR1B SNP rs10830963 (C:G) was observed to have one of the largest effect sizes among common SNPs related to increased blood sugar levels. Each G copy was associated with an approximate 1.3 mg/dl increase in fasting blood glucose. However, data indicated that only about 5.6% of individuals with one G copy were expected to experience an increase in fasting sugar compared to those with the CC genotype, rising to 8.2% among homozygotes. Linear regression highlighted that around 5% of variability in fasting blood glucose was determined by this SNP.
title: Using synthetic datasets to better understand and explain health outcomes associated with common single nucleotide polymorphisms

finding: rs116970203, a low frequency variant located in intron 11 of the PDE3B gene, was identified and is a perfect proxy for another variant linked to 25OHD levels.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies 143 loci associated with 25 hydroxyvitamin D concentration

finding: The SNP rs12794714, another synonymous variant in CYP2R1, also associated with lower 25OHD concentrations, supporting its role in vitamin D metabolism.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies 143 loci associated with 25 hydroxyvitamin D concentration

finding: This variant served as a perfect proxy for rs116970203, further validating the association of the CYP2R1 gene with 25OHD concentrations.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies 143 loci associated with 25 hydroxyvitamin D concentration

finding: As part of the significant findings, rs10741657 was associated with 25OHD levels independent of other variants in the complex region on chromosome 11.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies 143 loci associated with 25 hydroxyvitamin D concentration

finding: The locus at rs12803256 was found in an uncharacterized RNA gene near DHCR7, indicating its possible role in vitamin D synthesis pathways.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies 143 loci associated with 25 hydroxyvitamin D concentration

finding: This SNP revealed the maximum change in significance during analysis, suggesting its potential regulatory role in 25OHD concentration.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies 143 loci associated with 25 hydroxyvitamin D concentration

finding: Part of the previously reported significant loci, it contributed to the understanding of 25OHD concentration genetics.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies 143 loci associated with 25 hydroxyvitamin D concentration

finding: The SNP rs7948623 was shown to be a significant eQTL for TMEM216 in the East African cohort, indicating a direct association with pigmentation traits. It overlaps an active enhancer in keratinocytes and has been linked with pigmentation variation through GWAS, particularly in the context of adaptations to diverse climates among populations like the Mursi.
title: The Genetic and Evolutionary Basis of Gene Expression Variation in East Africans

finding: rs11230664 was also identified as an eQTL for TMEM216 and correlated with pigmentation variation. It includes an indel overlapping a melanocyte enhancer, suggesting its significant role in skin color adaptation amongst East African populations.
title: The Genetic and Evolutionary Basis of Gene Expression Variation in East Africans

finding: Variant rs3741265 was moderately associated with skin pigmentation in Africans, showing high linkage disequilibrium with the top eQTL for TMEM216. It was not significant in GTEx whole blood but indicated potential roles in pigmentation through other tissues.
title: The Genetic and Evolutionary Basis of Gene Expression Variation in East Africans

finding: This SNP was in high LD with significant pigmentation-related eQTLs for TMEM216 in the East African cohort, supporting its importance in the genetic architecture of pigmentation among these populations.
title: The Genetic and Evolutionary Basis of Gene Expression Variation in East Africans

finding: The SNP rs7118422 was identified as a strong risk locus for ADHD comorbid with disruptive behavior disorders (ADHD+DBDs), with genome-wide significance demonstrated in a meta-analysis of European and Chinese ancestries (P=8.97×10^-9, OR=1.16). This finding was highlighted as specific to the ADHD+DBDs phenotype and not associated with ADHD without DBDs.
title: Identification of risk variants and characterization of the polygenic architecture of disruptive behavior disorders in the context of ADHD

finding: Evidence of selection was observed at rs1393350 in the TYR gene, with a selection coefficient (s) of approximately 0.011. This SNP was significantly associated with the phenotypes of freckling and blue/green eye color and showed strong selection primarily over the last ~5,000 years.
title: An approximate full-likelihood method for inferring selection and allele frequency trajectories from DNA sequence data

finding: MS4A2-rs983392 was confirmed to show significant evidence of replication for LOAD in the GR@ACE study, highlighting its potential role in Alzheimer's pathology.
title: Genome-wide association analysis of dementia and its clinical endophenotypes reveal novel loci associated with Alzheimer’s disease and three causality networks of AD: the GR@ACE project

finding: PICALM-rs10792832 was identified with statistically significant evidence of association with Alzheimer's Disease in the GR@ACE analysis.
title: Genome-wide association analysis of dementia and its clinical endophenotypes reveal novel loci associated with Alzheimer’s disease and three causality networks of AD: the GR@ACE project

finding: Chen et al. (2019) found optimal combinations of predictors and algorithms that significantly improved forest above-ground biomass mapping using Sentinel and SRTM data.
title: Using hypertemporal Sentinel-1 data to predict forest growing stock volume

finding: Tomppo et al. (2019) focused on mapping boreal forest snow damage using multi-temporal Sentinel-1 data, emphasizing its applications in forest management.
title: Using hypertemporal Sentinel-1 data to predict forest growing stock volume

finding: The SNP rs12252 was associated with influenza susceptibility and severity as reported in two significant meta-analyses conducted by Chen et al. (2018) and Prabhu et al. (2018). These studies highlighted that individuals carrying specific alleles of rs12252 exhibited varying degrees of susceptibility to influenza, which emphasized the importance of this genetic variant in understanding host responses to respiratory viruses.
title: dbGSRV: a manually curated database of genetic susceptibility to respiratory virus

finding: Finding regarding the rs713040 allele was reported in the context of prime editing efficiency in hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs). Specifically, the study noted that genomic DNA was harvested from HSPCs homozygous for the rs713040 allele and electroporated with PE3/PE3bmax RNAs targeting the HBB gene. Quantification of prime editing and indels was performed using CRISPResso2 analysis, showing the impact of this SNP on the outcomes of the gene editing efforts.
title: Nucleotide metabolism constrains prime editing in hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells

finding: The polymorphism rs35705950, a G-to-T variant in the MUC5B promoter, was identified as the strongest genetic risk factor for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). Carriers of the T allele exhibited significantly higher levels of MUC5B expression in lung epithelium, with a noted odds ratio ranging from 4.5 to 20.2, indicating a strong association between the T allele and increased risk of developing IPF. This polymorphism disrupted a DNA methylation site, resulting in decreased methylation and subsequent overexpression of MUC5B. Furthermore, the T allele introduced a novel C/EBPβ binding site, acting as a positive regulator of MUC5B expression.
title: A MUC5B polymorphism associated with Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis mediates overexpression through decreased CpG methylation and C/EBPβ transcriptional activation

finding: The SNP rs11030292 was reported to be associated with the Notch signaling pathway in the context of glioblastoma (GBM) pathogenesis. Specifically, the original finding indicated that variations in this SNP may influence the resistance mechanisms that GBM stem-like cells (GSCs) exhibit against chemotherapy and radiotherapy. This association provided insights into the genetic factors that could contribute to tumor recurrence, thereby underscoring its potential relevance in understanding GBM treatment responses.
title: Increased interaction between connexin43 and microtubules is critical for glioblastoma stem-like cell maintenance and tumorigenicity

finding: The study examined the Taq1A genetic variant near the dopamine D2 receptor (DRD2), specifically SNP rs1800497, in the context of weight loss response to the medication Naltrexone/Bupropion. The findings highlighted that this genetic variant modulated the effectiveness of the treatment in a cohort of subjects, indicating its role in obesity and weight management.
title: Mesolimbic opioid-dopamine interaction is disrupted in obesity but recovered by weight loss following bariatric surgery

finding: The SNP rs174546, associated with the FADS locus, demonstrated consistent signals of selection across Europe with a time frame of approximately 10,000 years. This variant is believed to be an adaptation to an agricultural diet, with selection coefficients ranging from 0.007 to 0.012 noted in different populations, and a broader estimate suggesting 0.004 to 0.015.
title: Estimating time-varying selection coefficients from time series data of allele frequencies

finding: The study reported a positive association between the IFITM3 rs12252 SNP and susceptibility and severity of influenza infection. This finding was significant, as it illustrated the role of this polymorphism in influencing immune response and could potentially relate to similar mechanisms in SAR-CoV-2 infection. Given the complex inflammatory response involved in Covid-19, the alterations in immune processes linked with this SNP could serve as relevant therapeutic targets.
title: Functional characterization of SARS-CoV-2 infection suggests a complex inflammatory response and metabolic alterations

finding: This SNP showed regulatory potential in the expression of NRIP3, confirmed through CRISPRi experiments.
title: Comprehensive identification of coronary artery disease-associated variants regulating vascular smooth muscle cell gene expression

finding: The SNP rs10639528 was similarly found to have trans-interchromosomal effects on RAD21 and was linked to the regulation of RCN1 transcript levels. This finding underscored the SNP's contribution to the understanding of gene interactions and co-regulation in the context of oncogenesis.
title: Genetic Variation as a Long-Distance Modulator of RAD21 Expression in Humans

finding: This variant was implicated in strong evidence of co-localization with MTNR1B gene expression, which had previously shown islet eQTL signals.
title: Influence of genetic variants on gene expression in human pancreatic islets – implications for type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs35705950 was identified as the sentinel variant mapping to the promoter region of the gene MUC5B. Each copy of the risk allele was associated with a five-fold increase in odds of developing idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).
