Despite its strong association, the risk allele frequency was significantly different between cases (35%) and the general population (11%), indicating that it did not fully explain the risk for IPF.
title: Genome-wide association study of susceptibility to idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

finding: The SNP rs1042602 was associated with changes in DNAm sites, further elucidating its role in pigmentation and potential links to skin cancers.
title: Investigating DNA methylation as a potential mediator between pigmentation genes, pigmentary traits and skin cancer

finding: The SNP rs878913005, which corresponds to the Arg1201Trp variant in MUC5AC, was positively associated with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) and Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF). In a cohort of 1,139 COPD patients, this SNP was found at a frequency of 0.3740, compared to 0.3397 in a control group of 5,196, indicating a statistically significant increase at p<0.05. Additionally, in a smaller IPF cohort of 107 patients, an increase in frequency of 0.1556 (46%) with significant p<0.01 was observed. The study suggested that the presence of both this SNP and the MUC5B SNP (rs35705950) significantly enhances the association with IPF.
title: Structural mechanism of MUC5AC mucin net-like polymer formation and its SNP variability that affect risk of the lung diseases COPD and IPF

finding: The SNP rs35705950, located in the promotor region of MUC5B, exhibited a significant association with IPF, with a frequency of 0.3194 observed in the cohort implying a substantial role in increased risk for this disease. The study noted that the combination of this SNP with MUC5AC SNP could strengthen the association of lung disease, particularly IPF, demonstrated by a tripling of occurrence when both SNPs were present as opposed to only the MUC5B SNP in isolation.
title: Structural mechanism of MUC5AC mucin net-like polymer formation and its SNP variability that affect risk of the lung diseases COPD and IPF

finding: The Taq1A polymorphism (rs1800497) in the ANKK1 gene, which affects the expression of the DRD2 gene, was implicated in the interaction where increased temporal impulsivity combined with a disadvantageous genotype might contribute to obesity development in men. This demonstrated a significant association between DRD2/ANKK1 genetic variability, temporal impulsivity, and BMI.
title: DRD2/ANKK1 Taq1A but not COMT single nucleotide polymorphisms contribute to the link between temporal impulsivity and obesity in men

finding: The study found rs12293022 to produce increased expression with the alternate T allele (FC=1.62, FDR q=0.036), marking it as a significant variant within the SLE risk haplotype.
title: Massively Parallel Reporter Assay Confirms Regulatory Potential of hQTLs and Reveals Important Variants in Lupus and Other Autoimmune Diseases

finding: It was identified as an hQTL in intron 2 of OVOL1, influencing expression in relation to the reference A allele with FC of 0.61 and FDR q=0.038, highlighting its importance in regulatory mechanisms associated with SLE.
title: Massively Parallel Reporter Assay Confirms Regulatory Potential of hQTLs and Reveals Important Variants in Lupus and Other Autoimmune Diseases

finding: It was noted that rs658676 produced an AE with the reference C allele (FC=0.57, FDR q=0.0005) and was the only variant in its region showing significant modulation.
title: Massively Parallel Reporter Assay Confirms Regulatory Potential of hQTLs and Reveals Important Variants in Lupus and Other Autoimmune Diseases

finding: The SNP rs4936277 was identified as significant in the genome-wide association study (GWAS) of Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) and was one of the SNPs previously associated with alcohol dependence in the findings.
title: Genome-wide Association Study of Alcohol Consumption and Use Disorder in Multiple Populations (N = 274,424)

finding: rs61902812 was also linked to AUD in the recent GWAS and was previously associated with alcohol dependence, confirming its importance in the genetic architecture of AUD.
title: Genome-wide Association Study of Alcohol Consumption and Use Disorder in Multiple Populations (N = 274,424)

finding: The SNP rs141845179 near the HBB gene was associated with eGFR (p = 3.0 x 10^-8). However, its significance was lost after conditioning on a previously reported SNP (rs334), which is also linked to kidney traits. Despite this, fine-mapping analyses indicated that rs141845179 was the most likely causal variant at the HBB locus, accounting for 61% of the posterior probability.
title: Discovery and fine-mapping of kidney function loci in first genome-wide association study in Africans

finding: The analysis revealed strong allele-specific enhancer activity for the rs11222369 SNP in primary mouse neuronal cultures, with the G allele showing significantly reduced MPRA activity compared to the A allele. In human post-mortem prefrontal cortex (PFC) tissue, the GG genotype resulted in significantly reduced expression of the SNX19 gene, indicating its potential role in schizophrenia.
title: Cell type and condition specific functional annotation of schizophrenia associated non-coding genetic variants

finding: The SNP rs174559 was identified as an eQTL for miR-1908, which exhibited colocalization with HbA1c and blood glucose levels. This association suggested that rs174559 may play a crucial role in the genetic regulation of glycemic traits. The research also indicated possible pleiotropic effects, as the SNP was associated with RCDW, further emphasizing its impact on metabolic processes.
title: Human pancreatic islet microRNAs implicated in diabetes and related traits by large-scale genetic analysis

finding: The SNP rs11030343 was linked to the presence of Panx2 in various brain regions of zebrafish, particularly in visual centers like the optic tectum and thalamus. The study showcased that this SNP was associated with altered expression of vision-related genes in Panx2 knockout larvae, which led to significant behavioral changes in visual perception, including reduced locomotor activity in light and increased activity in dark conditions. Notably, the knockout larvae also exhibited impaired optomotor response, further establishing the connection between this SNP and ocular health issues such as myopia.
title: Pannexin-2 deficiency disrupts visual pathways and leads to ocular defects in zebrafish

finding: This variant caused the P1054R coding mutation in ATM, a gene linked to HSC function, and was identified among missense mutations relevant to cancer risk.
title: Genetic predisposition to myeloproliferative neoplasms implicates hematopoietic stem cell biology

finding: A 928-bp deletion upstream of INSR at chromosome 19 (chr19:7,258,353-7,259,281) was found in strong LD (r2=0.979) with rs12798472 at chr19:7,257,979, which was significantly associated with systolic blood pressure (P=1×10−58). This finding suggested that the SV impacted the regulatory region influencing blood pressure.
title: Structural variation across 138,134 samples in the TOPMed consortium

finding: Variant rs17309874 was also recognized in the context of lifetime smoking influencing WC<sub>adjBMI</sub>, linking a genetic predisposition to smoking with abdominal fat outcomes.
title: Estimating the causal relationship between smoking and abdominal adiposity using Mendelian randomization

finding: The SNP rs11040527 showed a connection with PSMD3's regulation of breast cancer by stabilizing HER2 from degradation, which was relevant to breast cancer mechanisms.
title: A Comprehensive Meta-Analysis of Breast Cancer Gene Expression

finding: The SNP rs77147099 was associated with recurrence of mild malaria infections (RMI) and is located in the ACER3 gene at the 11q13.5 region, showing a p-value of 6.85×10-8.
title: First genome-wide association study of non-severe malaria in two birth cohorts in Benin

finding: The SNP rs4938573 was identified as a risk allele associated with the DDX6-CXCR5 region linked to Sjogren's Disease (SjD) and Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). It was noted for its role in impairing CXCR5 expression in CD19+ B cells from SjD patients and was correlated with increased infiltration of CXCR5+ immune cells in the salivary gland.
title: Variants in the DDX6-CXCR5 autoimmune disease risk locus influence the regulatory network in immune cells and salivary gland

finding: The SNP rs57494551 was found to position within the first intron of DDX6 and impacted nuclear protein binding and promoter activity. It showed evidence of enhanced regulatory activity affecting both DDX6 and CXCR5 expression in B cells, suggesting a regulatory role in immune response mechanisms relevant to SjD and SLE.
title: Variants in the DDX6-CXCR5 autoimmune disease risk locus influence the regulatory network in immune cells and salivary gland

finding: The SNP rs4938572 demonstrated increased enhancer and promoter activity in immune cell types, particularly Jurkat cells. Its risk allele was linked with differential expression of genes, including DDX6, within the context of SjD/SLE-associated genetic risk, showcasing its functional significance in immune modulation.
title: Variants in the DDX6-CXCR5 autoimmune disease risk locus influence the regulatory network in immune cells and salivary gland

finding: The SNP rs4936443 exhibited increased nuclear protein binding compared to the non-risk allele in multiple immune cell types. It was tied to enhancer/promoter activities that potentially influences gene expression within the DDX6-CXCR5 region important for autoimmune responses.
title: Variants in the DDX6-CXCR5 autoimmune disease risk locus influence the regulatory network in immune cells and salivary gland

finding: The SNP rs7117261 was confirmed to increase promoter activity in specific cell types while showing variations in enhancer activity across others, indicating its relevante role in modulating gene expression connected to immune processes in SjD and SLE.
title: Variants in the DDX6-CXCR5 autoimmune disease risk locus influence the regulatory network in immune cells and salivary gland

finding: The SNP rs11030287 exhibited a connection to the regulation of voltage-gated potassium channels, particularly in the context of neoplastic cell proliferation. The research established that these channels are critical for maintaining cell membrane potential and influencing cellular behaviors associated with proliferation, highlighting the SNP's relevance to cancer biology.
title: Voltage-dependent volume regulation controls epithelial cell extrusion and morphology

finding: The association between SNP rs2403254 and the metabolite 2-hydroxyisovalerate was initially incorrectly attributed to the HPS5 gene, as stated in the original GWAS publication. However, this association was later refuted and re-annotated to be driven by the LDHA gene located at the same locus. This correction came from experimental evidence demonstrating that the SNP-metabolite association was indeed caused by LDHA. This finding highlighted the importance of accurate genetic variant annotation in metabolomic studies.
title: piTracer - Automatic reconstruction of molecular cascades for the identification of synergistic drug targets

finding: The SNP rs7111031 had previously been associated with broadly defined depression, providing insights into its role in mood disturbance.
title: Multivariate GWAS of psychiatric disorders and their cardinal symptoms reveal two dimensions of cross-cutting genetic liabilities

finding: This SNP was noted for its association with schizophrenia, supporting its relevance in the genetic architecture of serious mental illness.
title: Multivariate GWAS of psychiatric disorders and their cardinal symptoms reveal two dimensions of cross-cutting genetic liabilities

finding: The SNP rs1815739 was found to be located within the ACTN3 gene, which is known to be involved in muscle contractions. The study reported a significant synergistic effect with related SNP rs362584, which was beneficial for identifying elite gymnasts as opposed to sedentary individuals.
title: Detection of epistasis between ACTN3 and SNAP-25 with an insight towards gymnastic aptitude identification

finding: The SNP rs34481144, located in the promoter region of IFITM3, was linked to lower mRNA levels of IFITM3 and was strongly associated with increased disease severity in cohorts infected with influenza. The majority G allele was associated with higher IFITM3 expression, while the minority C allele correlated with a reduced number of antiviral CD8+ T cells in the lung tissue of individuals infected with influenza A virus (IAV).
title: IFITM3 regulates virus-induced inflammatory cytokine production by titrating Nogo-B orchestration of TLR responses

finding: The CC genotype of the rs12252 SNP, found in exon 1 of IFITM3, was associated with increased severity of influenza A virus infections across multiple studies. Carriers of the CC genotype exhibited elevated levels of cytotoxic CCL2, leading to pathogenic monocyte responses and hypercytokinemia, characterized by elevated IL-6 levels. This hypercytokinemia was also linked to fatal H7N9 infections among individuals carrying the rs12252 CC genotype.
title: IFITM3 regulates virus-induced inflammatory cytokine production by titrating Nogo-B orchestration of TLR responses

finding: The SNP rs4246215 showed that miR-1236 specifically targeted the G allele over the T allele in the 3'-UTR of Flap endonuclease 1. This finding illustrated the regulatory impact of miR-1236 on the expression of genes associated with the alleles.
title: An alternative miRISC targeting a coding mutation site in FOXL2 links to granulosa cell tumor

finding: The SNP rs10437655 was highlighted as a significant variant within the example LOAD GWAS locus involving genes CELF1 and SPI1. In the context of the association statistics reported by Jansen et al., this SNP showcased a strong association with cognitive domains affected during the progression of late-onset Alzheimer's Disease (LOAD). Despite its significant association, the research emphasized the challenges faced in pinpointing the exact causal genes within this genomic locus, suggesting the complexity of genetic contributions to LOAD pathology.
title: A systems biology-based identification and in vivo functional screening of Alzheimer’s disease risk genes reveals modulators of memory function

finding: The CCND1 rs9344 polymorphism was investigated for its association with breast cancer, suggesting its importance in cancer progression.
title: The Identification of Key Genes and Biological Pathways in Polycystic Ovary Syndrome and its Complications by Next Generation Squancing (NGS) and Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: This SNP was located in a region with significant evidence of adaptive introgression and was identified as a GTEx eQTL for BRSK2. The Neanderthal allele was hypothesized to influence gene regulation in the context of glucose metabolism.
title: A signature of Neanderthal introgression on molecular mechanisms of environmental responses

finding: The SNP rs3794087 located in the SLC1A2 gene was identified as being associated with susceptibility to Parkinson's disease (PD) in a specific Chinese population. This association highlighted its relevance to PD while indicating that it was not related to essential tremor, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or multiple system atrophy, which provided a clear context for its significance in understanding genetic factors contributing to PD.
title: Defining specific cell states of MPTP-induced Parkinson’s disease by single-nucleus RNA sequencing

finding: The SNP rs11232752 was linked to the establishment of plot-yield prediction models in soybean breeding programs using UAV-based hyperspectral remote sensing. This finding was published by Zhang et al. (2019), illustrating the use of advanced remote sensing techniques for improving yield predictions in soybean thereby enhancing crop management practices.
title: Time-series Multi-spectral Imaging in Soybean for Improving Biomass and Genomic Prediction Accuracy

finding: The SNP rs3794087 was linked to the SLC1A2 gene, which is associated with the risk for restless legs syndrome (RLS). This finding highlighted the genetic contribution of the glutamate transporter SLC1A2 in the pathophysiology of RLS, suggesting that variations in this gene could influence neuronal signaling and thus impact the development of this condition.
title: A novel post-developmental role of the Hox genes underlies normal adult behaviour

finding: The SNP rs73036086 showed significant allelic differences in both K562 and SH-SY5Y cell lines, influencing gene expression. It was associated with several genes in gene expression studies.
title: A screen of 1,049 schizophrenia and 30 Alzheimer’s-associated variants for regulatory potential

finding: The rs33930165 variant, a hemoglobin missense variant, was associated with increased white blood cell count (WBC) in individuals of African descent (AA) with a p-value of 8.1×10^-12. Its minor allele (T) encoded an abnormal form of hemoglobin, Hb C, and although associated with WBC, there were no individuals identified with Hb C disease in the study, suggesting the association was not driven by inflammatory responses from disease states.
title: Use of >100,000 NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Consortium whole genome sequences improves imputation quality and detection of rare variant associations in admixed African and Hispanic/Latino populations

finding: The rs11549407 variant, identified as a stop-gain variant in the HBB gene, was associated with lower hemoglobin (HGB) and hematocrit (HCT) levels in Hispanic/Latino populations, with p-values of 1.59×10^-12 for HGB and 1.13×10^-9 for HCT. The allele frequency was extremely low in the study cohort, leading to its classification as pathogenic in ClinVar.
title: Use of >100,000 NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Consortium whole genome sequences improves imputation quality and detection of rare variant associations in admixed African and Hispanic/Latino populations

finding: The SNP rs4244842 was identified as an eQTL associated with ejection fraction (EF) in African American samples. It was located approximately 15kb downstream of the MRGPRD gene on Chromosome 11, and significant differential gene expression effects were noted in heart-related cell types.
title: Transcriptional Variabilities in Human hiPSC-derived Cardiomyocytes: All Genes Are Not Equal and Their Robustness May Foretell Donor’s Disease Susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs11228427 was also found to be an eQTL linked to ejection fraction (EF) in African American samples, located about 12kb downstream of the MRGPRD gene on Chromosome 11. Interestingly, it exhibited opposite effects in left ventricle (LV) and aorta tissues.
title: Transcriptional Variabilities in Human hiPSC-derived Cardiomyocytes: All Genes Are Not Equal and Their Robustness May Foretell Donor’s Disease Susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs636049 was categorized as an eQTL related to left ventricular mass (LV mass). Located in an intron of the MRPL21 gene on Chromosome 11, it showed substantial positive effects in all four heart-related tissues analyzed.
title: Transcriptional Variabilities in Human hiPSC-derived Cardiomyocytes: All Genes Are Not Equal and Their Robustness May Foretell Donor’s Disease Susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs12252 in IFITM3 was associated with an N-terminal 21-amino acid truncation resulting from an alteration in the splice acceptor site, contributing to increased severity of influenza virus infection. A meta-analysis confirmed the correlation between the minority allele of this SNP and influenza severity in over 16,000 subjects.
title: A rare variant in ANP32B impairs influenza virus replication in human cells

finding: The SNP rs11040466 was associated with findings related to the study of glioblastoma, particularly implicating Vimentin in glioblastoma cell migration. This was detailed in the proteomic analysis conducted by Nowicki et al., where the impact of the SNP on cellular processes in glioblastoma was explored, emphasizing the relationship between genetic variations and the biological behavior of the tumor.
title: Proteomics and phosphoproteomics profiling of the co-formulation of type I and II interferons, HeberFERON, in the glioblastoma-derived cell line U-87 MG

finding: The rs1582763 variant in the MS4A locus was found to increase MS4A4A expression. This expression was upregulated by DSS treatment in the study but not when the mice were also treated with DSP-4, indicating that LC injury dampened the neuroprotective response during colitis. The MS4A variant was previously associated with a reduced risk of Alzheimer's disease, suggesting its role in promoting healthy lipid metabolism and reducing chemokine signaling in microglia.
title: Locus coeruleus injury modulates ventral midbrain neuroinflammation during DSS-induced colitis

finding: The SNP rs7949048 was identified as having a genome-wide significant association with effective bone mineral density (eBMD), with a p-value of 3.1E-12. This significant result was linked to the gene SLC37A2, which encodes a sugar transporter involved in the function of secretory lysosomes in osteoclasts. The study highlighted the importance of SLC37A2 in bone metabolism, indicating that variations in this SNP may influence bone mass and metabolism through its role in the osteoclast's secretory apparatus.
title: Sugar transporter Slc37a2 regulates bone metabolism via a dynamic tubular lysosomal network in osteoclasts

finding: The SNP rs174541 was found to be significantly associated (p = 4.3 × 10⁻⁵) with factor 7, which correlates with lipid metabolism. This SNP is also reported in GWAS for type-2 diabetes, suggesting its relevance to metabolic disorders.
title: Multiset correlation and factor analysis enables exploration of multi-omic data

finding: The SNP rs174549 demonstrated a significant association (p = 5.6 × 10⁻⁵) with factor 7, linked to blood lipid studies. It is also noted in GWAS relating to white blood cell count, indicating its potential impact on immune response.
title: Multiset correlation and factor analysis enables exploration of multi-omic data

finding: The SNP rs1535 was significantly associated (p = 8.3 × 10⁻⁵) with factor 7, which relates to lipid metabolism. This SNP has also been identified in GWAS associated with inflammatory bowel disease, highlighting its possible role in inflammatory processes.
title: Multiset correlation and factor analysis enables exploration of multi-omic data

finding: rs11603014 emerged as a new significant variant associated with the gene RP11-890B15.2, indicating its relevance in psychiatric conditions.
title: Multivariate GWAS of psychiatric disorders and their cardinal symptoms reveal two dimensions of cross-cutting genetic liabilities

finding: The SNP rs1973765 was identified as part of the most significantly BrCa-associated LD block, correlating with LSP1 regulatory regions, including binding sites for immune regulatory transcription factors. It was found to be predictive of altered LSP1 expression in leukocytes, highlighting its role in breast cancer incidence and outcome.
title: Machine Learning Reveals Genetic Modifiers of the Immune Microenvironment of Cancer

finding: The SNP rs4980389 was identified as a functional SNP (fSNP) within the LSP1 locus, predicted to disrupt a binding site for transcriptional regulators involved in immune and inflammatory signaling, thus associating it with breast cancer incidence and outcome.
title: Machine Learning Reveals Genetic Modifiers of the Immune Microenvironment of Cancer

finding: The SNP rs588321 was also classified as a functional SNP (fSNP) in the LSP1 locus, disrupting a transcriptional regulatory binding site, providing further evidence of its association with breast cancer incidence and outcome.
title: Machine Learning Reveals Genetic Modifiers of the Immune Microenvironment of Cancer

finding: The TaqA1 variant (rs1800497) was identified as impacting dopaminergic signaling by lowering D2 receptor density in the striatum. This genetic variation was associated with reduced performance in the Iowa Gambling Task (IGT), suggesting diminished sensitivity to losses.
title: D2 dopamine receptor expression, sensitivity to rewards, and reinforcement learning in a complex value-based decision-making task

finding: The C957T variant (rs6277) was believed to affect dopamine D2 receptor availability by influencing receptor affinity to dopamine. Its role in learning efficacy, as assessed in the IGT, indicated that alterations in D2 signaling could detrimentally affect decision-making processes.
title: D2 dopamine receptor expression, sensitivity to rewards, and reinforcement learning in a complex value-based decision-making task

finding: The SNP rs8181588 was associated with the KCNQ1 gene, which was significantly downregulated in patients with HbA1c ≥ 6.5% but not in diagnosed T2D patients. Additionally, KCNQ1 was negatively co-expressed with INS and rs8181588 nominally influenced its expression, linking this SNP to T2D risk.
title: Islet Gene View - a tool to facilitate islet research

finding: The rs11031005 C-allele was associated with a higher risk of PCOS (OR 1.17) and lower levels of follicle stimulating hormone (FSH). It also showed strong associations with female hormonal traits such as menstrual cycle length and age at menopause, indicating its role in PCOS pathophysiology.
title: Colocalization highlights genes in hypothalamic–pituitary–gonadal axis as potentially mediating polycystic ovary syndrome risk

finding: The SNP rs1061810 was significantly associated with the transcript expression of HSD17B12, which is involved in long-chain fatty acid metabolism, with a top signal of P = 2.3×10−117. An NRS (GNRS_4918) in high linkage disequilibrium (r² = 0.87) with rs1061810 was identified, demonstrating even greater significance (P = 5.6×10−120) than rs1061810. This NRS, located in the 3'UTR of the transcript, negatively influenced the transcript level, supporting its role as a potential causal variant in regulating gene expression.
title: Graph pangenome reveals functional, evolutionary, and phenotypic significance of human nonreference sequences

finding: The SNP rs7120118 located in the NR1H3 gene was found to be associated with significant increases in mRNA levels among Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients, indicating a role in AD progression. However, the study noted that the severity of the disease did not affect NR1H3 expression, suggesting it may play a part in the underlying pathology of AD without being influenced by the extent of disease.
title: Identification of common molecular biomarker signatures in blood and brain of Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs2279238 was linked to a 1.35-fold increased risk of developing progressive multiple sclerosis (MS) through its association with variant NR1H3. The findings indicated that mutated NR1H3 alters gene expression profiles, which may contribute to disrupted transcriptional regulation mechanisms, highlighting its potential relevance to neurodegenerative conditions like AD.
title: Identification of common molecular biomarker signatures in blood and brain of Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs143445068 was noted for its association with recurrent miscarriage. It had a MAF of 0.8% and a meta-analysis P-value of 5.2×10^-9, located in the intron of the NAV2 gene, with additional candidate genes suggested by chromatin interaction mapping.
title: The genetic architecture of sporadic and recurrent miscarriage

finding: The SNP rs11020145 was associated with calcium signaling in brain cancers, which relates to the pathophysiology of glioblastoma. This finding was highlighted as important for therapeutic targeting in glioblastoma, indicating its potential role in influencing disease progression and treatment responses.
title: Voltage-gated ion channels mediate the electrotaxis of glioblastoma cells in a hybrid PMMA/PDMS microdevice

finding: The SNP rs11826236 in the RIC3 gene was significantly associated with a lower age at smoking initiation, suggesting that genetic factors related to this locus may pre-dispose individuals to begin smoking at a younger age.
title: Gene-Gene interactions and pleiotropy in the brain nicotinic pathway associated with the heaviness and precocity of tobacco smoking among outpatients with multiple substance use disorders

finding: The SNP rs4758042, when interacting with rs11072793 in RIC3 and CHRNB4, was associated with a lower age at onset of daily smoking, suggesting genetic factors that might facilitate earlier smoking habits.
title: Gene-Gene interactions and pleiotropy in the brain nicotinic pathway associated with the heaviness and precocity of tobacco smoking among outpatients with multiple substance use disorders

finding: The SNP rs149514849, located at 11p13 near the gene ABTB2, showed suggestive association with RBC deformability, with a p-value of 8.08 x 10^-8. This finding indicated that variants in this region were potentially linked to the regulation of CD44 expression in macrophages, an important aspect of their phagocytic function.
title: Splenic clearance of rigid erythrocytes as an inherited mechanism for splenomegaly and natural resistance to malaria

finding: The SNP rs3842753 was identified as an at-risk allele for Type 1 Diabetes. It was associated with increased levels of beta-cell INS messenger RNA as reported in a meta-analysis utilizing single-cell RNA sequencing data. This finding highlighted a potential genetic basis for the observed heterogeneity in insulin production among pancreatic beta-cells, suggesting that genetic variations can influence the transcriptional activity of insulin in relation to diabetes risk.
title: Dynamic Ins2 gene activity defines β-cell maturity states

finding: Variation in FADS2 (rs9326418) was associated with an increase of TNFα production after in vitro β-glucan-induced trained immunity, indicating a crucial role of this SNP in the inflammatory response mediated by trained immunity.
title: Fatty acid desaturation and lipoxygenase pathways support trained immunity

finding: Variations in FADS2 (rs11600019) were associated with increased fold change of TNFα after BCG vaccination, further supporting its impact on trained immunity and pro-inflammatory responses in vivo.
title: Fatty acid desaturation and lipoxygenase pathways support trained immunity

finding: The SNP rs12252 was identified as a genetic variant that influences the severity of infections related to the Interferon-Induced Transmembrane Protein 3 (IFITM3). Specifically, it was linked to increased severity of Hemorrhagic Fever with Renal Syndrome in a study conducted by Xu-yang et al. (2017), and to severe influenza in Chinese individuals according to Zhang et al. (2013). This suggests that the rs12252 variant plays a significant role in modulating immune responses during viral infections.
title: The furin cleavage site of SARS-CoV-2 spike protein is a key determinant for transmission due to enhanced replication in airway cells

finding: The SNP rs11020190 was linked to distinct therapy responses and treatment resistance in glioblastoma, indicating its influence on tumor heterogeneity and patient outcomes.
title: Generalising uncertainty improves accuracy and safety of deep learning analytics applied to oncology

finding: This SNP increased breast cancer risk while decreasing prostate cancer risk, indicating a differential effect depending on cancer type.
title: Combining genome-wide studies of breast, prostate, ovarian and endometrial cancers maps cross-cancer susceptibility loci and identifies new genetic associations

finding: Identified as significant for breast and prostate cancer risk, this SNP displayed strong associations with the expression of the RHOD gene across both tissues.
title: Combining genome-wide studies of breast, prostate, ovarian and endometrial cancers maps cross-cancer susceptibility loci and identifies new genetic associations

finding: SNP rs4262739, located within a human-specific <cis only> regulatory region, was identified as an eQTL for ETS1. It has been associated with differences in lymphocyte percentage in humans, illustrating its role in human trait variation.
title: Human gene regulatory evolution is driven by the divergence of regulatory element function in both cis and trans

finding: The rs4245080 SNP was also identified as an eQTL for the ETS1 gene. It has been connected to human trait variation, indicating its functional relevance in the modulation of regulatory activity at the ETS1 enhancer.
title: Human gene regulatory evolution is driven by the divergence of regulatory element function in both cis and trans

finding: The SNP rs108499 was linked to the positively selected FADS1 haplotype. It was associated with an increase of NEB by 0.0134—a reflection of adaptation and selection favoring this allele in reproductive demographics over thousands of years.
title: Genome-wide analysis identifies genetic effects on reproductive success and ongoing natural selection at the FADS locus

finding: The SNP rs964184 on chromosome 11 was identified as a lead SNP with a significant GxE effect across multiple lipids, despite moderate evidence of pleiotropy in previous univariate analyses. The GxE interaction for this SNP included HDL with sleep duration and triglycerides with physical activity, while also being marginally associated with various phenotypes such as lipid levels and cardiovascular disease. The two-step approach successfully detected this SNP’s overall GxE effect, which was missed in earlier single analyses.
title: A two-step approach to testing overall effect of gene-environment interaction for multiple phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs4265625 was found to create regulatory activity in HepG2 cells. It lies within the POU2AF1 gene, which has been linked to primary biliary cirrhosis in previous GWAS studies.
title: Systematic identification of human SNPs affecting regulatory element activity

finding: The rs1800497 SNP, also known as Taq1 A polymorphism, was identified as having a notable association with addiction-related behaviors. The study reported the genotypic frequencies in the population of Eastern Uttar Pradesh, finding that the allele A2 had a higher frequency (0.56) compared to allele A1 (0.44). Additionally, individuals with the A1A1 genotype exhibited approximately 49% reduced dopamine receptors compared to those without this genotype, potentially increasing cravings for alcohol and connecting the polymorphism to psychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia, depression, and ADHD.
title: DRD2 TaqI A polymorphism in Eastern Uttar Pradesh population

finding: The genetic variant rs12252-C in the Interferon-induced transmembrane protein 3 (IFITM3) gene was associated with severe influenza in Chinese individuals, demonstrating its relevance in understanding susceptibility to viral infections.
title: Interferon-Induced Transmembrane Protein 3 Blocks Fusion of Diverse Enveloped Viruses by Locally Altering Mechanical Properties of Cell Membranes

finding: This variant was linked to venous thrombosis and identified as a lead cis-pQTL for F2 protein, connecting genetic risk factors for blood coagulation disorders.
title: Genetic architecture of host proteins interacting with SARS-CoV-2

finding: The SNP rs2168101 G>T was identified in the enhancer region of the gene LMO1. This mutation disrupted GATA3 binding, which in turn impacted LMO1 expression, specifically in patients with neuroblastoma. The findings linked this noncoding mutation to significant alterations in gene expression crucial for the pathology of this cancer type.
title: Diverse noncoding mutations contribute to deregulation of cis-regulatory landscape in pediatric cancers

finding: The variant rs55646091 was prioritized as a putative causal variant for asthma and correlated with increased eosinophil counts. It was shown to overlap with CAMBUS+ OCR in regulatory T-cells and associated with the gene LRRC32, a known T-reg cell surface marker. The variant was linked to a positive effect size in both asthma and eosinophil counts.
title: Predicted constrained accessible regions mark regulatory elements and causal variants

finding: The SNP rs10835310 at the METTL15 locus was associated with childhood obesity based on a trans-ancestral meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies. This finding highlighted the potential involvement of METTL15 in the pathogenesis of childhood obesity, although the exact molecular mechanisms underlying this association remained unclear.
title: The human mitochondrial 12S rRNA m4C methyltransferase METTL15 is required for proper mitochondrial function

finding: The SNP rs11819995, found in the first intron of the ETS1 transcript, had its enhancer activity significantly influenced by an HNF1 motif located 11 bp downstream. Deleting this motif caused significant decreases in activity for both alleles (C, non-risk; and T, risk) at rs11819995 (p = 0.008). Shuffling the motif also decreased activity for the reference allele (p = 0.008). The regulatory activity was notably stronger in beta cells than in skeletal muscle cells, emphasizing a specific context-dependent regulatory mechanism.
title: Using a modular massively parallel reporter assay to discover context-specific regulatory grammars in type 2 diabetes

finding: The genetic polymorphism rs12218 in SAA1 demonstrated an association with myocardial infarction in a Chinese population, showing its potential impact on cardiovascular disease.
title: Identification of biomarkers and pathways for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis using next generation sequencing data and bioinformatics analysis

finding: The CYP2R1 rs10766197 polymorphism was examined in relation to multiple sclerosis, presenting potential implications for autoimmune conditions.
title: Identification of biomarkers and pathways for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis using next generation sequencing data and bioinformatics analysis

finding: Studies indicated that the FADS2 rs3834458 gene polymorphism was associated with Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease and coronary artery disease in the Chinese Han population, highlighting its relevance in lipid metabolism and NAFLD susceptibility.
title: Bioinformatics analysis of differentially expressed genes in non alcoholic fatty liver disease using next generation sequencing data

finding: The SNP rs11030413 was linked to the modulation of presynaptic filament stability of RAD51 recombinase. This finding was derived from research that indicated the involvement of c-Met in phosphorylation sites of RAD51, which subsequently affected its stability and functionality in DNA repair mechanisms. The relevance of this SNP in the context of splicing profiles modifications associated with radio and chemoresistance was noted, highlighting its significance in therapeutic responses.
title: Aurora A mediated new phosphorylation of RAD51 is observed in Nuclear Speckles

finding: The SNP rs11020251 was associated with FOXM1 overexpression in cancer, which related to the findings in the study involving the dual inactivation of the TP53 and CDKN2A genes in gastroesophageal junction (GEJ) tumorigenesis. The research highlighted a novel FOXM1-PTAFR-PTAF axis activated by FOXM1, linking it to neoplastic processes in the developed organoid model.
title: Novel tumorigenic FOXM1-PTAFR-PTAF axis revealed by multi-omic profiling in TP53/CDKN2A-double knockout human gastroesophageal junction organoid model

finding: The SNP rs1790218, which encodes the A-allele and leads to the p.Trp96Ter variant, was associated with significantly decreased transcript levels of the SLC22A10 gene in human samples. This variant was frequently observed in human populations with allele frequencies ranging from approximately 20% in Africans to 50% in Europeans. The presence of this nonsense variant suggested a loss of function of the SLC22A10 protein, which correlated with lower protein expression in liver tissue.
title: Illuminating the Function of the Orphan Transporter, SLC22A10 in Humans and Other Primates

finding: The Taq1A polymorphism, defined by the rs1800497 SNP, was associated with significant behavioral and metabolic outcomes. Specifically, the A1 allele carriers were observed to have reduced striatal DR2 levels, which correlated with alterations in learning, impulsivity, and flexible behaviors, paralleling endophenotypes seen in A1 carriers. This variant was connected to obesity and energy homeostasis, depicting a novel role of the ANKK1 gene in metabolic regulation.
title: The addiction-susceptibility TaqIA/Ankyrin repeat and kinase domain containing 1 kinase (ANKK1) controls reward and metabolism through dopamine receptor type 2 (DR2)-expressing neurons

finding: The intergenic variant rs532230290, located 42kb from SCYL1, was established as height-associated. Its significance surfaced in the context of joint analysis with other genetic variants, which had not been recognized in earlier studies.
title: Joint modelling of whole genome sequence data for human height via approximate message passing

finding: The intronic variant rs543038394 in OVOL1 was identified as related to height. The association emerged only through a comprehensive analysis of genome-wide data utilizing WGS techniques.
title: Joint modelling of whole genome sequence data for human height via approximate message passing

finding: The SNP rs3842753 was identified as an at-risk allele associated with increased beta-cell INS mRNA levels in a meta-analysis of single-cell RNA-sequencing data. This finding was particularly relevant to Type 1 Diabetes (T1D), suggesting a genetic mechanism that could influence the progression of the disease by impacting beta-cell function.
title: Delineating mouse β-cell identity during lifetime and in diabetes with a single cell atlas

finding: The SNP rs174570 was linked to the FADS gene family (specifically FADS1 and FADS2) associated with lipid metabolism. This SNP exhibited top selection signals indicating its role in metabolic adaptation and potentially linked to conditions like lipid metabolism disorder and hypobetalipoproteinemia.
title: Malaria resistance-related biological adaptation and complex evolutionary footprints of Tai-Kadai people inferred from 796 genomes

finding: The SNP rs867611 was found to be associated with Alzheimer’s disease, showing a significant P-value of 2.19×10^-18. It was reported that under this SNP, 16 circRNAs were actively expressed in pyramidal neuron samples derived from the PICALM gene.
title: Circular RNAs in the human brain are tailored to neuron identity and neuropsychiatric disease

finding: This SNP was identified in the European (EUR) sample analysis as significantly associated with PTSD, nearest to the gene METTL15, and had a p-value of 1.75×10⁻¹⁰.
title: Genomic Characterization of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder in a Large US Military Veteran Sample

finding: This SNP, identified in the trans-ancestral analysis, was related to prior findings in the EUR GWAS, sharing linkage disequilibrium with a significant association.
title: Genomic Characterization of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder in a Large US Military Veteran Sample

finding: The SNP rs12225230 was found to be associated with apoA-I concentrations at a GWAS significance level (P < 5×10−8) in a large study involving 20,370 Finnish participants. It showed a per-C allele beta of 0.076 SD and was robustly associated with higher levels of multiple HDL-related measures, indicating its role as a cis-pQTL for apoA-I. Furthermore, rs12225230 was identified as the principal driver of the apoA-I association in the APOA1 locus, corroborated by its previous identification in a prior GWAS of apoA-I. The minor allele was linked to increased serum apoA-I levels, reflecting a significant genetic influence on this phenotype.
title: Genetic variation in apolipoprotein A-I concentrations and risk of coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs34481144 was found to influence the expression of the IFITM3 gene, with donors homozygous for the reference allele (C) exhibiting 4.82-fold higher expression than those with the alternate allele (T). This SNP accounted for 58% of the variation in Zika virus (ZIKV) infectivity, with donors carrying the TT genotype being significantly more prone to infection compared to CC carriers. This highlights rs34481144 as a functional QTL affecting NPC sensitivity to ZIKV.
title: Natural variation in gene expression and Zika virus susceptibility revealed by villages of neural progenitor cells

finding: The SNP rs174548 was identified as a significant variant associated with circulating polyunsaturated fatty acids, which linked to lung cancer. This finding emphasized the role of fatty acid metabolism in disease processes, aligning with the study's broader context of lipids influencing memory decline.
title: Untargeted Metabolomics Shows Alterations in Homocysteine, Lipids and Fatty Acids predicting Memory Decline in Healthy Middle-Aged Individuals

finding: The variant rs636317 was found to disrupt CTCF binding and regulate MS4A6A expression significantly when excised in differentiated THP-1 cells, linking it to the AD GWAS locus.
title: Functional regulatory variants implicate distinct transcriptional networks in dementia

finding: The novel SNP rs117956829 near the NOX4 gene showed associations with schizophrenia (SCZ), bipolar disorder (BIP), major depression (MD), autism spectrum disorder (ASD), and anorexia nervosa (AN), with a meta-analysis p-value of 1.82 x 10^-9. The gene has been implicated in neural stem cell growth and is a key source of superoxide production in the brain.
title: Genome wide meta-analysis identifies genomic relationships, novel loci, and pleiotropic mechanisms across eight psychiatric disorders

finding: The rs10792832-A SNP in the PICALM locus presented a protective effect in all tested populations in GWAS, emphasizing its potential role in reducing AD risk.
title: How understudied populations have contributed to our understanding of Alzheimer’s disease genetics

finding: The CELF1/SPI1 locus variant rs10838725-C was linked to increased AD risk in NHWs and showed a connection with reduced SPI1 expression, suggesting a delay in AD onset.
title: How understudied populations have contributed to our understanding of Alzheimer’s disease genetics

finding: The GWAS SNP rs1557765 was associated with the promoter region of the gene ABCC8, suggesting its influence on body mass index and linked to TCF7L2 motif enhancement based on analysis.
title: INFIMA leverages multi-omics model organism data to identify effector genes of human GWAS variants

finding: SNP rs5215 showed better sequence motifs for TCF7L2 and YY1, indicative of its role in the transcriptional regulation related to type 2 diabetes.
title: INFIMA leverages multi-omics model organism data to identify effector genes of human GWAS variants

finding: The SNP rs5219 was included among three intronic GWAS SNPs of KCNJ11 associated with type 2 diabetes, influencing transcriptional regulation identified through analysis.
title: INFIMA leverages multi-omics model organism data to identify effector genes of human GWAS variants

finding: Contained within the KCNJ11 locus, rs757110 is among SNPs correlated with type 2 diabetes, with implications for transcription factor binding enhancements.
title: INFIMA leverages multi-omics model organism data to identify effector genes of human GWAS variants

finding: The SNP rs3903072 was identified as a breast cancer-associated variant linked to the expression of CTSW in immune cells, specifically tumor infiltrating lymphocytes. Its presence correlated negatively with CTSW expression levels in ER+ breast cancer patients, suggesting a tumor-suppressive role for CTSW, with higher expression being associated with better survival outcomes.
title: Can cancer GWAS variants modulate immune cells in the tumor microenvironment?

finding: The SNP rs658524 was found to be linked with CTSW regulation due to its positioning at the CTSW promoter and correlation with CTSW expression in immune cells. Although it showed partial association with breast cancer risk, it was highlighted for its potential role in modulating CTSW expression through enhancer activity.
title: Can cancer GWAS variants modulate immune cells in the tumor microenvironment?

finding: The SNP rs11227311 was identified as a putative functional SNP within a distal regulatory element impacting CTSW expression in immune cells, demonstrating significant interaction with transcription factor binding and highlighting its potential in regulating immune response related to cancer.
title: Can cancer GWAS variants modulate immune cells in the tumor microenvironment?

finding: The c.625G>C; p.(E209Q) variant was identified as a novel homozygous missense mutation associated with amelogenesis imperfecta (AI) in Families 4, 5, 6, and 7. Although it was previously documented in the gnomAD database, it had not been associated with a disease phenotype before this study. The variant had a frequency of 0.000457 in the South Asian population but was absent across all other populations. The amino acid E209 is fully conserved among mammals, and the mutation was predicted to be damaging.
title: Spectrum of pathogenic variants and multiple founder effects in amelogenesis imperfecta associated with MMP20

finding: The rs3092836 variant at the ATM gene was significantly associated with mCA at ATM, showing an odds ratio (OR) of 26.41 (p=0.0013). It had a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 8% in individuals of African ancestry (AA), 2% in East Asian (EAS) and Hispanic ancestry (HA), and 0.06% in individuals of European ancestry (EA).
title: Mosaic chromosomal alterations in blood across ancestries via whole-genome sequencing

finding: The variant rs56009889 at the ATM locus exhibited a very strong association with CN-LOH at ATM, with an odds ratio (OR) of 92 (P = 2.5e-8) and a minor allele count (MAC) of 7. This finding underscored the role of this rare variant in mCAs.
title: Mosaic chromosomal alterations in blood across ancestries via whole-genome sequencing

finding: The SNP rs2075290 was associated with a MACIE-regulatory score of 0.88, which suggests that it may have functional implications at the TG locus, despite being in moderate linkage disequilibrium with the leading SNV rs964184.
title: A Multi-dimensional Integrative Scoring Framework for Predicting Functional Regions in the Human Genome

finding: The SNP rs174535 at the MYRF locus was identified as a missense variant associated with asthma. It caused a serine to arginine substitution and was also predicted to be 'probably damaging' by PolyPhen. The SNP was noted to be in linkage disequilibrium with a significant eQTL for TMEM258.
title: Genome-wide association analysis of 350,000 Caucasians from the UK Biobank identifies novel loci for asthma, hay fever and eczema

finding: The SNP rs11231693 was found to have inconsistencies in its pleiotropic pattern due to its marginal effect on height, which significantly reduced the overall consistency of traits associated with it. Its association with height was further questioned due to a non-significant p-value (0.91) in the height GWAS from both GIANT2015 and UKB.
title: Beyond power: Multivariate discovery, replication, and interpretation of pleiotropic loci using summary association statistics

finding: The SNP rs11040537 was identified in the context of glioblastoma immunotherapy. It was associated with tumor immune interactions, particularly the efficacy of CD4+ T cell responses that enhanced microglial tumoricidal activities. This context indicated that the presence of this SNP potentially influenced the mutualistic relationship between CD4+ T cells and microglia, thus impacting tumor suppression dynamics.
title: A microglia-CD4+ T cell partnership generates protective anti-tumor immunity to glioblastoma

finding: The SNP served as a proxy for the SLE sentinel SNP rs4639966 and was linked to the CXCR5 promoter, highlighting its role in the regulation of SLE-related genes.
title: Human follicular helper T cell promoter connectomes reveal novel genes and regulatory elements at SLE GWAS loci

finding: Acting as a proxy for SLE SNP rs4639966, rs71041848 was found to physically interact with the CXCR5 promoter instead of the nearest TREH gene, evidencing its functional significance.
title: Human follicular helper T cell promoter connectomes reveal novel genes and regulatory elements at SLE GWAS loci

finding: As a sentinel SNP in SLE, this variant was proved to interact with both rs527619 and rs71041848, demonstrating its important role in regulating the chemokine receptor CXCR5 in TFH cells.
title: Human follicular helper T cell promoter connectomes reveal novel genes and regulatory elements at SLE GWAS loci

finding: The rs694539 variant of the nicotinamide-N-methyltransferase (NNMT) gene was found to be associated with bipolar disorder.
title: Bioinformatics and next generation data analysis reveals the potential role of inflammation in sepsis and its associated complications

finding: The SNP rs10767873, associated with the MPPED2 gene, was linked to kidney function and the risk of cardiovascular disease in patients with hypertension.
title: Bioinformatics and next generation data analysis reveals the potential role of inflammation in sepsis and its associated complications

finding: The SNP rs10830963 at MNTR1B was previously shown to alter enhancer activities, making it a positive and original finding related to type 2 diabetes (T2D). This association was established through multiple studies including Gaulton et al., 2015.
title: Deep learning models predict regulatory variants in pancreatic islets and refine type 2 diabetes association signals

finding: The gain-of-function variant S140G (rs120074192) was created and studied for its impact on KCNQ1, showing that it biases the I<sub>Ks</sub> channels to the open state at lower membrane potentials, ultimately leading to increased cellular potassium efflux. This finding established its substantial impact in cardiac physiology.
title: High-throughput functional mapping of variants in an arrhythmia gene, KCNE1, reveals novel biology

finding: The risk allele at this locus increased the expression of DHCR7 while also increasing the acetylation of a nearby actQTL peak, indicating an intricate regulation of gene expression where opposing effects were seen on different genes.
title: Immune disease variants modulate gene expression in regulatory CD4+ T cells and inform drug targets

finding: This was the lead variant for regulatory effects coinciding with colocalizations among eQTL, actQTL, and promQTL signals, showing that disease alleles influenced expression dynamics across multiple layers of genetic regulation.
title: Immune disease variants modulate gene expression in regulatory CD4+ T cells and inform drug targets

finding: Found to exhibit maternal effects on Cystatin C, this SNP was documented with PofO associations at the 11p15.5 locus related to type 2 diabetes (differential p-values < 0.01).
title: Parent-of-origin effects in the UK Biobank

finding: This SNP demonstrated PofO effects associated with Cystatin C levels, contributing to the evidence for its role in type 2 diabetes susceptibility (differential p-values < 0.01).
title: Parent-of-origin effects in the UK Biobank

finding: Associated with multiple weight- and fat-related phenotypes, this SNP showed opposite parental effects; it decreased these phenotypes when paternally inherited and increased them when maternally inherited, indicating its role in metabolic traits.
title: Parent-of-origin effects in the UK Biobank

finding: This indel variant was part of the credible set of T2D variants in the STARD10 locus and was associated with differences in DNA-protein complex mobility, indicating potential regulatory roles.
title: Chromatin 3D interaction analysis of the STARD10 locus unveils FCHSD2 as a new regulator of insulin secretion

finding: SNP rs79430446 was identified within the credible set with allele-specific binding activities differing between risk and protective alleles, suggesting its involvement in T2D regulation.
title: Chromatin 3D interaction analysis of the STARD10 locus unveils FCHSD2 as a new regulator of insulin secretion

finding: SNP rs7103836 was noted to show marked differences in DNA-protein interactions between risk and protective alleles, indicating its likely regulatory role in T2D susceptibility.
title: Chromatin 3D interaction analysis of the STARD10 locus unveils FCHSD2 as a new regulator of insulin secretion

finding: This SNP was part of the credible set of T2D variants and its differential binding activity between alleles suggested its potential regulatory functionality in the context of T2D.
title: Chromatin 3D interaction analysis of the STARD10 locus unveils FCHSD2 as a new regulator of insulin secretion

finding: This variant was found to be associated with decreased expression of the FCHSD2 gene in risk allele carriers, linking it to altered gene expression relevant to diabetes risk.
title: Chromatin 3D interaction analysis of the STARD10 locus unveils FCHSD2 as a new regulator of insulin secretion

finding: This SNP was also associated with reduced expression of FCHSD2 in carriers of the risk alleles, demonstrating its relevance in the regulation of T2D-associated genes.
title: Chromatin 3D interaction analysis of the STARD10 locus unveils FCHSD2 as a new regulator of insulin secretion

finding: SNP rs1552224 showed a correlation with lower FCHSD2 expression, indicating its involvement in regulatory mechanisms associated with T2D variants.
title: Chromatin 3D interaction analysis of the STARD10 locus unveils FCHSD2 as a new regulator of insulin secretion

finding: The rs511217 variant, associated with refraction error and myopia, was a sc-eQTL of KCNA4 and a nominally significant sc-caQTL of its residing OCR in BC. This variant's GWAS signal was colocalized with the retinal bulk eQTL signal of KCNA4.
title: Integrative single cell multiomics analysis of human retina indicates a role for hierarchical transcription factors collaboration in genetic effects on gene regulation

finding: This SNP demonstrated a significant association with cEF (β = 0.010, p = 1.3e-10), indicating its relevance in understanding the genetic variance underlying cEF.
title: Genome-Wide Association Study of Over 427,000 Individuals Establishes Executive Functioning as a Neurocognitive Basis of Psychiatric Disorders Influenced by GABAergic Processes

finding: This SNP was also significantly associated with cEF (β = 0.010, p = 1.4e-100), indicating its impact on making sense of the genetic framework related to cEF.
title: Genome-Wide Association Study of Over 427,000 Individuals Establishes Executive Functioning as a Neurocognitive Basis of Psychiatric Disorders Influenced by GABAergic Processes

finding: The common rSNP rs368698783 A-allele reduced the interaction of the transcription factor LYAR and the epigenetic regulators DNMT3A and PRMT5 with the HBG promoter. This interaction attenuation resulted in elevated levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) in individuals diagnosed with β-thalassemia, suggesting a potential pathway for therapeutic strategies targeting β-hemoglobinopathies.
title: Fibrillarin modulates fetal hemoglobin silencing

finding: The SNP rs11020251 was associated with overexpression of FOXM1 in cancers according to the study by Barger et al. (2019). This overexpression was linked to various genomic features in the context of cancer, suggesting a potential role in influencing chromatin structure and regulation of gene expression.
title: The intrinsically disordered region of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRIP12 induces the formation of chromatin condensates and interferes with DNA damage response

finding: The rs71467481 intronic variant in PPFIA1 was linked to complex processing speed, presenting its involvement in cognitive functions, particularly in Alzheimer's disease contexts.
title: Exome-wide analysis reveals role of LRP1 and additional novel loci in cognition

finding: In the study, rs3087967 was established as the likely causal eQTL at the 11q23.1 locus, co-localizing with expression of POU2AF2 and demonstrating a significant association with colorectal cancer (CRC) risk. Analysis revealed that the risk genotype of rs3087967 (T) was linked to lower tuft cell abundance in human colonic epithelium, contributing to the understanding of CRC risk mechanisms.
title: Genetic variation at 11q23.1 confers colorectal cancer risk by dysregulation of colonic tuft cell transcriptional activator POU2AF2

finding: The SNP rs3802842 exhibited significant cis-eQTL effects for the expression of local genes POU2AF2, COLCA1, and POU2AF3, further validating the impact of 11q23.1 variation on CRC-associated gene expression.
title: Genetic variation at 11q23.1 confers colorectal cancer risk by dysregulation of colonic tuft cell transcriptional activator POU2AF2

finding: This variant was associated with cis-eQTL effects on POU2AF2, COLCA1, and POU2AF3, indicating its potential role in influencing gene expression related to CRC risk, alongside rs3087967.
title: Genetic variation at 11q23.1 confers colorectal cancer risk by dysregulation of colonic tuft cell transcriptional activator POU2AF2

finding: Similarly, rs7130173 was identified with significant cis-eQTL effects on POU2AF2, COLCA1, and POU2AF3 expression, supporting its involvement in CRC risk pathways.
title: Genetic variation at 11q23.1 confers colorectal cancer risk by dysregulation of colonic tuft cell transcriptional activator POU2AF2

finding: The variant rs11039131 demonstrated significant chromatin contacts with genes DDB2 and ACP2, both related to DNA repair and damage response. Additionally, it was found to be near SPI1 and CELF1, both implicated in AD pathology, suggesting it may serve as an AD risk variant influencing microglial phagocytosis and anti-inflammatory mechanisms.
title: S-BEAM: A Semi-Supervised Ensemble Approach to Rank Potential Causal Variants and Their Target Genes in Microglia for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP MS4A14:rs12226367 was identified exclusively within the immune-compartment-mediated eQTL analysis. This SNP is associated with the expression of MS4A14, which is primarily expressed in monocytes and myeloid cells. The finding represents a novel eQTL effect, despite rs12226367's previous association with the expression of MS4A6A. This emphasizes the role of genetic variations in modulating immune cell functions in the context of CeD.
title: Gene expression and eQTL analysis reflect the heterogeneity in the inflammatory status of the duodenal epithelial lining in coeliac disease

finding: The SNP rs1800497 was associated with striatal dopamine levels, which were linked to variability in human time perception. The study indicated that individuals with specific genotypes at this locus may exhibit elevated spontaneous eye blink rates, serving as a proxy measure of dopamine availability. This was correlated with poorer temporal precision in interval timing tasks, highlighting the role of striatal dopamine in individuals' ability to perceive time accurately.
title: A proxy measure of striatal dopamine predicts individual differences in temporal precision

finding: The SNP rs17120434 was found to have significant associations with elevated total cholesterol and LDL-C levels. This finding related to the overall genetic influence of the TAGLN locus on plasma lipid traits.
title: Transgelin: A New Gene Involved in LDL Endocytosis Identified by a Genome-wide CRISPR-Cas9 Screen

finding: The SNP rs2075547 exhibited significant associations with elevated triglycerides and total cholesterol. The connection indicated that variations in this SNP could affect lipid metabolism through its role within the TAGLN gene.
title: Transgelin: A New Gene Involved in LDL Endocytosis Identified by a Genome-wide CRISPR-Cas9 Screen

finding: Associations were noted for rs2269397 with total cholesterol and LDL-C. This finding underscored the relevance of the TAGLN gene in lipid regulation processes.
title: Transgelin: A New Gene Involved in LDL Endocytosis Identified by a Genome-wide CRISPR-Cas9 Screen

finding: The SNP rs508487 showed strong associations with triglycerides and LDL-C, with a p-value of 3x10^-20. It was also linked to soluble transferrin receptor (sTfR), suggesting a role in iron metabolism as well.
title: Transgelin: A New Gene Involved in LDL Endocytosis Identified by a Genome-wide CRISPR-Cas9 Screen

finding: Significant associations with triglycerides and LDL-C were identified for rs641620, with a p-value of 9.8x10^-15. Like rs508487, this SNP was also associated with sTfR, indicating dual roles in lipid and iron metabolism.
title: Transgelin: A New Gene Involved in LDL Endocytosis Identified by a Genome-wide CRISPR-Cas9 Screen

finding: The SNP rs664971 had reported associations with sTfR (p=8.5x10^-17) and was related to alterations in lipid profiles, highlighting the potential of the TAGLN locus in influencing both lipid and iron-related traits.
title: Transgelin: A New Gene Involved in LDL Endocytosis Identified by a Genome-wide CRISPR-Cas9 Screen

finding: The A-allele of rs45480496, identified as a common variant with a MAF of 21% in TOPMed, was suggestively associated with autoimmune disease, particularly marked as having an "autoimmune origin" in the Finngen study (OR = 1.04, pvalue = 2 x 10^-7). Additionally, it was reported as a suggestive hit in a meta-analysis of BBJ and UKB datasets related to "autoimmune multi-trait" (OR = 1.08, pvalue = 2 x 10^-6). Further analysis combining these signals yielded genome-wide significance (pvalue = 2 x 10^-12). Functional studies indicated that rs45480496 is located within a regulatory element interacting with the promoter of KMT2A in various immune cell types, including megakaryocytes and CD4+ T-cells. It was found in an active enhancer in Th17 cells and intersected with a predicted KMT2A enhancer in CD4+ T-cells, supporting its role as a novel risk locus for autoimmune traits linked to KMT2A.
title: Gene regulatory network inference from CRISPR perturbations in primary CD4+ T cells elucidates the genomic basis of immune disease

finding: The variant rs610932, associated with higher risk for LOAD, was shown to affect serum levels of TREM2, with the risk allele correlating with decreased TREM2 levels. It also aided in corroborating findings for genetic susceptibility to LOAD.
title: Human serum proteome profoundly overlaps with genetic signatures of disease

finding: The variant rs1052373 was assigned to the disease-associated allele. This variant was used to determine the association of alternatively spliced isoforms in the transcriptome sequencing, specifically linking it to phenotypic outcomes in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
title: Targeted Long-Read RNA Sequencing Demonstrates Transcriptional Diversity Driven by Splice-Site Variation in MYBPC3

finding: The rs10769255 SNP was considered for evaluating truncated isoforms. Its role was highlighted in the manual phasing of reads that indicated a significant portion of alternatively spliced transcripts were linked to the splice-site variant containing alleles.
title: Targeted Long-Read RNA Sequencing Demonstrates Transcriptional Diversity Driven by Splice-Site Variation in MYBPC3

finding: This SNP was also one of the four loci that were successfully replicated in the elderly cohort for ALM, suggesting its potential role in modulating skeletal muscle mass.
title: Genome-wide associations reveal human-mouse genetic convergence and modifiers of myogenesis, CPNE1 and STC2

finding: The SNP rs11020208, reported in the work by Sun et al. (2019), was associated with statistical characteristics of cyclonic and anticyclonic eddies in the North Pacific. This finding related to the dynamics of mesoscale eddies, which influenced the environmental conditions impacting biological communities, specifically how these physical oceanic features affected the structuring of plankton and consequently the distribution of various taxa.
title: Food or physics: plankton communities structured across Gulf of Alaska eddies

finding: The study presented findings related to the RNASEH2C variant c.468G>T (rs61736590) in a systemic sclerosis patient. This variant was associated with significantly reduced RNase H2 activity in the patient’s T cells, which was measured and compared to a control group. The residual activity per cell and per microgram of cellular protein in T cells was found to be 80% and 63.5% of the control activity, respectively. These results indicate that the identified RNASEH2C variant contributes to a decrease in RNase H2 activity, linking it to the patient’s autoimmune condition.
title: Validation of an RNase H2 activity assay suitable for clinical screening

finding: The SNP rs35705950 was associated with the enhancer that showed lineage- and disease-dependent epigenetic remodeling, indicating its involvement in regulating genes relevant to airway responses, potentially influencing susceptibility to responses from environmental exposures such as wood smoke particles.
title: Genomics-based deconvolution of multiplexed transcriptional responses to wood smoke particles defines rapid AHR signaling dynamics

finding: The SNP rs1293651 was associated with bipolar disorder (BD) specifically in individuals with psychotic features. The study conducted by Leszczynska-Rodziewicz et al. in 2012 indicated that this polymorphism in the CRHR1 gene exhibited a significant correlation with the clinical presentation of BD, suggesting its role in the disorder's etiology.
title: Abnormal features of human self-domestication in bipolar disorder

finding: The SNP rs555105 was associated with the lincRNA RP11-290F20.3 in FCGR3A+ monocytes, indicating its role in modulation of gene expression related to immune response.
title: Expression QTLs in single-cell sequencing data

finding: The SNP rs10770141 was found to be associated with the onset of schizophrenia with an odds ratio of 1.788 (p<0.0001). Furthermore, individuals carrying the minor allele T(+) exhibited a 30%–40% higher expression of the TH gene compared to T(-) individuals, suggesting increased dopaminergic activity.
title: Genetic risks of schizophrenia identified in a matched case-control study

finding: RS1800497 displayed a significant association with schizophrenia, with an odds ratio of 1.727 (p<0.0001). Imaging analyses indicated that individuals with the A1(+) allele had 12% less availability of striatal DRD2 than those with the major A1(-) allele, highlighting a potential dopaminergic dysfunction.
title: Genetic risks of schizophrenia identified in a matched case-control study

finding: SNP rs734094 was discovered to overlap chromatin peaks accessible in both T and myeloid cell types. This variant was closely linked to multiple gene isoforms, and preliminary functional data suggested a causal relationship with the LSP1 gene, known to negatively regulate inflammation and T cell activity.
title: The Chromatin Landscape of Pathogenic Transcriptional Cell States in Rheumatoid Arthritis

finding: rs2514218 was highlighted among lead variants and was linked to the dopamine receptor D2 (DRD2) gene, showing relevance in the context of both SCZ and CompGaming phenotypes. However, specific statistical outcomes for this SNP were not detailed.
title: DRD2 and FOXP2 are implicated in the associations between computerized device use and psychiatric disorders

finding: The SNP rs2734837 was mapped to the dopamine receptor D2 (DRD2) gene, positioning it as a significant lead variant in the genetic analyses of both SCZ and CompGaming disorder, though specific figures were not provided.
title: DRD2 and FOXP2 are implicated in the associations between computerized device use and psychiatric disorders

finding: This SNP also mapped to the DRD2 gene and was part of the identified significant variants for both SCZ and CompGaming, reaffirming the genetic interplay between these psychiatric traits.
title: DRD2 and FOXP2 are implicated in the associations between computerized device use and psychiatric disorders

finding: Similar to the other SNPs, rs4936271 was linked to the DRD2 gene and identified as a significant variant, contributing to the genetic analysis of SCZ and CompGaming.
title: DRD2 and FOXP2 are implicated in the associations between computerized device use and psychiatric disorders

finding: The SNP rs45474901 was found in the 3'UTR of the gene TMEM25 and exhibited a higher expression in the PASSPORT-seq assay and in subjects with AUDs compared to the lower expression documented after ethanol exposure in SK-N-BE(2) cells. This indicated that acute ethanol treatment had a dose-responsive effect on this SNP.
title: Allele-Specific Expression and High-Throughput Reporter Assay Reveal Functional Variants in Human Brains with Alcohol Use Disorders

finding: The SNP rs45522239, which demonstrated differential expression in response to ethanol treatment, was identified as having significantly different allele frequencies between AUD subjects and controls, affirming its role in AUD-related allelic expression variation.
title: Allele-Specific Expression and High-Throughput Reporter Assay Reveal Functional Variants in Human Brains with Alcohol Use Disorders

finding: The SNP rs45548238 also had alternative allele frequencies that varied significantly with ethanol treatment in SK-N-BE(2) cells. This finding further supported the association between ethanol treatment and altered gene expression linked to AUD.
title: Allele-Specific Expression and High-Throughput Reporter Assay Reveal Functional Variants in Human Brains with Alcohol Use Disorders

finding: The SNP rs4945097 acted as a quantitative trait locus (QTL) for chromatin accessibility, specifically influencing H3K4me1 and methylation. This finding was relevant in the context of understanding how this genetic variant contributed to variations in immune response, particularly in relation to influenza A virus exposure.
title: Epigenetic variation impacts ancestry-associated differences in the transcriptional response to influenza infection

finding: The rs3851179 SNP in the PICALM gene was associated with altered functional connectivity in fMRI images, highlighting its role in brain functions relevant to the risk of developing Alzheimer's Disease.
title: Alzheimer’s disease-like features in resting state EEG/fMRI of cognitively intact and healthy middle-aged APOE/PICALM risk carriers

finding: The variant rs35835984 exhibited a high predicted probability of impacting the expression of colocalized genes. It demonstrated an effect size on body mass index (BMI) that was two to three times greater than the lead colocalized variant rs6591.
title: Diverse transcriptomic signatures across human tissues identify functional rare genetic variation

finding: Similar to rs35835984, the variant rs184629044 also had an effect size on BMI that was two to three times greater than the lead colocalized variant rs6591, suggesting its relevance to the trait.
title: Diverse transcriptomic signatures across human tissues identify functional rare genetic variation

finding: The variant rs192797357 was involved in the trait of body mass index (BMI) and had an effect size that was two to three times greater than the lead colocalized variant rs6591, indicating its potential impact.
title: Diverse transcriptomic signatures across human tissues identify functional rare genetic variation

finding: The SNP rs1800497, associated with the expression of the DRD2 gene, was reported to have a significant association with migraine risk in Han Chinese individuals. This finding highlighted a potential genetic predisposition to migraine within this population, suggesting a link between dopamine signaling and migraine susceptibility.
title: PACAP induces light aversion in mice by an inheritable mechanism independent of CGRP

finding: Similar to rs653178, the SNP rs642803 was identified as an outlier contributing to 14 traits related to coronary heart disease (CHD). Its association with factors such as thyroid disease and smoking behavior highlighted its potential influence on CHD risk.
title: MR-TRYX: A Mendelian randomization framework that exploits horizontal pleiotropy to infer novel causal pathways

finding: The analysis indicated that rs3741360 was identified as the lead variant in the P-P plot generated by the eQTpLot R package. This lead variant correlated with other eQTL variants at the BBS1 locus, which demonstrated strong linkage disequilibrium (LD) among them. The findings pointed to significant colocalization between BBS1 eQTL and LDL GWAS signals, suggesting a complex relationship between gene expression and trait associations in this locus.
title: eQTpLot: a user-friendly R package for the visualization and colocalization of eQTL and GWAS signals

finding: The study indicated that the rs12252-C variant was associated with severe influenza infection. It was highlighted that cells homozygous for this variant lacked truncated IFITM3 transcripts, suggesting that this genetic variation significantly impacted the expression of IFITM3, which is crucial for controlling influenza virus infection.
title: Low basal expression and slow induction of IFITM3 puts immune cells at risk of influenza A infection

finding: The new variant rs1039215 in HBG2/HBE1 was discovered to be significantly associated with HbA1c in African-ancestry populations. It demonstrated a P-value of 2.0 × 10^-9 and was classified as a low-frequency variant with a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.03. Its association was suggested to influence HbA1c potentially through its relationship with fetal hemoglobin, which could affect the accuracy of HbA1c measurement.
title: Impact of rare and common genetic variants on diabetes diagnosis by hemoglobin A1c in multi-ancestry cohorts: The Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine Program

finding: This variant was identified as a top candidate for its role in enhancing PIDD1 promoter activity in breast cancer, supported by reporter assays that indicated its significant effect on promoter activity.
title: DSNetwork: An integrative approach to visualize predictions of variants’ deleteriousness

finding: This variant, like rs7484123, was recognized as a leading candidate linked to PIDD1 promoter activity enhancement, validating its functional significance.
title: DSNetwork: An integrative approach to visualize predictions of variants’ deleteriousness

finding: The SNP rs3842752 was found to interact with rs9273363 in contributing to T1D risk. Specifically, the effect of the GG allele was noted to increase the model output towards a positive T1D prediction, further providing insights into the genetic architecture of the disease.
title: Deep integrative models for large-scale human genomics

finding: The SNP rs3842727, located near the insulin region, was in high linkage disequilibrium with rs3842752 and contributed to the interaction network identified in T1D modeling. Its interactions were pivotal in low-dimensional models, contributing to a more comprehensive understanding of non-linear effects on T1D risk.
title: Deep integrative models for large-scale human genomics

finding: Associations were found for rs1582763 with MS4A6A (p = 0.01), indicating a potential genetic link to tauopathies.
